story:
Utah Rep Needs Your Help

In order for Utah Repertory Theater Company to continue into a second season, we need some sponsorship help!  We have a great season we want to announce, but until we raise the funds we need, this may only be a wish.  It's been a tough first year, but we have had great feedback on our productions. We were hailed as “the most exciting up-and-coming theater company in the state” by Broadway World

Utah Rep is now the resident theater company of the Utah Arts Alliance.  And will be moving into our new venue with BONNIE & CLYDE and all future productions will be held at our new home, THE CUBE, a new black box theater next to the Gateway Mall seating 200 patrons. 

What We Need and What You Get

Utah Rep needs your help!  We are striving to raise additional funds to kick start our 2014 season.  We are dedicated to bringing high-quality productions of seldom-produced plays and musicals to Utah.  With costs of royalties, sets, costumes, rentals, etc., productions can be expensive.  We are making it through our first season, but we need your help to continue.

The Impact

We are dedicated to bringing Utah premieres and powerful musicals and plays that never or seldom make it to Utah.  We strive to bring the most talented performers and designers together to produce high-quality productions.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even a small donation will go a long way!  Please help us today and share our campaign with family and friends!

Read our press release below:

Salt Lake City, Utah (PRWEB) September 29, 2013

Will Utah Embrace Its Newest Theater Company—Utah Repertory Theater Company?

Utah Repertory Theater Company, hailed as “the most exciting up-and-coming theater company in the state” by Broadway World, approaches its first-year anniversary. But will the company see a second season, or will this non-profit company be a flash in the pan, following the pattern of many theater companies closing after their first year?

“I founded Utah Repertory Theater Company as a way to bring high-quality, though seldom-produced, plays and musicals to the state. There is so much talent in Utah, but much of this talent is forced to leave the state to find work,” said Johnny Hebda, the company’s founder and member of the company’s executive board. “Also, I was tired of seeing the same 15 to 20 shows recycled throughout the state year after year. There are many amazing shows with important messages that need to be shared in the state. Theater has always had the power to shape people’s thinking and open people’s eyes to others’ lives and struggles.”

During its first season, the company has produced shows at several different theater venues and employed some of Utah’s most talented performers and artists, from Spanish Fork to Ogden.

Utah Repertory Theater Company, commonly referred to as Utah Rep, took on a very ambitious season, debuting with the musical SIDE SHOW. The company has since presented Utah audiences with five full-length productions, four of which have been Utah premieres. The season has included I LOVE YOU BECAUSE, WHAT THE BELLHOP SAW, Rodgers and Hammerstein’s CAROUSEL, and currently in production, Jonathan Larson’s RENT. The following show will be the state premiere of Frank Wildhorn’s BONNIE & CLYDE.

Each production has received critical acclaim from local reviewers and bloggers. Patrons have given standing ovations and left in tears as they have been moved by the productions. One patron said after CAROUSEL, “I left the theater wanting to be a better person, it made me go home and tell my husband and kids that I love them!” And another patron sent a message after seeing SIDE SHOW that “I have never been moved so much by a production. As someone who has always felt different or didn’t fit in, this show really spoke to me and gave me hope. Thank you for bringing [SIDE SHOW] to Provo.”

Despite its successes, the company has struggled to gain sponsorship and strong attendance.

“It can be discouraging, when you feel that you have put your heart and soul, blood and tears to do everything in your power to make the shows successful, and we don’t receive the full support we need,” said Hebda. “Ticket sales have averaged 25 to 30 percent of the house, which is not covering our operations. I just don’t want our dream to die as we have so much positive momentum. We simply need more patrons and businesses to support our mission.”

Utah Rep has launched an Indiegogo campaign with a goal to raise $10,000. Benefits to contributors include season tickets, flex passes, and tickets to the complete Utah Rep 2014 season. The fundraising event, with all proceeds tax-deductible, can be viewed at http://www.indiegogo.com/projects/utah-rep-s-2014-season-kick-off.

Hebda also announced a resident theater for Utah Rep, in partnership with the Utah Arts Alliance. This non-profit, downtown Salt Lake City arts group has begun to refurbish an adjacent theater known as The Cube specifically for Utah Rep productions.

“Establishing a resident theater location at the Utah Arts Alliance’s The Cube will give Utah Rep an artistic home and increase our visibility as a member of the Utah theater community,” Hebda said.

However, Utah Rep’s quest for funding to remain financially solvent remains.

“If patrons knew some of the obstacles Utah Rep is up against, they would rally to our aid,” said Kymberly Mellen, Utah Rep’s Executive Producer: Artistic Adviser/Casting. “We have been hugely successful in producing shows with increasing production and artistic values. Something that makes our company very different is the focus to pay actors and artists now and increase wages in the future. Other local companies produce good shows but, by never paying actors, expect the actors to subsidize the shows.”

“There is no other theater company like Utah Rep and that’s why Utah so desperately needs it,” said JC Carter, Utah Rep Executive Producer: Business Manager. “Many companies that want to do ‘different’ theater jump way out of the box and produce theater that could only appeal to a very small niche market. Others take risks on certain shows, but often fall quickly back into old, tried-and-true productions. Utah Rep takes a different tactic. The company produces shows that people know, but nobody has dared to do them. Utah needs Utah Rep to wake it up and bring new ideas to the forefront.”

For more information on Utah Rep, visit the company webpage: http://utahrep.org/.

The credentials of the company’s board members are here: http://utahrep.org/information/board/

Source: Broadway World names Utah Rep “the most exciting up-and-coming theater company in the state”http://www.broadwayworld.com/salt-lake-city/article/Summer-Stages-BWWs-Top-Summer-Theatre-Picks-Salt-Lake-City-20130614.

Reviews of Previous Utah Rep Productions

RENT:

RENT is “fantastic” with “stand out performers who got my attention for great acting and fantastic voices.” “It is one of the few shows that I want to go see again before it closes.”—Backstage Utah

http://backstageutah.com/be-sure-to-pay-the-rent-at-the-project/

“The success of [the director's] vision was beyond anything I could have ever expected from a production of RENT in a small, new theater company in Utah, and I left with the honest opinion that the production I just saw would have made Jonathan Larson and the original production team proud.” “As for the cast, each deserves to be praised...”—Utah Theatre Bloggers 

http://utahtheatrebloggers.com/16840/rent-offers-something-new-for-old-fans-and-newcomers

CAROUSEL:

Utah Rep’s production is “exemplary” through “poignant acting, emotional choreography, and wonderful voices.”—Utah Theatre Bloggers Association 

http://utahtheatrebloggers.com/16487/utah-reps-carousel-hits-highs-and-lows-of-life

“Carousel has very strong vocal talent, dancing that can sell its own tickets, and acting that caused a patron that I overheard say, ‘I don’t know why I’m crying, I never cry.’ Director Johnny Hebda amassed an amazing group of talent for this production.”—Front Row Reviewers 

http://frontrowreviewersutah.com/?p=1482

WHAT THE BELLHOP SAW:

“I cannot tell you how impressed I was with this troupe rarely missing a beat of the frantic comedy pacing.”—Larissa Explains It All For You

“Well done one and all, including the show’s director, Chase Ramsey. Directing a farce is akin to herding cats, and Mr. Ramsey managed to deliver a very smooth show.”—Backstage Utah 

http://backstageutah.com/silly-shenanigans-are-what-the-bellhop-saw-at-the-murray-theater/

I LOVE YOU BECAUSE:

“The opportunity to see a group of attractive, talented young people who obviously love the genre [of musical theater] is wonderfully satisfying.”—Salt Lake City Weekly 

http://utahrep.org/city-weekly-utah-repertory-theater-company-i-love-you-because/

“The wonderful talent and enthusiasm onstage created an infectiously upbeat atmosphere from the first entrance to the final bow.”—Backstage Utah 

http://backstageutah.com/i-love-utah-repertory-theater-company-because/

SIDE SHOW:

“SIDE SHOW at the Echo Theatre in Provo is an engaging, poignant, and thought-provoking theatrical experience. The production is a fine debut for the newly christened Utah Repertory Theater Company.”—Broadway World 

http://www.broadwayworld.com/salt-lake-city/article/BWW-Reviews-Utah-Repertory-Theater-Companys-SIDE-SHOW-is-Engaging-and-Poignant-20130123

“You should make whatever arrangements you need to get to Provo and see this amazing production before it ends.”—Backstage Utah 

http://backstageutah.com/come-look-at-the-freaks-in-side-show/

story:
About us

All of Me is a new play about the thrill and secrecy of one man’s gambling addiction, as he attempts to unpack his loneliness, grief and struggle to cope. 

‘When it’s working, you won’t even pay attention to the time; there is no time, there is just that win.’ Welcome to Prime Travels. Gareth’s lost a job, a father, and a lot of money. He still has one thing though – his keys... and a plan.

We are raising money towards a 2 week performance run of All of Me at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival 2016. The play will be performed from Monday 15 - Saturday 27 August, at Greenside Venues (Jade studio, Royal Terrace). 

Written by Martin Brett

Directed by Liz Bacon

Performed by Tommy Burgess

Set design by Nicola Ralph

Anything Other, the company behind the production, are a new theatre company: We delve into the uncertain, explore divisive subjects & put underrepresented voices at the centre of our work. We want to bring people together at different ends of society to create communities on, and beyond, the stage www.anythingother.com


What We Need & What You Get

  • We are raising money to cover the cost of the venue hire, props, set and costume for the 2 week run of the play at Edinburgh Festival.
  • This is Anything Other's first production. We are raising funds to create a high-quality show that explores gambling, obsession, loneliness and addiction; we want to provoke a conversation and bring people together, on and beyond the stage.

The Impact

Your contribution will go directly into the production budget, it will go towards the cost of the venue hire and enable us to purchase set, costume and props. We plan to make back the remaining budget through ticket sales whilst performing at the Fringe.

This is Anything Other's first show- and we want to have an impact. We want to engage audiences with the quality of our work, to provoke conversations, and to connect people through theatre. Any donation will go directly towards this production, helping us to secure the future life of the company in these early stages. On our website www.anythingother.com you'll find more information about our aims and values, if you like what we do, we'd love you to be a part of our community.

Risks & Challenges

Although this is our first production as Anything Other, between us, we have a wealth of experience producing, projecting managing, devising and creating theatre and managing budgets. Liz Bacon is founder and artistic director of Anything Other, and has previously produced large-scale community shows, professional theatre productions and touring theatre shows for organisations including the Barbican Centre, Guildhall School of Music & Drama, Spitalfields Music, Only Connect and Root Theatre. Liz has also previously produced Cannes at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival, which was nominated for a Fringe First award. Liz trained in Theatre Facilitation and Directing at Royal Central School of Speech & Drama and at the Young Vic Theatre as part of Springboard 2016. www.elizabethbacon.co.uk 

Tommy Burgess is just completing a Masters Degree in Acting at Mountview Academy of Theatre Arts, and has a wealth of stage experience having previously performed at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival, and in several award-winning shows with Masquerade Theatre Company in Kent.

http://www.spotlight.com/1419-8943-6132

Nicola Ralph is currently working  in the art department of a prime-time BBC cooking show and recently worked as a set designer for In the Gut by Les Femmes Ridicules at the Brighton Fringe Festival.

Martin Brett works as Operations Manager at Only Connect, a crime-prevention charity in London. His short-stories have won competitions, and he is currently working on a film-script and a selection of short stories. www.martinbrett.net


Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't make a monetary donation, but you're still interested in what we do- we would love to hear from you. Our work is all about people and building communities, so if you'd like to volunteer your skills, or you have an idea that you think we might like, please get in touch: info.anythingother@gmail.com or on twitter @anythingother

If you can't make a donation yourself, please help us share our campaign so we can make an impact.

Thank you for taking the time to find out more about us and our work.

story:
What is Mirenesis?

Mirenesis is the name of our neighbourhood. The buildings are grey. A man is selling simit. There is a party in the park. On a  balcony you can see a green plant growing.



Mirenesis is a contemporary flamenco project by the Turkish dancer Senem Balaban and the Swedish dancer Siri Salminen, taking place in the chaotic and vibrant metropolis of Istanbul. Together with live musicians we are creating a green and grey flamenco performance, asking each other questions, who are you? What is flamenco? Who knows? How can we dance together? In what language should  we speak? What is life, where should you go? What do you do with all the uncertainty?

We have been working with the project since the beginning of 2014, the piece consists of both traditional flamenco and more experimental parts. We started working together with the aim of creating something beyond the stereotypical flamenco cliché, a project expressing our own identities and questions instead of being just another exotistic imitation.


This is a unique collaboration by sincere artists with great integrity. The close collaboration between dancer and musicians is an important part of flamenco, we are therefore happy to work with a highly professional group of people:

Sound artist: Saara Salminen Wallin
Guitar: Doruk Okuyucu
Vocals: Didem Ezgi Kurt & Özgür Çiftçi
Percussion: Mehmed Mert Baycan/Kerem Kırca
Bass guitar: Alper Sonat


Senem Balaban and Siri Salminen are two innovative dance artists, based in Istanbul and Stockholm with many years of flamenco experience both from Turkey, Sweden and Spain.

What we need

We need your support! We are very inspired and would love to perform our piece. We are currently working very hard, thinking, rehearsing, thinking a bit more, rehearsing again, talking etc. So what we are missing is mostly financial support.

We need your help with the following costs:

Rental of performance venue: 1100 USD

Compensation for musicians and dancers: 3400 USD

Studio rental:   450 USD

Sound system: 900 USD

Think about it, why not support a meeting between Turkey and Sweden and flamenco? All taking place in the metropolis of Istanbul, between Asia and Europe. A unique project!




What you get

To show how grateful we are for your support, we have some gifts for you! 
For example, a thank you video specially made for you, your name mentioned as our sponsor on our DVDs, posters etc, a DVD of our performance sent to you and free tickets to our performance. Take this opportunity to show your support and get something memorable in return.

Other ways you can help

You can also support us through social media by following, sharing, liking and leaving comments. Here are our accounts:

facebook.com/mirenesis

instagram.com/mirenesis

twitter.com/mirenesis

We are grateful for all kinds of help from you.



Thank you for your attention! 

Tack!

Teşekkürler! 

Gracias :)

Think about it, why not support a meeting between Turkey and Sweden and flamenco? All taking place in the metropolis of Istanbul, between Asia and Europe. A unique project!



What you get

To show how grateful we are for your support, we have some gifts for you! 
For example, a thank you video specially made for you, your name mentioned as our sponsor on our DVDs, posters etc, a DVD of our performance sent to you and free tickets to our performance. Take this opportunity to show your support and get something memorable in return.


Other ways you can help
You can also support us through social media by following, sharing, liking and leaving comments. Here are our accounts:
facebook.com/mirenesis
instagram.com/mirenesis
twitter.com/mirenesis
We are grateful for all kinds of help from you.





Thank you for your attention! 
Tack!
Teşekkürler! 
Gracias :)

story:
Why is Our 12th Night Different?

Founded in 2010 by Daniel Crane and Erin Sloan, the mission of the Enlightenment Theatre Project is to “present classical works in a vibrant and passionate manner, all while living within the truth of the text we perform." This production of Shakespeare's 12th Night, produced in cooperation with Colonial Williamsburg, promises to deliver on that mission. 12th Night is our first fully-staged production and our third project to date, following successful staged readings of Shakespeare's Cymbeline, and an original adaptation of The Tempest by Mr. Crane, presented at Historic Jamestowne.

So what's different about our production of 12th Night? The Enlightenment Theatre Project will join forces with Colonial Williamsburg to bring a fully staged version of Shakespeare's 12th Night to Williamsburg, VA this December. Nine actors, two musicians, and the 18th-century setting of the Governor’s Palace Ballroom will make this production a must see event. Directed by Daniel Crane, this production features regional actors from Washington DC and New York, including alumni from the Academy for Classical Acting at the Shakespeare Theatre Company in Washington DC. These actors will join local talent from the Williamsburg area, including performers from Colonial Williamsburg, as well as the College of William and Mary. 

We also have the cooperation of Colonial Williamsburg's Costume Design Center to provide period costuming. As you can see in the gorgeous painting above by John Heinrich Ramberg from 1789, courtesy of the Yale Center for British Art, we are going for a very luxurious aesthetic. This production is reminiscent of what would have been seen at the British court during the 18th-century, and is a wonderful fit for the atmosphere of the Governor's Palace Ballroom in Colonial Williamsburg.

With your help, we can create a vibrant theatrical event during the holiday season in Colonial Williamsburg!

Check out Erin Sloan (Olivia) as she walks you through the Governor's Palace and see the one of a kind setting for our production. 

You Can Help! 

12th Night is a chance for those visiting Williamsburg, VA for the holiday season, as well as those who live locally, to experience a production that would normally be found in Washington DC, New York, or other major cities. This is a ticketed event, with 10 performances between December 17th and December 27th; however, the cost of production cannot be fully offset by ticket sales, and $7,500 is needed to bring the production to fruition.

We are offering special access to the first read-thru and design presentation, as well a chance to share meals with the cast (don't you want to dine with Sir Toby Belch?!) and exclusive access to the final dress rehearsal. 

All funds raised will be directly applied to offset the costs of mounting this production. 

Artistic and Historical Impact

This project offers The Enlightenment Theatre Project the opportunity to stage a full work of Shakespeare in a truly unique and historical setting, literally the birthplace of American theatre. This production will give us the opportunity to thoroughly explore this work through the rehearsal process, and share a fully realized production with guests to Colonial Williamsburg during the holiday season.

As we stated earlier, the mission of The Enlightenment Theatre Project is to “present classical works in a vibrant and passionate manner, all while living within the truth of the text we perform." We can imagine no more truthful setting than where theater in North America began, Williamsburg, VA! Check out the following article, http://www.history.org/history/teaching/enewsletter/volume4/april06/theatre.cfm 


    Other Ways You Can Help

    Help get the word out about this incredibly unique production of 12th Night to others! Share our event with the Shakespeare lover or 18th-century re-enactor in your life! Indiegogo has share tools that are easy to use and great in helping to spread the word about our project.

story:
The Project

  • My name is Kailey McCrudden and I am currently finishing my BFA in dance at Temple University.
  • My piece if only was a year long project comprised of doing research and surveying about female body image, and the creation a dance performance which portrays the complex, unresolved relationship each and every woman has with her body.
  • Contributing to this project will help bring this piece on female body image to different audiences, sparking conversation around a topic relevant for women everywhere. 

What We Need & What You Get

  • Funding will go towards transportation of the dancers to and from NYC for three upcoming performances, as well as performance space costs. 
  • Our gratitude for your donation will shown through hand written thank yous, home made cookies, performance footage among other perks!

story:
We are very pleased to announce that The Dance Program at The Exploratory School for Math and Science (MS 447) has been reinstated! We want to thank everyone for their contributions and their help to get the word out that school is "More than Math and Science!" The funds raised will go develop the dance program and make it stronger than ever. Hurray!

The More Than Math & Science Campaign is a sponsored project of MS 447 PTA, a non-profit organization. Contributions for the purposes of More Than Math & Science Campaign must be made payable to MS 447 PTA and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

WHAT WE ARE ABOUT

We are the PTA of MS447, the Exploratory School for Math & Science, in Brooklyn, New York, serving 500 middle schoolers. Late this fiscal year the school was hit with deep budget cuts and reluctantly eliminated their Dance Program, which was part of the school’s core curriculum.

As the PTA we will not take this laying down: not only do we want to reinstate Dance Program of eight years back into the curriculum, we want to send a powerful message to the Department of Education that Dance is not dispensable.

Dance is at the heart of what it means to be educated....not just about Math & Science, critical as they are to understanding our world, but it is how kids get educated about themselves as human beings, about their bodies in positive ways that no school book could ever give them. Dance teaches our children how to be free.

WHAT WE NEED

Basically, what we need is the salary of one person. One teacher. Her job is to inspire the students to dance, to explore their bodies in space, to experience pleasure while discipling their bodies to move in concert with others and to music.


THE IMPACT

Children's bodies change rapidly during these few years of middle school. Dance gives them safe ways to express themselves, all the while getting more confident in who they are as a people in the world. In the face of an obesity epidemic dance gives kids ways to look at their bodies, move their bodies, experience their bodies that are positive, empowering and personal.


Dance helps kids with their academics by integrating the mind-body connection into their experience. Research supports movement for laser focus, mental stamina, and  acuity. Dancing keeps you smart!

But perhaps the best thing the students get from the program is an open opportunity for fun. We all know how valuable that is!

PERKS

We are very lucky to live in New York City where opportunities to see dance are often right outside our doors. Our perks will include opportunities to experience dance in the Big Apple at some of City’s finest venues.

Not only do we have handmade friendship bracelets and happening T-shirts, we will be offering tickets to live performance, access to special events and opportunities to experience this splendid city that are a testament to how important dance is to the New York City experience. Check back with us often and regularly for the best in NYC Perks!

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

If we fall short of our goal (which we won’t) we will fund dance programming in and out of the school and obtain dedicated dance instruction for the Drama Program.


Anyone you know who has a heartbeat needs to know about our campaign. Have them tell their friends then like us on Facebook, love us on Twitter.


Make it easy on yourself: use Indiegogo share tools and broadcast us to the world!

story:
Help support the McGill Savoy Society's 50th year as a service on campus!The McGill Savoy Society is a non-profit, high-profile student theater group producing Gilbert and Sullivan Operettas. Collaborating with various clubs on campus for events, including musical cabarets we are part of a vibrant social and artistic scene at McGill. We need your support for our 2013-2014 season which promises to be our greatest yet! 

for more information please visit: http://mcgillsavoy.ca/

story:
Ariel Rivka Dance is producing our 9th Season Festival May 19-21st at New York Live Arts, in collaboration with RIOULT Dance NY and soloists Heidi Latsky and Elisa King!  Help us make this possible by supporting our season:)

  • Tickets available now!

We will premiere three works, all of which meld live, original music with a range of elegant and bold movements. In Hallelujah Eva, five women dancers explore solitude, and consequently find empowerment through shared experience. Beatrice’s Rainbow features a sprightly trio reveling in the innocence and purity of early life.  With a pulsating live score, Variations on a Box drives the full company of eight dancers to explore the constraints of shape and sound. ARD also reprises Ori from its acclaimed repertoire, a passion-filled work for 7 graceful dancers set to a vigorous and lush score of amplified cellos.

  • Support the Momentum of Ariel Rivka Dance, building larger audiences in dance and collaborations with other companies.
  • ARD is fiscally sponsored by the Live Arts Collaboration, so all donations are tax-deductible and will be used to support this production!
  • Spread the word and send everyone to Ariel Rivka Dance to buy tickets!
Check out Ori here to get a taste of what you'll be supporting and will see when you join us!

story:
Margaret I is a new play about people fighting for what and who they love in a system that says they have no power.  

Women buy 65-70% of theater tickets and write fewer than 20% of the plays produced in any given season.  Less than a third of all roles cast are played by women.  The unexpected success of plays like Fun Home and movies like Mad Max show how eager this audience is to see more of their stories.  Your support helps us continue this conversation.

What sets Margaret I apart, however, is that we hear the men’s experience of the issues as well.  Margaret I is performed by a cast of four men and four women who comment on the story as they perform it, all of them relating their experience of everything from love to violence to fatherhood. It is the other side of Shakespeare’s Henry VI plays in the same way that Rosencrantz and Guildenstern Are Dead is the flip side of Hamlet, using the past to illuminate the present.  The resistance to the first female presidential candidate is the same that Margaret faces as she tries to rule.  Every day in our media we see Elizabeth and Margaret’s desperate fight to protect their children from a violent world.  In Joan, we see the face of the refugees uprooted by war from Dadaab to Bae Mae Surin.  In Eleanor, the discomfort we still have with a woman’s ruthless ambition. 

The characters also narrate the story using found text.  My original plan was use only scenes from Shakespeare's plays, with interstitial text entirely from Holinshed and Hall, Shakespeare’s sources.  As I researched, however, I discovered a wealth of forgotten texts by medieval and renaissance women.  Those texts now form most of the spine and lyrics.

It is a contemporary retelling, in a raw performance space with minimal set and costume pieces.  It’s not about the fashion and manners of the period, but the ideas and dynamics.  The way they treat each other within their hierarchy has a lot to say about how we treat each other within ours.

The goal of this play is to tell a fascinating story that’s been hidden in plain sight.  Just as modern women have stories they keep from friends and lovers, history is littered with women fighting great odds, just out of frame.

By contributing to this fundraiser, you will help us present a public workshop for Margaret I.  Your donation will get us rehearsal space, fabric, props and - most importantly - performance time for our amazing equity actors.  We literally cannot do it without you!

Elyzabeth Gorman, director and dramaturg

Elyzabeth Gorman is a sponsored artist with Performance Zone Inc (dba The Field), a not-for-profit, tax-exempt, 501(c)(3) organization serving the performing arts community. Contributions to The Field earmarked for Elyzabeth Gorman are tax-deductible to the extent allowed by law. For more information about The Field contact: The Field, 75 Maiden Lane, Suite 906 New York, NY 10038, phone: 212-691-6969 or fax: 212-255-2053 or for our national charities registration, see details. A copy of our latest financial report may be obtained from The Field or from the Office of Attorney General, Charities Bureau, 120 Broadway, New York, NY 10271.

story:
Why Toronto?

"After debuting 'You Are Perfect 'off-off Broadway in February of 2016, we felt a need to share this story with audiences across the border, with people for whom these horrific events don’t hit as close to home.  We are very interested in seeing if Canadian audiences can help us better understand this tragedy.”-- Playwright and Producing Artistic Director Cyndy A. Marion

We were thrilled  to learn we had been selected as just one of 15 international artist groups accepted into The Toronto Fringe Festival. Seeking a fresh take on the play, WHTC enlisted Rhys J. McClelland, a 2004  Director’s Guild of Britain award-winner, to direct.  The Canadian premiere also features a new cast including Lindsay Danielle Gitter as Susan Atkins, Kristin Samuelson as The Woman and Alexander Reed as Charles Manson.  

The Toronto Fringe Festival is our FIRST opportunity to share WHTC’s vision of high-caliber American drama with an International Audience.

The Impact

We need your help to bring "You Are Perfect" to Canada.  Producing theater is expensive. It's even more expensive when you are facing additional costs of taking a show on the road. Aside from our usual production costs, which include rehearsal space, scenery, props, costumes, and marketing, we are now also facing the costs of travel and housing.  We need to transport  3 actors and 6 staff members to Toronto--that costs money!  We also need to throw our cast and crew a bone by providing stipends to help offset the cost of food and local travel.  Unlike when we produce in NYC, our artists will not be able to work other jobs while they are in production. 

Your gifts will make this possible!  We need to raise $10,000.  Your generous donations will cover these additional costs of travel, food & housing. You will be helping us take "You Are Perfect" and White Horse Theater Company to Canadian audiences!

The Play:

Inspired by the story of Susan Atkins, a real-life member of the Manson family (a quasi-commune led by murder-conspirator Charles Manson in California in the late 1960's), "You Are Perfect" uses a unique structure and narrative to enter the world of Manson’s ardent disciple, who was implicated in at least eight coldblooded killings, including the infamous Tate/LaBianca murders.

The world premiere of "You Are Perfect" was produced by White Horse Theater Company at The Workshop Theater Co., NYC (Feb. 2016) and received both audience and critical praise. 

The material dealing with the Sharon Tate murders is still fascinating almost half a century later... This is a little gem of a show." --Mark Savitt, Hi Drama!

"After you've seen more Broadway plays than one can count, it's amazing when a production really stands out... Cyndy Marion has redefined the narrative of one of America's saddest moments. She has taken us to a place of understanding by pulling back the veil of a forbidden subject. An event many want to suppress and forget, instead of forgive." --Scott Cowan, Spotlight 

About Us

Now in our 14th year, White Horse Theater Company is a not-for-profit organization dedicated to producing and developing American plays. We seek to investigate and celebrate American culture by re-examining American classics and nurturing new American voices. White Horse is committed to making high-quality theater and sharing our passion for American plays and playwrights with our fellow artists and audiences.  We are known for producing the work of Sam Shepard including Eyes for Consuela, The Late Henry Moss and True West as well as many of Tennessee Williams' lesser-known works including Clothes for a Summer Hotel, A Perfect Analysis Given by a Parrot and In The Bar of a Tokyo Hotel.

Other Work

"Directors who choose the crutch of magical realism when approaching a Sam Shepard play would be better served by recognizing the magic of realism as Cyndy A. Marion has skillfully done in THE LATE HENRY MOSS." Andrea Stevens, The New York Times

"No one does Williams plays like White Horse." Sherri Rase, QONSTAGE.COM on Suddenly Last Summer

The Team

This production includes many our trusted artistic collaborators and a number of new ones! We are an international team originating from 6 different countries including the United States, Great Britain, New Zealand, South Africa and last but not least Canada.

Team:

Writer: Cyndy A. Marion; Directed by Rhys. J. McCelland; Featuring: Lindsay Danielle Gitter, Kristin Samuelson and Alexander Reed.                                      

Staff

Sets:  Ruth Albertyn; Lighting: Debra Leigh Siegel; Costumes: Derek Nye Lockwood ; Original Score: Joe Gianono; Sound Design: Andy Evan Cohen; Dramaturgy: Vanessa R. Bombardieri;   Production Stage Manager: Benjamin A. Vigil; AD/ASM: Kat Brannan-Williams,     Fight Choreography: Ray A. Rodriguez; Dance Choreography: Kathryn E. Cashin; Dialect Coach: Julie Foh; Associate Producer: James Michael Hughes; Press Representative: Sweat Equity PR       
 

More Love?

If you have made it to this page, that means that theater is probably important to you in the same way that it is important to us!  Please show us the love.  This could be through a donation, by speaking about our production to those you know or by posting about our show on social media using our hashtag. Simply click the icons above and use #youareperfect. 

Our Toronto performances dates are listed below: Fri. July 7 @1:45pm, Sat. July 8 @9:15pm, Mon. July 10th @5pm, Tues. July 11 @8pm, Wed. July 12 @ 3:30pm, Fri. July 14th @11pm & Sat. July 15th @8:45pm  @ Theatre Passe Muraille- Mainspace.  You can check out fringetoronto.com  for ticket info.   

Thanks

Thank you for helping to make off-off Broadway theater not only survive but thrive.  We have had a wonderful 14 years of producing here in NYC and with your help we will be able to share our work with our Northern Canadian neighbors!

McClelland, a 2004  Director’s Guild of Britain award-winner, to direct.  The Canadian premiere also features a new cast including Lindsay Danielle Gitter as Susan Atkins, Kristin Samuelson as The Woman and Alexander Reed as Charles Manson.  The Toronto Fringe Festival is our FIRST opportunity to share WHTC’s vision of high-caliber American drama with an International Audience.The ImpactWe need your help to bring "You Are Perfect" to Canada.  Producing theater is expensive. It's even more expensive when you are facing additional costs of taking a show on the road. Aside from our usual production costs, which include rehearsal space, scenery, props, costumes, and marketing, we are now also facing the costs of travel and housing.  We need to transport  3 actors and 6 staff members to Toronto--that costs money!  We also need to throw our cast and crew a bone by providing stipends to help offset the cost of food and local travel.  Unlike when we produce in NYC, our artists will not be able to work other jobs while they are in production. Your gifts will make this possible!  We need to raise $10,000.  Your generous donations will cover these additional costs of travel, food & housing. You will be helping us take "You Are Perfect" and White Horse Theater Company to Canadian audiences!The Play:Inspired by the story of Susan Atkins, a real-life member of the Manson family (a quasi-commune led by murder-conspirator Charles Manson in California in the late 1960's), "You Are Perfect" uses a unique structure and narrative to enter the world of Manson’s ardent disciple, who was implicated in at least eight coldblooded killings, including the infamous Tate/LaBianca murders.The world premiere of "You Are Perfect" was produced by White Horse Theater Company at The Workshop Theater Co., NYC (Feb. 2016) and received both audience and critical praise. The material dealing with the Sharon Tate murders is still fascinating almost half a century later... This is a little gem of a show." --Mark Savitt, Hi Drama!"After you've seen more Broadway plays than one can count, it's amazing when a production really stands out... Cyndy Marion has redefined the narrative of one of America's saddest moments. She has taken us to a place of understanding by pulling back the veil of a forbidden subject. An event many want to suppress and forget, instead of forgive." --Scott Cowan, Spotlight About UsNow in our 14th year, White Horse Theater Company is a not-for-profit organization dedicated to producing and developing American plays. We seek to investigate and celebrate American culture by re-examining American classics and nurturing new American voices. White Horse is committed to making high-quality theater and sharing our passion for American plays and playwrights with our fellow artists and audiences.  We are known for producing the work of Sam Shepard including Eyes for Consuela, The Late Henry Moss and True West as well as many of Tennessee Williams' lesser-known works including Clothes for a Summer Hotel, A Perfect Analysis Given by a Parrot and In The Bar of a Tokyo Hotel.Other Work"Directors who choose the crutch of magical realism when approaching a Sam Shepard play would be better served by recognizing the magic of realism as Cyndy A. Marion has skillfully done in THE LATE HENRY MOSS." Andrea Stevens, The New York Times"No one does Williams plays like White Horse." Sherri Rase, QONSTAGE.COM on Suddenly Last SummerThe TeamThis production includes many our trusted artistic collaborators and a number of new ones! We are an international team originating from 6 different countries including the United States, Great Britain, New Zealand, South Africa and last but not least Canada.Team:Writer: Cyndy A. Marion; Directed by Rhys. J. McCelland; Featuring: Lindsay Danielle Gitter, Kristin Samuelson and Alexander Reed.                                      StaffSets:  Ruth Albertyn; Lighting: Debra Leigh Siegel; Costumes: Derek Nye Lockwood ; Original Score: Joe Gianono; Sound Design: Andy Evan Cohen; Dramaturgy: Vanessa R. Bombardieri;   Production Stage Manager: Benjamin A. Vigil; AD/ASM: Kat Brannan-Williams,     Fight Choreography: Ray A. Rodriguez; Dance Choreography: Kathryn E. Cashin; Dialect Coach: Julie Foh; Associate Producer: James Michael Hughes; Press Representative: Sweat Equity PR        More Love?If you have made it to this page, that means that theater is probably important to you in the same way that it is important to us!  Please show us the love.  This could be through a donation, by speaking about our production to those you know or by posting about our show on social media using our hashtag. Simply click the icons above and use #youareperfect. Our Toronto performances dates are listed below: Fri. July 7 @1:45pm, Sat. July 8 @9:15pm, Mon. July 10th @5pm, Tues. July 11 @8pm, Wed. July 12 @ 3:30pm, Fri. July 14th @11pm & Sat. July 15th @8:45pm  @ Theatre Passe Muraille- Mainspace.  You can check out fringetoronto.com  for ticket info.   ThanksThank you for helping to make off-off Broadway theater not only survive but thrive.  We have had a wonderful 14 years of producing here in NYC and with your help we will be able to share our work with our Northern Canadian neighbors!

story:
Who we are

 

We, ODE. Movements, are committed to ground-breaking, transformative story-telling within which the Artist is challenged to re-envision the archetypal portrayals of violence, intimidation and fear; to awaken in our colleagues a desire to address the subject matter from a fresh perspective. We wish to provide a platform for the artists to have their work showcased and shared while strengthening an Arts Community culture where the work we create stimulates artists and audiences alike to expand the imagination. We wish to inspire humankind to have a desire to extend its vision and seek the opportunity to exchange ideas and inspire moments of optimism. Together, we hope to form an international family of members to bring inspiration and innovation to every project and promote respect for diversity in an age of global community.

We are a non-profit society and our board is an international group of people with varied backgrounds and cultures. www.odemovements.com

This year, we have the honor to present in association with Up In the Air Theatre, 'NeOn' written by Mayumi Yoshida and directed by Laura McLean, as part of the rEvolver festival 2017 (https://www.upintheairtheatre.com/neon).

We need your help to bring this beautiful story to life and to help support the amazingly talented people working with us on this production. We believe passion drives all art but artists need not always be 'starving artists'.

NeOn-ね音-

Framed around the revelation of a deep secret within Mayumi Yoshida’s beloved late grandmother’s arranged marriage, NeOn is a look at Love. True Love: does it exist? Has anyone ever got it right? Are there different forms of True Love? Why have we all been, all over the world, conditioned to yearn for it? Told through multiple intertwining stories, NeOn transcends generations, continents and language. An « international citizen’s » charming look at what it means to negotiate love on either part of the world.

The SHOULDs, WOULDs and COULDs about choice…and the grace of accepting when there isn’t one.

*Performed in English and Japanese (with English subtitles).

What We Need & What You Get

The target of $1500 is primarily to help us remunerate our cast and crew as they deserve. Creating art is incredible but funding it in a way that also includes paying everyone on board what they deserve is often difficult. We have a cast of 6 and crew of 8. 

Anything beyond that would go towards bringing the world of this beautiful play to life and support our set designing/building. 

Anything beyond that would go towards our marketing efforts to get the word out about the show.

We are so grateful for any kind of support, so please share this campaign and spread the word about 'NeOn' at rEvolver 2017(https://www.upintheairtheatre.com/neon) at the Cultch May 24 - 28. 

Any contribution helps! But in return you'll get some sweet perks like becoming a member or getting tickets to the show and some opportunities to showcase your projects or products on our platforms!

The Impact

We feel that the story of 'NeOn' is so important and relevant today. It is a multi-cultural, multi-generational story that takes a look at how we relate to others in our lives and to ourselves. We feel that in this day and age, when we are all more connected than ever, we actually are getting more disconnected from each other and have a more difficult time relating to the people around us. Everyone can connect with a part of that story and we think it needs to be told. 

In addition, as a society that is deeply rooted in the community, your support means more than we can tell. We want to ensure that the arts community in this city is here to support each other. We want to be able to remunerate the dedicated artists working hard to bring this story to life. We want to support a still growing local theater community, and you are a part of that! 

We would love your help to strengthen a global community where love and support is at the forefront; art helps us all create the world, let's make it a kind one.

ODE. Movements Society has been around since 2013 and has incorporated as a non-profit about a year ago. We have produced numerous events, plays and film. Two of our past projects, Pockets of Light and Same Boat, have benefited from incredible community support through Indiegogo, reaching beyond our goals and making those projects huge successes at bringing people together, and Same Boat by David C. Jones even won the people's choice awards at the Queer film festival. For more information on these projects, please check our website www.odemovements.com or our facebook page https://www.facebook.com/odemovements/ 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute financially, and we totally get that! We appreciate any kind of support you can give us. 

Here's how else you can help:

  • Get the word out and make some noise about this campaign!
    #revolverfest #revolver2017neon #odemovements
    @odemovements @UITATheatre
  • Don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools!
  • Come check out 'NeOn' by Mayumi Yoshida presented by rEvolver festival (https://www.upintheairtheatre.com/neon) and ODE. Movements Society and directed by Laura McLean at the Cultch Historic Theatre on May 24th 7:00pm, May 26th 9:30pm, May 27th 3:30pm and May 28th 6:00pm. The Cultch  
    1895 Venables Street, Vancouver. The Cultch Box Office  www.tickets.thecultch.com or 604.251.1363.

story:
＊日本語は下記に記載しております。

 

"Whited Sepulcher" on Competition Final

After many years dancing and learning from amazing choreographers from all over the world, I’ve developed interest in the actual creation of dance and started to pursue my own choreographic work.  My recent work, Whited Sepulcher has been selected to go to the final at the International Choreographic Competition, held in Yokohama, Japan.  I need financial support to be able to cover airfare for me and my four dancers to be able to perform and participate in this Incredible event.

Competition Website: http://yokohama-dance-collection.jp

 

A an independent emerging female artist, with no company structure or grants facilitating my projects yet, being selected as a finalist (10 choreographers out of 138 choreographers from all around the world) is truly a milestone for me.  I want to honor this exciting opportunity not only to present my work there, but to also broaden my audience, and have the chance to exchange knowledge, artistry and the creativities in the art of dance with the other choreographers and judges from all over the world.

I am asking for your support for my first participation to the International Choreographic Competition.  Your generosity will be what makes this possible.  THANK YOU!
 

What I Need & What You Get

I need to be able to cover airfare,  (5 round trip tickets Sapporo/Tokyo) and 4 nights of hotel accommodations (3 rehearsal days and 2 performance days).

It is important and useful for artists in this era to showcase our work, experience and creation with the social media platforms.  I will be creating a blog about the competition final and rehearsals up the performance.  The blog will be shared online for backers to see all the creative and artistic exchange happening within the events with other finalists from different countries.

The blog:  http://asamidance.wixsite.com/blog

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can not contribute with money now, it’s all good!  You can simply share my campaign on your social media pages and with your friends.

 

私は３歳からバレエを始め、これまで沢山の振付家の作品を踊る機会に恵まれてきました。世界中の様々なスタイルのダンス作品に触れるうちに、与えられた振付を踊るだけではなく、自ら振付をして、表現の可能性を広げたいと強く思うようになりました。現在はアメリカの振付家育成学校に通いながら、振付の勉強をしております。

今回、私の振付作品　”私は墓をしろく塗りたる”　が、公益財団法人横浜市芸術文化振興財団主催の横浜ダンスコレクション2017、国際振付コンクールの本選出場作品に選ばれました。海外からを含め１３８組の応募作品の中から、１０名のファイナリストの1人として選ばれたことを大変嬉しく、光栄に思います。この貴重な機会に、舞台での作品発表だけではなく、世界中から集まる参加者や審査員から知識や想像力などを吸収して、より芸術性の高い作品を今後発表したいと思います。

コンクールホームページ：http://yokohama-dance-collection.jp

 

ご協力ください

本選に出場するにあたり、資金のご協力をいただける方を募集しております。ご協力いただいた資金は以下の用途に使用いたします。

－　航空券：東京／札幌往復券、出演ダンサ－４人分を含めた５枚

－　横浜滞在費：５名宿泊費、５泊分（リハーサル３日、コンクール２日）

 

特典

資金提供にご協力いただいた方には、作品のブルーレイやTシャツ、コンクール本番の鑑賞チケットなど様々な特典をご用意しております。

また２１世紀の芸術家にとって、制作過程や作品の発表をソーシャルメディアで行うことは、とても重要で効果的です。今回ご協力いただいた皆様には、ブログにて横浜での本選の様子や、本番に向けてのリハーサル、そして国際色豊かな他のファイナリスト達との交流の様子を発表いたします。

ブログ：　http://asamidance.wixsite.com/blog

 

資金以外にも、、、ご協力をお願いします。

SNSで是非このページをシェアしてください！

皆様のご協力により、本選での作品発表が可能になります。どうかお力をお貸しください。よろしくお願い致します。お読みいただきまして、誠に有難うございます！

 

Video donated by Kyoto Ruch and Francisco Lopez

ブログ：　http://asamidance.wixsite.com/blog

皆様のご協力により、本選での作品発表が可能になります。どうかお力をお貸しください。よろしくお願い致します。お読みいただきまして、誠に有難うございます！
 
Video donated by Kyoto Ruch and Francisco Lopez

story:
Short Summary

Kidz Theater needs your help to produce our 2018 season!  We are currently dealing with the skyrocketing costs of production in New York City--while we are looking to raise $10,000, which isn't even a quarter of production cost for a single show.  Kidz Theater has become a home for its staff and returning company members and we are determined to keep it GOING! That's where you come in!

What We Need & What You Get

Our goal is $10,000 for this season.  It costs well over $25,000 to produce each show, so this money would be instrumental in providing rehearsal space, renting the theater, props, costumes, set, as well as making sure we can keep mainstage participation for our mentor performers COMPLETELY FREE!

The Impact

Our program primarily serves as a training ground for children and teenagers pursuing careers in musical theater and technical theater.  This season, our productions were performed and operated by a VERY talented group of teenagers working both on and off stage.  Our performers have gone off to alma maters such as Boston Conservatory, University of Cincinnati College-Conservatory of Music (CCM), Carnegie Mellon, Pace University, New York University,  Elon University, Point Park University, Shenandoah University, among others; and have appeared on Broadway in Aladdin, Les Miserables, Dear Evan Hansen, The Book of Mormon, Evita, and The Phantom of the Opera; on the West End in Dreamgirls and in National Tours in Newsies, Les Miserables, among others.

Risks & Challenges

The disappearance of Kidz Theater would mean the disappearance of one of the strongest performing arts educational platforms in the tri-state area.  

Children and teenagers who want to pursue careers as performers look at us as a way to de-mystify the process; we recognize their love for performing and we turn it into amazing productions and give them roles that equally challenge them and allow them to have fun.  Without your help, we could be at risk of closing our doors forever.

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word!  Tell your friends! Tell your friends' friends! Text them, call them, email them. We need word of mouth to get out about Kidz Theater so that people know who we are and what we do.  We rely on you all to keep our home growing and changing, and we TRULY thank you for all that you have done and continue to do.

story:
About Me

I'm Megan Riordan, a performer and theatremaker. With my company Making Strange, I've produced and performed in award-winning, world-touring shows including the Irish premieres of Hedwig and the Angry Inch and The Last Days of Judas Iscariot, and the original creations Luck and You Remember the Stories You Wish Were True. As a performer, I've appeared as Girl in Once: The Musical, originated the role of Liza Field in Frank McGuinness's musical Donegal at the Abbey, and toured Australia, New York, and Toronto (amidst multiple Dublin runs too) with THISISPOPBABY in RIOT. After a hiatus from making work, I'm finally returning with this project I've had in mind for years, in a festival in Dublin very close to my heart.

 

About the Show

The show, It's Not About Love, asks these questions and more: what does it mean that the Romeo and Juliet story is one of the first love stories of which we become aware at a young age, and it's about teenagers who wreak havoc and die? What is the effect of this being the first Shakespeare play that people usually see or read? And what place does this story have in the world as it is today? 

 

It's Not About Love is directed by Aoife Spillane-Hinks and performed with some of Dublin's most exciting and prolific musicians, including Ruth McGill of The Evertides. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

We're crowdfunding at least €2000 to get the show ready for the festival. Our perks include special limited-edition badges, tickets to opening night, and most excitingly, behind-the-scenes videos, including bespoke sonnet recitations according to your whim or specially recorded performances of songs considered for the show but didn't quite make it. You could even get a personal Shakespeare workshop for you and friends!

 

Your pledge goes to all those wonderful up-front requirements, including buying set, costume, and lighting; booking rehearsal space; paying the musicians, director, and designers for their valuable time; and documenting performances to help the show's future life and the opportunity to revive the show and tour! 

 

The Impact

Your contribution will ease the challenges of birthing a new show into the world by reassuring us that our vision will come to be, and therefore allowing us to focus on creating rather than admin. I've run successful crowdfunding campaigns in the past, most specifically for my show You Remember the Stories You Wish Were True, and the difference it makes to the creative process knowing that cash flow is taken care of is immeasurable. It's Not About Love is a true labour of, well, love, and--without spoiling too much about the show--we believe the journey we'll give the audience and what they'll leave feeling is joyous, life-affirming, and necessary. All funds raised at this point give us more access to creating that experience for you.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread the word amongst your networks if you think this would be of interest to your friends, even if they're not in Dublin or Ireland--with enough momentum and documentation, we'll be able to take this show anywhere. Indiegogo has handy share tools for social media and we'd love for you to use them.

story:
About:

CoreDance Contemporary is an Australian Modern Dance Company residing in New York City. Founded by Artistic Director Rebecca McCormac in March 2011, the company is comprised of six dance artists who bring different cultural and dance backgrounds to the fore, to form a hardworking and dedicated ensemble.

CoreDances' objective is to investigate choreographically, different and oft times contradictory movement vocabulary through the physicality of one’s kinetics and to explore the realization of this physicality as it takes shape in the space.  Ms McCormac has an interdisciplinary approach to her work drawing ideas both contextually and visually to create work that is engaging for herself and her audience.  CoreDance has presented work at:  APAP, The ODC Theatre San Francisco, Your Move NJ, Alvin Ailey, New York City Center, Steps on Broadway, DANY Studios, PMT, Dixon Place, White Wave, Triskelion Arts, The Actors Fund Arts Center and Green Space.

Campaign:

CoreDance's "Stratagem" Campaign is being launched to assist the company produce and present its 2018 Spring Season.  This venture is an important goal at this stage in the company's timeline as we are trying to make a name for ourselves in the ever competitive dance industry that is New York City.  Contributions will help pay for:

*  Theatre Rental

*  Rehearsal Space

*  Costume Design and Manufacture

*  Graphic Design and Printing for Marketing Purposes

*  Lighting Design

*  Videography

*  Photography

Goal:

Our goal is to raise $1500.00 to help with production values.  If our goal is not reached the amount obtained will be used solely for Theatre Rental at The Mark O'Donnell Theatre at The Actors Fund Arts Center in Brooklyn, NY.

Perks:

We are providing an opportunity to observe CoreDance Contemporary in Rehearsal to anyone who contributes $50.00.

Any contribution is helpful, so even if you can't make one of monetary value we would just love it if you could spread the word and make some noise about our campaign. 

You can find us at:

http://coredancecontemp.wixsite.com/dance-company

https://www.facebook.com/CoreDanceContemporary/

https://www.instagram.com/coredancecontemporary/

To reserve tickets to "Stratagem" please visit:  https://stratagem.bpt.me

Thanks so much for showing your interest in our campaign.

Artistic Director:  Rebecca McCormac

Dance Artists:  Rebecca Allen, Jessica Nolan, Brittany Piazza, Quilvio Rodriguez, and Ashley Zimmerman

With:  Kathleen Bollana

story:
Short Summary

Angry Young Men ltd is a puppet creation and performance company that was founded in 2007.  The team was gathered together to create Night Of The Living Dead - The Puppet Show!  We've been performing that show every Halloween ever since and we've also performed NOTLD-TPS at colleges and multiple horror conventions around the country.  We've been performing NOTLD-TPS at the Oriental Theater for 6 years now.  The Oriental Theater has been great to us but there are limitations to performing in that space due to the nature of it being a Movie Theater: we couldn't rent the space on the weekend and there are light and sound issues that made it hard for our audiences to see/hear us.  Since this is our 10th Anniversary of NOTLD-TPS we wanted to nip those issues in the bud and do everything PERFECT this year.  This has led us to securing the Next Act Theater Performance Space as our show location for the 10th Anniversary Show.  An ACTUAL theatre space with actual theatre lights and seating close enough to see and hear everything we do!

That leads us to the reason behind this campaign.  We don't like asking for a hand out so we're treating this campaign as an Investment Opportunity.  Our contributors can secure a VIP seat in a reserved section and also get swag and a chance to be a part of the show!  Using the campaign as an Advance Ticket Sales Machine will allow us to pay our rental fee up front so we can stop worrying about money and kick zombie butt doing the show!

Renting the Next Act Theater performance space is a bit more costly than the Oriental, but having access to the space all week and getting to do 3 performances are all major improvements to the show!  It will look better than it ever has and we will be more prepared than ever before!  Our fans are why we keep doing this show year after year.  Having the fans help the show BEFORE it begins will bind them even closer to our hearts and the undying legacy that is Night Of The Living Dead - The Puppet Show!

What We Need

We have already paid the deposit to secure the Next Act Performance Space.  Here is the rest of what we need to make this show shine!

  • $1,900 - The remainder of our rental cost
  • $250 - Insurance Certificate needed to perform in the space
  • $200 - Marketing materials: posters/postcards, etc.
  • $650 - SWAG: new T-shirts, new buttons, new stuff with our logo on it so you can take it home!

What You Get

  • a $10 donation gets you a unique NOTLD-TPS related button!
  • a $20 donation gets you a VIP Ticket to one of the performances AND a button!
  • a $30 donation gets you a NOTLD-TPS T-shirt AND a button!
  • a $50 donation means you can get both the VIP and T-shirt packages! (just claim both the $20 and $30 perk when you give $50)
  • a $100 donation gets you the VIP ticket, the T-Shirt, the Button and YOU get to be one of our Gore Technicians during the show!  That means you get a great seat AND you get to throw blood and zombie brains!  There are only 4 of these perks available per show.
  • a $500 donation gets you the VIP ticket, the T-Shirt, the Button, Gore Technician status and...YOU GET TO BE A GUEST ZOMBITEER!!  That's right, YOU will join us on stage and see what it's like to be a zombie!  There is only 1 Guest Zombiteer perk available per show.

TO CLAIM A PERK YOU HAVE TO DONATE BY CLICKING ON THE PERK ITSELF

If we don't reach our main goal then any of the money we raised will go directly to the Next Act rental and we'll combine our penny jars to make the rest happen.

If we make more than our goal we will be able to turn our tech volunteers into paid staff!  We'll invest in more swag!  We may even put down a deposit at Next Act for next year's show!

This show means the world to us and we love the people who come back to see it year after year.  We've met a good number of the original cast of the original Night Of The Living Dead (as well as the Dawn and Day movies) and they've seen our show and treated us like we're doing the Lord's Work.

If you can't contribute to this campaign you can always just buy a regular ticket to see the show.  Tickets go on sale October 1st at nextact.org.  And if you can't share your funds then please share the good word of our Zombie Puppet Mayhem.  We just won't stay dead.

story:
Our goal is to mount great shows.

Greenbelt Arts Center's performance space is used for resident and guest company productions, a summer youth theatre camp, and community events such as the Utopia Film Festival.  Greenbelt residents of all ages are involved in the production of these events and enable our audiences (many of whom are also Greenbelt residents) to experience live theater, music and dance in an intimate space. 

Turning a bowling alley / archery range into a sophisticated theatre space is no easy task. While our current lighting setup functions, the electrical cabling consists of extension cords of multiple lengths and colors.  Concerns have been raised about this ad hoc arrangement.  The mass of exposed cabling, especially at the power packs, is unsightly and difficult to modify. 

Because our performance space has two configurations (with seating on three sides of the stage and with all seating facing the entrance), creating effective lighting can involve relocation and re-cabling of most of the lighting instruments.  This complex and even daunting process makes individual lighting for a show extremely time-consuming, requiring frequent trips up and down ladders and making reconfiguration more work and less safe.

WHAT ARE WE GOING TO DO?

  • The four power packs above our performance space will be relocated to a utility room behind the tech booth at the rear of the theater. 100 fixed outlets in strategic locations throughout the theater will be mounted on the ceiling.
  •  The wiring for those will be run, in conduit, back to the lighting closet.
  •  Connection of the outlets (and lighting instruments plugged into them} to the power packs will be made by a patch panel, allowing needed flexibility in the use of the outlets.

HOW WILL THIS MAKE THINGS BETTER?

  • SAFER ENVIRONMENT -- Permanent cabling in conduits will reduce the possibility of an electrical fire in the space. Installation of ceiling outlets throughout the space will  reduce the number of ladder trips needed to move a lighting instrument or reconfigure the space.
  •  EASIER TO USE SPACE -- We are simplifying our lighting setup  Users will be able to translate a lighting design into actuality more quickly and with less drudgery.
  •  IMPROVED AUDIENCE EXPERIENCE -- Our space will be more pleasing to our audiences because we will be removing the many ugly cables and the noticeable humming of the four power packs from the performance space.
  •  HIGHER QUALITY LIGHTING DESIGN -- Designers will be able to focus more on the quality of the lighting and less on the physical demands of placing the lights.

story:
Mister B. Gone, based on the novel by Clive Barker, is a new musical about the life of Jakabok Botch, a young demon. With his companion, Quitoon, Jakabok witnesses the full range of human capability, from its most joyful highs to its most violent lows. 

More than anything, Mister B. Gone is about humanity. This story is about the compassion it takes to love another being. It is a tale of self-discovery.

Terra Warman and Rachel Chung both grew up in Cincinnati, Ohio, but they met in 2017 in New York City. The writers have focused their work on the portrayal of universal stories told by individuals. At its heart, Mister B. Gone is a story of self-destruction. The missteps and relationships that color Jakabok's memoir are piercingly familiar.

Told through music with a folk-rock vibe, this story is both uplifting and terrifying. We hope to deliver an immersive, worthwhile experience to our audience through innovative storytelling.

story:
“Everyone is the Son of Somebody”: Who We Are

Cloud of Fools Theater Company, based in New York City, is a company of alumni from Columbia University’s Graduate Acting Program. We have been training, teaching workshops, participating in symposia, and performing here in New York and in international festivals (in Germany, Italy, and Puerto Rico) since 2003. 

The root of our theater as a “Cloud of Fools” is our ongoing, rigorous practical explorations – our training – which is part of a lineage leading back from this moment through many generations. Simply put, we find our way forward by listening to (and conversing with) the masters of the past. Master playwrights, yes, but more concretely, master teachers and actors who remain with us through the living re-engagement of their bodies of physical knowledge, passed down from maestro to apprentice across time and culture. For example, we are trained by maestro Niky Wolcz, who was in turn trained by his mentors; traditions have been passed down to us from all over Europe, Russia, India, and Asia. From these deep wells of human story and theatrical experience, we unfold a theater at once timeless, and ceaselessly new.

So, in our process we ask: “As bodies in space that are vibrant with this living knowledge, how much can we conjure into the theater – and therefore into the imagination which we will ultimately share with our audience”? (That is, with you!)  And, trusting in the depth of such imaginative resources, we ask, “How much can we create – from how little?”

Cloud of Fools Theater Company is Jon Froehlich, Susan Hyon, Laura Butler Rivera, and Casey Robinson


Stepping into the Fray: About The Whistling Mortician 

“When the powers of death crop up at every turn, what else can one do...but whistle?”  Like the holy fools before him and the characters of Chaplin and Keaton a couple generations later, The Whistling Mortician postulates the life of a puckish Prussian laborer living in the hotbed of 1870’s Alsace-Lorraine. One fateful day following the Franco-Prussian war, he whistles the wrong national anthem up and down the streets of town – and directly into trouble. Fleeing to far-off countries and meeting colorful characters all the way, he finds himself drawn towards the work that will define his life.”

Using some sticks, a bit of foam board, and our selves, the world of The Whistling Mortician will traverse whole continents and oceans as it unfurls the whimsical journey of our hero. Music, death, war, and waltzing: we’re curious to see just how significantly a simple tune can change a life.

We are thrilled to be featured at the PAM 2012 Festival presented by IATI Theater http://www.teatroiati.org

Location: Baruch Performing Arts Center

Purchase tickets: click on your desired show date below.

            Saturday, July 28, 2012 at 10:00pm

            Sunday, August 5, 2012 at 3:00pm

            Thursday, August 9, 2012 at 7:00pm

The Whistling Mortician cast: Amanda Boekelheide, Michael Buffer, Jon Froehlich, Natalia Miranda Guzmán, Eddie Jackson, Daniel Levitt, Casey Robinson, Jenny Tibbels-Jordan


Many Sources, A Mighty River: What We Need

Our expenses total $6,900. This includes costs for marketing, production material, the production staff, and the creative team. 

Our fundraising goal is $4,000. This amount will enable us to pay the ensemble (8 performers) a stipend of $500 for their work and commitment, which began on April 29 and extends through August 9. The pay is a gesture of our gratitude for everyone’s time and commitment. It is in no way a living wage, but it is something. We need your help to extend this token of appreciation to our talented team of artists.

Four of the actors are recent MFA Acting graduates. This project allows them to continue their work and training as they transition into the business. It’s an exciting and daunting time to launch into the real world as an actor, after three years of intensive training, where the focus is solely on the art. We believe this opportunity assuages some of the difficulties of this launch period for our young artists, by providing a family of mature theater artists to grow with and extend into.


The Impact of Your Gift: A Voice From Beyond the Veil

We believe our work represents a distinct cultural enhancement to the arts in New York City, and to the world at large, because in all the ways we’ve mentioned, we feel we have a voice unlike any other on the contemporary scene.

We bring a level of craft and precision, imagination and rigor, all of which for us ultimately points not to itself, but perhaps to a taste of things that cannot be defined, explained, or perceived in the terms common to our everyday lives. Far from simply esoteric, we embody the words of one of the “grandfathers” of our lineage: “That which is imperceptible demands precision.” We are hard at work, building a rich world that both entertains, and deeply nourishes.

Believe us, you’ll get your money’s worth – perhaps with low production overhead, but with artistic nourishment beyond measure. This is what we strive to share with the world.


Other Ways You Can Help: Mercury’s Minions

We understand if you simply can’t contribute money at this time. You can still help!

Please spread the word about our campaign! Are there 5 people you know who might be interested in the project? Can you forward our campaign link to them?

Talk to us! Are there ways you can volunteer your talents or potential production supplies? Write to shyons@gmail.com. We'd love to hear from you!
