For example, we are trained by maestro Niky Wolcz, who was in turn trained by his mentors; traditions have been passed down to us from all over Europe, Russia, India, and Asia. From these deep wells of human story and theatrical experience, we unfold a theater at once timeless, and ceaselessly new.
So, in our process we ask: “As bodies in space that are vibrant with this living knowledge, how much can we conjure into the theater – and therefore into the imagination which we will ultimately share with our audience”? (That is, with you!)  And, trusting in the depth of such imaginative resources, we ask, “How much can we create – from how little?”
Cloud of Fools Theater Company is Jon Froehlich, Susan Hyon, Laura Butler Rivera, and Casey Robinson


Stepping into the Fray: About The Whistling Mortician 
“When the powers of death crop up at every turn, what else can one do...but whistle?”  Like the holy fools before him and the characters of Chaplin and Keaton a couple generations later, The Whistling Mortician postulates the life of a puckish Prussian laborer living in the hotbed of 1870’s Alsace-Lorraine. One fateful day following the Franco-Prussian war, he whistles the wrong national anthem up and down the streets of town – and directly into trouble. Fleeing to far-off countries and meeting colorful characters all the way, he finds himself drawn towards the work that will define his life.”
Using some sticks, a bit of foam board, and our selves, the world of The Whistling Mortician will traverse whole continents and oceans as it unfurls the whimsical journey of our hero. Music, death, war, and waltzing: we’re curious to see just how significantly a simple tune can change a life.
We are thrilled to be featured at the PAM 2012 Festival presented by IATI Theater http://www.teatroiati.org
Location: Baruch Performing Arts Center
Purchase tickets: click on your desired show date below.
            Saturday, July 28, 2012 at 10:00pm
            Sunday, August 5, 2012 at 3:00pm
            Thursday, August 9, 2012 at 7:00pm
The Whistling Mortician cast: Amanda Boekelheide, Michael Buffer, Jon Froehlich, Natalia Miranda Guzmán, Eddie Jackson, Daniel Levitt, Casey Robinson, Jenny Tibbels-Jordan

Many Sources, A Mighty River: What We Need
Our expenses total $6,900. This includes costs for marketing, production material, the production staff, and the creative team. 
Our fundraising goal is $4,000. This amount will enable us to pay the ensemble (8 performers) a stipend of $500 for their work and commitment, which began on April 29 and extends through August 9. The pay is a gesture of our gratitude for everyone’s time and commitment. It is in no way a living wage, but it is something. We need your help to extend this token of appreciation to our talented team of artists.
Four of the actors are recent MFA Acting graduates. This project allows them to continue their work and training as they transition into the business. It’s an exciting and daunting time to launch into the real world as an actor, after three years of intensive training, where the focus is solely on the art. We believe this opportunity assuages some of the difficulties of this launch period for our young artists, by providing a family of mature theater artists to grow with and extend into.

The Impact of Your Gift: A Voice From Beyond the Veil
We believe our work represents a distinct cultural enhancement to the arts in New York City, and to the world at large, because in all the ways we’ve mentioned, we feel we have a voice unlike any other on the contemporary scene.
We bring a level of craft and precision, imagination and rigor, all of which for us ultimately points not to itself, but perhaps to a taste of things that cannot be defined, explained, or perceived in the terms common to our everyday lives. Far from simply esoteric, we embody the words of one of the “grandfathers” of our lineage: “That which is imperceptible demands precision.” We are hard at work, building a rich world that both entertains, and deeply nourishes.
Believe us, you’ll get your money’s worth – perhaps with low production overhead, but with artistic nourishment beyond measure. This is what we strive to share with the world.

Other Ways You Can Help: Mercury’s Minions
We understand if you simply can’t contribute money at this time. You can still help!
Please spread the word about our campaign! Are there 5 people you know who might be interested in the project? Can you forward our campaign link to them?
Talk to us! Are there ways you can volunteer your talents or potential production supplies? Write to shyons@gmail.com. We'd love to hear from you!

story:
The Decay of Cities is an experiment by the members of Enthuse Theater into the how, where & why of theater-making.  

We begin with a company of performers, designers, dramaturgs, theater-artists.

We pose an interrogation: What is it to exist in decay?

We are in the midst of building a triptych: creating three devised, site-specific, interactive theatrical events while occupying three different American locations.

The first, An Orchard of Cherries, was created by 10 members of the company occupying an abandoned family farm in Maine for 10 days.  The second, Orchard-Less, will be created this November in an abandoned sheet metal shop in New Orleans, Louisianna.  The third will be created in an as-yet-determined site in Detroit.

We are documenting the creation of these pieces, evolving the method we use to make them and accumulating the material we build them on.  

They all are grounded in the bodies of the creators and the locations of their creation.  An Orchard of Cherries used, as source-material, Anton Chekhov's The Cherry Orchard.  The piece spoke directly to our generation of Americans, the first who will not "do better" than the ones before them.

Orchard-Less will incorporate the late writings of Tennesse Williams and examine the American archetypes who silently rage within societies' structures.  We will also be looking to work with local actors, musicians, dancers and artists, adding them to our companies' ranks while there.

Once these three pieces have been created, the data and material collected, we will develop the final piece of theater: The Decay of Cities.  We will bring this completely original performance back home to New York.

Right now we are in desperate need of funding to get us to New Orleans to develop the second part of this work.  Venue security and other logisitcal issues have been slow to solidify, hence the late call for donations.  But we now have a confirmed venue and confirmed performance dates and times.  We even have housing sorted.  We just need to get there.  

We also are taking this opportunity to begin building a community of folk interested in the project as it develops.  Know that while you're donating to us so we can put on a show in New Orleans, it's all working towards bringing a show to you some time next year.  With a donation you will become a part of the community with insite into how the piece is developed, where it goes from here and when it will be coming to a theater near you.

Over the years Enthuse Theater has continued to create enthusiastically create performances of scale and magnitude that diligently sound for evasive truths, starkly illuminate contradictions, loosen the fetters on the imagination and push the boundaries of the where, why, how and what of theater.  This is, by far, our most ambitious project yet.  And the most necessary one.  Those who were audience members at the farm in Maine can attest to the incredible uniqueness of the experience.  The further development of this piece and of the way we are making work together is crucial now more than at any other point in our company's history.  We're working on bringing you an experience unlike any you've had before.   

As usual, we're doing it on a shoestring budget, each of the company members working as many jobs as possible in order to make this happen.  Please help us if you can.  You'll be helping to create something you will be proud of.

story:
The Company

Established in 2009, Theatre Re is an international company creating physical and emotional work on the edge of mime and theatre. 

The Show

In an old circus tent, two brothers fight to the death. As their absurd rivalry builds towards destruction, their entire existence unfolds before them. Primal emotions take hold, furious ambition drives them into an unknown world and an impossible dream looms ever closer.

Inspired by the ancient tale of Cain and Abel, “The Little Soldiers” by acclaimed company Theatre Re combines spellbinding physical theatre and a sonic landscape created by live musical narrative to portray a timeless rivalry.

We are extremely grateful to Arts Council England, The French Institute in London, Haringey Council and The Cockpit Theatre for their trust and support in this audacious new adventure.

The Impact

“Destiny has two ways of crushing us, by refusing our wishes and by fulfilling them” Henri Frederic Amiel

“Until you make the unconscious conscious, it will direct your life and you will call it fate” Carl Jung

Our project addresses the difficulty of achieving one’s dreams. In the mysteriously ambiguous world of the circus on the borderline of reality and illusion, we want to explore the moment when folly takes over men’s mind and when ambition goes beyond moral constraints in a stream of uncontrolled violence. The conflict between our two brothers will be a metaphor addressing the struggle of living together as neighbours, people and nations.

Part of our development process involves opening a meaningful dialogue, through feedback sessions after regular showings, with members of the community and non-regular theatregoers in Haringey (North London).

Our plan of action

Following an initial five weeks rehearsal period in October/November 2012, The Little Soldiers will be developed at The French Institute in March/April 2013 and at St. Ann’s Library April/May 2013 before opening at The Cockpit in Westminster (London, UK) from May 15th to June 2nd 2013.

We will also be organizing free work in progress showings throughout April and May 2013 (see our website for more information).

We have established links with supporters of the project, have developed time lines, appointed a strong team, and are now seeking a little help from you to complete our budget.

What We Need & What You Get

Donations will contribute mainly towards production costs (transportation, costumes, props), marketing costs (flyers, posters and publicity) and administrative costs (postage, insurance).

For $15, you will get a signed flyer of the show and regular updates on our progress.

For $25, you will get to meet the cast after the show, a signed flyer of the show, and regular updates on our progress.

For $50, you will get your name on the program in the special thanks, to meet the cast after the show, a signed flyer, and regular updates on our progress.

For $100, you will get your name on Theatre Re’s website as an associate producer for The Little Soldiers, a signed poster of the show, your name on the program in the special thanks, to meet the cast after the show, and regular updates on our progress.

Other Ways You Can Help

The most helpful thing you can do for us is to come and see our work!

Beyond that, if you are able and willing please help us to promote The Little Soldiers through word of mouth, Facebook, Twitter and any other way you can possibly think of!

The Team

Guillaume Pigé | Director & Performer | France

Guillaume is an actor, director and mime. He trained at the Conservatory of Villeurbanne (France) and graduated from the International School of Corporeal Mime in London. Guillaume also holds an MA in Text and Performance Studies from King’s College and RADA.

Guillaume formed Theatre Re in 2009. He co-devised and performed Comme Un Gant, which toured in France (Avignon OFF, Lyon, Paris) and in the UK (Edinburgh Forest Fringe). Guillaume conceived, directed and performed Your Letter, At Last!, the company’s second piece, which was supported by Arts Council Ireland and toured in Ireland, France and the UK 2009-2011. Guillaume conceived, directed and performed The Gambler, which opened at The Space in 2011 and then toured in London at The Cockpit, Gieldgud Theatre RADA, The Bull Theatre, Jackson’s Lane and The Roundhouse Studio, before transferring to The Pleasance, Edinburgh Fringe Festival 2012. The R&D and subsequent tour of The Gambler received the support of Arts Council England. His new show in development in 2013 is The Little Soldiers.

His experience includes working with Andrew Visnevski, Sue Dunderdale and Bill Gaskill as assistant and movement director; running workshops in corporeal mime for various youth theatre groups and the graduates and actors of Theatre de Iris in Lyon; and he is a visiting Physical Performance tutor at RADA. Guillaume is also a professional magician regularly performing close-up and stage magic. www.retheatre.com

 

Alex Judd | Composer & Musician | United-Kingdom

Alex studied violin, piano and composition at the Guildhall School of Music and Drama in London before going on to read music at Goldsmiths College, University of London and specialising in composition.

Alex composes extensively for dance and drama projects, most recently having composed for the Theatre Re production of The Gambler performed at Jackson’s Lane, RADA, The Roundhouse and the Edinburgh Fringe Festival 2012. Other recent composition credits include Othello at Lauderdale House (Aug 2010) and music for pieces performed at the European Cultural Congress (Sept 2011) and Resolution! Festival at The Place (Jan 2011).

Alex is an experienced session musician having performed in many orchestras as a violinist, and worked with several bands in the recording studio and live onstage as a session pianist and guitarist. Most recently Alex worked with the ‘Noisettes’, and is a permanent session musician for ‘Bright Light Bright Light’ and ‘Glass Pear’. www.soundcloud.com/alexjudd

 

Selma Roth | Performer | Switzerland

Selma Roth studied mime at the Mimenschule Ilg in Zürich. Thereafter she lived four years in Berlin and graduated from the mime-department of Die Etage, e.V. She worked with Anemone Poland (Theaterforum Kreuzberg), Emilie Bajard (Spheric E-motion) as well as freelance. In Switzerland Selma worked with Louis Naef, Heinz Stalder, Mariana Coviello and Hans Hassler.

In 2010, she came to London to deepen her knowledge in Corporeal Mime. She graduated from the International School of Corporeal Mime and worked with Corinne Soum and Steven Wasson (Théâtre de l’Ange fou, London). Since 2005 Selma worked regularly with Pavel Stourač (Divadlo Continuo, Czech Republic). In 2008 Selma founded the physical theatre company supplement subtile within whichshe produced, directed and performed Solos and in collaboration with other Artists: sara par hasard (2oo8), Theatraler Nachschlag (2o1o), Gute Mime zum bösen Spiel (2o11) and Konzert für Aug und Ohr (2o11). She also received the Student Award for physical theatre by Migros cultural foundation 2007.

 

Malik Ibheis | Performer | Germany

Malik is a trained Mime and Physical Performer. He has studied at Die Etage, Berlin and graduated from the International School of Corporeal Mime in London.

He is also training in contortion and advanced flexibility with Iona Luvsandorj, a skill he likes to combine with his main discipline.

Malik brings acts and characters into being using props, costumes and makeup he designs and creates himself, combining a variety of objects and fabrics through self-taught techniques. What fascinates him the most is to fuse old with new, especially if the new lights up.

He has been performing unusual acts for a variety of festivals and cabarets in the UK and Germany (among others Wilderness in Oxfordshire and Rumpus in London) with expressionist silent movies as well as the Steampunk genre being his main inspiration.

Malik can also be seen in several episodes of the TV Show “FIT” created for the CBBC, where he was miming about. www.ungewinster.de

 

Katherine Graham | Lighting designer & Technical manager | Ireland

Katherine is a freelance lighting and stage designer. She has previously worked with Theatre Re as lighting designer for The Gambler.

Other recent credits include lighting design for Sleeping Beauty - The Castle, (Wellingborough); BYPASS – Painted Filly Theatre (Block T, Dublin); Sense – Made by Brick (Hen and Chickens); The Bright Side of the Moon – Beyond The Bark (Brighton Fringe Festival); Chicken – Made by Brick(Southwark Playhouse); You Can’t Just Leave – There’s Always Something (Site Specific); Soh (Smock Alley)and Andy Warhol’s Nothing Special (Belltable) all with Spilt Gin. Also stage and lighting design for Romeo and Juliet (Gaiety Theatre, Dublin and Tour of Ireland and UK) and Cinderella (National Concert Hall and Tour of Ireland and UK) both with Ballet Ireland; stage lighting and costume design for 100 Minutes (Samuel Beckett Theatre)and The Common Will (Bewleys Café Theatre) both with Painted Filly Theatre. Solo and installation work includes City Walk, Hiding/Seeking and Re-membering.

Katherine trained at Wimbledon College of Art  (MA – Visual Language of Performance) and Trinity College, Dublin (BA Hons. – Drama Studies). www.katherine-graham.com

 

Dr Bernie C. Byrnes | Dramaturge | United-Kingdom

Bernie is a multi-award winning writer and director who has recently returned from directing actors at Prithvi Theatre, Mumbai and I Theatre, Singapore. Previous directing commissions include Another Midas, OffCuts, AC Random Productions, Ugly Sister, South Hill Park, Ivy Paige, Stone Crabs, Arena North, Stage Focus, Network Theatre, the Ashby Youth Group and the Royal Shakespeare Company.

Bernie is an established theatrical practitioner, a Fellow of the Royal Society of Arts and a member of the Guild of Directors. She has lectured in numerous universities, dramaturged on numerous New Writing projects, as well as setting up her own Touring Theatre Company, Kipper Tie Theatre.

Bernie has worked alongside Stephen Pimlott, Ed Hall, Michael Attenborough, Gareth Armstrong and Wayne Sleep. She has been a successful writer, director and producer at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival and has attracted 4 and 5 stars for her shows over the past 10 years. 

 

Patrick Collier | Producer | Ireland

Patrick is a London-based freelance producer, and will take charge of ensuring the smooth running of the production and of meeting targets and deadlines. Recently Patrick has worked as a producer, general manager and tour booker with companies in London and Ireland, including Metta Theatre, Theatre Témoin, and Iris Theatre.

story:
PERFECT CURIOSITY

A THEATRICAL FABLE

A WORKSHOP

 

THE STORY

    Once upon a time there was a flawless family:  a Mother, a Father and a little girl named Perfect.  But one dark night a screaming, bawling monster rips her way out of the Mother’s womb:  a baby called Curiosity.  Suddenly nothing is quite right in this world or the next…  

     The story of these two sisters’ navigation of the slippery terrain of a cold yet incestuous household is told by an ensemble of eight migrating souls, each with its own distinct persona:

  The Father cross-dresses. The Sexpot can’t keep her skirt down. The Mother becomes a three-headed witch. The Badboy can be a bitch. The Puppet strings others up. Perfect is in knots. The Romantic is a sap. Curiosity is a brat.

  They all feed and fight their intertwining fates, insinuating themselves into each others lives - sometimes underlining each others’ struggles with sympathetic cries and sighs, but just as often undermining them with ugly laughter and lies.

 

THE ENSEMBLE

 

Writer / Director:   Elizabeth Hess

Composer:   Lucas Syed

Choreographer:   Katie Palmer

Ensemble:

Cherrye Davis, Luke Eisemann, Vanessa Koppel, Javi Perez, Katie Polin, Danielle Sachs, Lucas Syed, Lauren Ullrich

Production:     

Barbara Begley (Designer), Nate Koch (Production Consultant), Brad Raimondo (Assistant Director/ Production (Consultant), Colleen Toole (Stage Manager)

 

THE WORKSHOP

  The ensemble and creative team will rehearse during the month of January, finding ways to investigate the inner landscape of their characters and explode them open through text, movement and sound.  Because of the devised nature of the project, it is vital that all the various storytelling languages have the freedom to be created and rehearsed along side each other.  Every discovery about one aspect of the production will illuminate and re-shape every other aspect.

 

WORKSHOP PRESENTATIONS

  The ensemble will present its findings in two presentations at The Moss Theater on January 26 & 27 @ 7pm.

  Your presence is a huge part of our process. Your response will inform us as to where we are, and where we want to go with the piece.

 

 

PROJECT HISTORY

PERFECT CURIOSITY was initially developed during a residency at The O’Neill Center.  A sampling of the work was subsequently presented for the National Theater Institute (NTI).

This January we will continue the process toward a full production with a month of workshop rehearsals that will culminate in two work-in-progress presentations at the Robert Moss Theater (440 Lafayette) on January 26th and 27th, 2013.
story_txt:
PERFECT CURIOSITY
A THEATRICAL FABLE
A WORKSHOP
 
THE STORY
    Once upon a time there was a flawless family:  a Mother, a Father and a little girl named Perfect.  But one dark night a screaming, bawling monster rips her way out of the Mother’s womb:  a baby called Curiosity.  Suddenly nothing is quite right in this world or the next…  
     The story of these two sisters’ navigation of the slippery terrain of a cold yet incestuous household is told by an ensemble of eight migrating souls, each with its own distinct persona:
   The Father cross-dresses. The Sexpot can’t keep her skirt down. The Mother becomes a three-headed witch. The Badboy can be a bitch. The Puppet strings others up. Perfect is in knots. The Romantic is a sap. Curiosity is a brat.
   They all feed and fight their intertwining fates, insinuating themselves into each others lives - sometimes underlining each others’ struggles with sympathetic cries and sighs, but just as often undermining them with ugly laughter and lies.
 
THE ENSEMBLE
 
Writer / Director:   Elizabeth Hess
Composer:   Lucas Syed
Choreographer:   Katie Palmer
Ensemble:
Cherrye Davis, Luke Eisemann, Vanessa Koppel, Javi Perez, Katie Polin, Danielle Sachs, Lucas Syed, Lauren Ullrich
Production:     
Barbara Begley (Designer), Nate Koch (Production Consultant), Brad Raimondo (Assistant Director/ Production (Consultant), Colleen Toole (Stage Manager)
 
THE WORKSHOP
   The ensemble and creative team will rehearse during the month of January, finding ways to investigate the inner landscape of their characters and explode them open through text, movement and sound.  Because of the devised nature of the project, it is vital that all the various storytelling languages have the freedom to be created and rehearsed along side each other.  Every discovery about one aspect of the production will illuminate and re-shape every other aspect. 
 
WORKSHOP PRESENTATIONS
   The ensemble will present its findings in two presentations at The Moss Theater on January 26 & 27 @ 7pm.
   Your presence is a huge part of our process. Your response will inform us as to where we are, and where we want to go with the piece.
 
 
PROJECT HISTORY
PERFECT CURIOSITY was initially developed during a residency at The O’Neill Center.  A sampling of the work was subsequently presented for the National Theater Institute (NTI).
This January we will continue the process toward a full production with a month of workshop rehearsals that will culminate in two work-in-progress presentations at the Robert Moss Theater (440 Lafayette) on January 26th and 27th, 2013.

story:
“To dance is to be yourself”

About Me

Hello, my name is Marina Mendez.  I am a senior in high school.  I am a member of the National Honors Society at my school and I’m also currently taking college classes in order to graduate with my AA degree.  When I’m not in school, I’m dancing.  I’ve been dedicated to dance since I was three years old. 

What I'm Fundraising For

Since I'll be graduating this year, it is also my most important year of dance and possibly my last time competing.  This year I will be attending nine competitions, some being out of state.  With the cost of tuition, costumes, various competition fees, and travel expenses I need the help of donations in order to pay for my senior year of dance.

Even if I do not reach my goal amount, the funds that I make will still go toward dance.

Thank you in advance for any donations you are able to make and for taking the time to read this.

Sincerely,
Marina Mendez

 

“To watch us dance is to hear our hearts speak”

story:
ABOUT US

 

Small… but mighty.

Half-Pint Theatre was founded in the summer of 2011 by four so-called ”half-pints” with big dreams, and an even bigger desire to be a part of Toronto’s theatrical scene.

 

Half-Pint was created with the intention to produce those shows that one dreams of working on but are rarely given the chance. Our vision is to collaborate and explore these works with other artists who share this passion and enthusiasm, so that audiences are given a show that has been cared for, nurtured, and brought to life with the vibrant energy of those who are compelled and inspired to tell the story.

In addition to our productions, we hope to set the groundwork for a supportive artistic community. Through play-readings, events and workshops we aim to provide artists with the opportunity to ask questions, get advice, connect, and most importantly play.

Half-Pint’s inaugural production of “tick, tick…BOOM!” was a limited run presented at Buddies In Bad Times Theatre in February 2012 to wonderful audience response and acclaim.

This just in!

"tick, tick...BOOM!" has been nominated for 9 BROADWAY WORLD TORONTO AWARDS including: Best Production of a Musical, Best Direction of a Musical: Alanna Stone, Best Actor in a Lead Role: Jeremy LaPalme, Best Actress in a Lead Role: Esther Vallins, Best Actor in a Featured role: Jon Chou, and Best Independent Theatre Production!

 

 

“A NIGHT OF SHANLEY”

Our sophomore show “A Night of Shanley” is a double bill featuring John Patrick Shanley’s classic one-act plays “Welcome to the Moon” and “Women of Manhattan”. Joined by some of our favourite Shanley monologues, this evening is a tribute to the works of one of the most celebrated playwrights of the last 50 years.

 

“What I admire most are that his plays are beautifully well made, economical, sharp and coherent. I like the toughness of his writing a lot. He's not a misanthrope, but he's in pursuit of why people behave as badly as they do along with having a great compassion for them. That's an unusual and interesting combination.''

~ Tony Kushner, Playwright (Angels in America)

 

 

What we need and What you get

Between royalty rights, the rent for our venue, production costs, advertising, and payment for our cast and crew our budget for this show is $6,500. Our goal is to raise $5000. You may ask why our goal is so high?

The artistic team of Half-Pint is already planning our third show (most likely going up this summer). Our hope is to make enough money from this campaign to cover the majority of our current expenses, that way we can use the money from our ticket sales towards our next show. We want to create an established company and eventually have full seasons. Your contribution will not only help “A Night of Shanley” but will also help our future productions to come.

 

To reward your generosity in supporting this project we’ve thought long and hard about some amazing perks. You will of course get a very enthusiastic thank you on all of our social media, and depending on your contribution can get VIP tickets to the show, a personalized singing telegram (done live if you live in the GTA, and by video if you do not – good for playing jokes, happy birthdays, and seasons’ greetings), a care package from the “Women of Manhattan”, a date with the cast, and even your own private concert featuring the ladies of Half-Pint and our talented friends.

 

This is a “flexible” campaign meaning that if we do not reach our goal we will still receive the money you have donated and that it will go towards this production. We might just have to sell our organs to pay for the rest – don’t worry, nothing vital…hopefully.

 

THE IMPACT

Theatre in Toronto is changing. If a theatre like the Princess of Wales can get torn down for condos, how are we supposed to continue to be one of the top theatrical cities in the world? It will come down to the next generation of artistic entrepreneurs to keep this city at the top of its game. Companies like Half-Pint need your donations in these first few years so that we can grow to become the next Factory Theatre or Acting Up Stage. By supporting us you are supporting a team that cares for the future of our theatres and wants to propel Toronto into the next stage of this theatrical evolution.

We are setting the groundwork so that Half-Pint Theatre can be around for a long time. Your generous donations will go one or more of these very important places:

1) Production costs

2) The licensing rights for the plays and our venue.

 A two-week run is obviously more expensive then a one-week run, but what we learned from our last production (which had 4 performances) was that it didn’t allow the public many chances to come out and see what we had been working on for months. If they weren’t free that weekend, then they weren’t able to see it. This longer run grants our audience flexibility and gives them more opportunities to come out and see the show. 

3) Payment for the cast and artistic team.

We may only be in our second year of operation but it has been a priority from day one for us to pay the people who work diligently to make this show great.

 

If I CAN’T DONATE CAN I STILL HELP?

Absolutely!! If you are financially troubled and are unable to donate your money here are some other ways you can still help:

  • You can donate costumes, props or sets
  • Volunteer your time
  • SPREAD THE WORD

You can still help us reach our goal without having to spend a penny. Tell your friends and family, email your peeps, like our facebook page, and please share this campaign through your social media (facebook, twitter, etc.)

 

Thank you so much for your support!  Please check out our campaign video. If you would like more information about our company please visit us on Facebook, twitter or our website.

Thank you!

story:
Potentially Sketchy 

Potentially Sketchy is a diverse group of theatre-trained actors and comedians who want to showcase the value of prioritizing a variety of voices when producing comedy; when everyone is heard, no topic is left unassailed, and the results are devastatingly funny.

We are currently working furiously to prepare for our first show in October of 2018, and we are asking for your help to give us the extra push we need to get this project to its final stages.

 

What we need & what you get

We are currently raising $1000. These funds are for:

  • Renting theatre spaces
  • Building props
  • Making costumes
  • Covering some small marketing costs

 

In return for supporting us, you get:

  • $5 donation -  1 shoutout on social media

  • $10 donation - 1 ticket + shoutout

  • $15 donation -  2 tickets + shoutout

  • $50 donation  - 1 season pass + shoutout

  • $150 donation - Producer credit For Season 1 + season pass + shoutout

  • $300 donation - Have a line in a sketch + producer credit + season pass + shoutout

  • $500 donation - Lifetime Producer + 2x tickets to everything we produce + shoutout

 

What your donation means

Your donation means more people get to see diversity on a comedic stage - they get to see themselves represented, and that's important. In turn, as we grow, more spaces and opportunities will be created for comedians who are people of colour, women, and/or queer. We don’t pay lip-service to diversity, we actively cultivate it.

 

Please share!

If you can't contribute at this time, no problem! Please share our campaign on social media. We look forward to seeing you at our first show!

story:
Who We Are:

Eastern Bridge Theater Troupe is thrilled to announce the First Three Editions of "Foreign Voices Are Us", a series of monthly events in different formats.

The 1st April Edition entitled 'Let's Build The Bridge -  Not A Wall. Adaptation of Charles Mee's works'. - SUCCESSFULLY PREMIERED! ( See Pictures in Updates) 
The 2nd May Edition: Unheard Female Voices: Poetry Event. 
The 3rd June Edition: Let's Be Celebrated, Not Tolerated: A Cabaret. 

Our Mission:

Eastern Bridge Theatre Troupe seeks to give opportunity to foreign voices in New York City and operates on the idea that there are many unheard stories to be told that miss their chance to take flight. By creating the bridge for foreign artists within and outside the United States, our collective experiences motivate work that is revealing, significant and provocative. 

Support Our New Board- OUR NEW BEGINNING! 

Anna Rak (Artistic Director) ;  Irina Bravo (Director of Design and Marketing); Cristina Sebastian and Yuching Tsai (Team of Producers)

We are all unique in our own way - we have big personalities, very different backgrounds and life experiences. However there is something we all have in common - it’s drive and passion to theatre and storytelling. Anna immigrated from Poland, Irina is Catalan-Chilean, Cristina is Philipino and Yuching comes from Taiwan.  We all have something special to contribute to the Eastern Bridge and it’s our different point of view, usually connected with our culture, upbringing and training. 

Some of us met at Stella Adler Studio, some working in independent projects but all based in New York City. There is something about the energy people give away, and we definitely felt like ours is similar. After graduation from our trainings, we all felt like there’s something missing in the projects we are being asked to take part in , or the shows we are cast in… We wanted to tell stories that we cared for. Social media definitely makes it easier to communicate and brainstorm together even if you’re totally absorbed by the crazy NYC lifestyle. We would meet accidently on some events and there would always be a conversation that would end with a statement : ‘We have to do something together’ and that was it! We're FINALLY DOING IT! 

What We Need 

Goal:

$2000 - What we need to cover the cost of our first 3 venues!

$1000 - Production cost (props, insurance etc)  

 & What You Get

Each donor will get a personal mention in our program

$10 gets you an e-postcard with the picture of our upcoming photoshoot entitled 'Starving For Art' 

$25 gets you a signed picture of the cast 

$30 gets you one complimentary ticket for one of our events

$50 gets you 2 complimentary tickets

$100 gets you 2 tix + a signed picture

$200 gets you 2 tix + a signed pic + a Thank You video from the our team

$500 gets you 4 tix + a signed pic + a Thank You video from our team 

$1000 gets you 4 tix + 4 signed pics + a Thank You video from our team + PRODUCER CREDIT

No Need To Claim Your Perk - We Will Send You Your Gift Once You Donate :-) 

Other Ways You Can Help

Don't worry we get it. This is New York and we all struggle to make our ends meet. If you can't donate - Please help us to spread the word! Make some noise! 

Share, like, follow, tweet! TALK ABOUT US! We'd LOVE THAT TOO! 

If your'e interested in helping out with our events, feel free to reach out too. 

Check us out :

Website: www.easternbridgetheatre.com

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/EasternBridgeTheatre/

Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/easternbridgetheatre/

Twitter: https://twitter.com/E_B_T_T

story:
What we are doing and why. 

xoxo moongirl is about growing up with domestic violence and abuse. The story is about the home life of Almanac Artist, Nicole Burgio, but moves past the singular experience and aims to  reveal the effects of abuse on mothers, daughters, sisters, friends, and anyone who has been afflicted by any sort of abuse or mistreatment.  It is Almanac’s hope to amplify this voice and shed light on domestic violence, abuse, and above all inner strength.

This show is important because it tells the story of domestic abuse without being dismal. It is funny, uplifting, and hopeful.

Your donations will go a long way towards making this rigorous rehearsal and creation process sustainable for the members, ensuring that the performances of Almanac’s artists/musicians/designers are compensated as well as possible. Without support for women creating and performing this type of art, we will continue to see male dominated roles and a loud male voice in theater. It is our expectation to share the story, xoxo moongirl. To watch Nicole defeat a violent dad and fly her family to the moon. To watch her swing on a trapeze, climb a fabric, and dance on a kitchen table to tell her story. It is our expectation to support one of our artist in her struggle with domestic violence. And it is our hope that we can reach out and support many more.

Who we are. 

Almanac Dance Circus Theater is an internationally touring ensemble that combines physical theater, dance, and circus to create a unique storytelling experience. Much of what Almanac creates is in direct response to social imbalance; amplifying voices that otherwise may not be heard. 

xoxo moongirl is a new full-length production featuring Almanac's Nicole Burgio as the solo performer. Nicole is an international touring circus artist. She began training in gymnastics at age 5, and pursued the sport competitively through her matriculation at Temple University. Circus quickly became her new passion, and she studied aerial arts at Philadelphia School of Circus Arts while simultaneously attaining a masters degree in Clinical and Counseling Health Psychology. After graduation, she was accepted into the New England School of Circus Arts. Later, she pursued an extended residency in Montreal where she was mentored by top-level Ecole Nationale de Cirque coaches.

Other collaborators in xoxo moongirl include: 

Ben Grinberg - Director

Melanie Hsu - Musician & Composer 

Evelyn Langley - Costume Design 

Lauren Johns - Choreographic Outside Eye

Joseph Ahmed, Robin Stamey, Jess Adams, Desiree Hall, Nick Gillette -- ensemble devisors

After graduation, she was accepted into the New England School of Circus Arts. Later, she pursued an extended residency in Montreal where she was mentored by top-level Ecole Nationale de Cirque coaches.Other collaborators in xoxo moongirl include: Ben Grinberg - DirectorMelanie Hsu - Musician & Composer Evelyn Langley - Costume Design Lauren Johns - Choreographic Outside EyeJoseph Ahmed, Robin Stamey, Jess Adams, Desiree Hall, Nick Gillette -- ensemble devisors

story:
I am an emerging Canadian choreographer currently based in Boston, MA. I started creating contemporary dance work while living in Montreal, QC and moved to Boston in 2014. Next January I will present two new pieces that I have been creating with artists from Boston and Montreal at the Cambridge Multicultural Center. These performances will take place on January 19th & 20th and will feature the Boston premiere of both pieces. This performance experience is a full-length evening of my choreography and is representative of the work I have been creating in Boston and Montreal over the past two years. This is a significant moment in my career as a choreographer in Boston because it is the first time I will present a full-length evening of my work to Boston audiences. I have been working toward the premiere of both these pieces for the last two years and it is the first large scale project that I have taken on as a choreographer. 

pull | tirer & they have taken nothing

 “pull | tirer” is a contemporary dance duet that features myself and  Montreal based dancer Louis-Elyan Martin.  Emily Gualtieri, co-artistic director of Montreal dance company Parts+Labour_Danse, has been the rehearsal director for this project. “they have taken nothing” is a piece that is being created on three professional Boston dancers, Cacia LaCount, Emily Jerant-Hendrickson,  and Jessica Smith. Both pieces are part of a collaboration between myself and Montreal-based composer Marc Bartissol. He has been creating original sound for both pieces and will travel to Boston in January to perform live. We have been working together on "pull | tirer" and "they have taken nothing", researching how his sound and my choreography can inform, support, and challenge the other. My goal as a choreographer is to offer contemporary dance that integrates articulate and technical dancing while engaging audiences with fragments of humanity and narrative. The intent of these performances is to create a bridge between artists in Montreal and Boston and hopefully lay the groundwork for future projects to take place between artists from both cities!

Why We Need Your Support

There are many moving parts that contribute to making this production a success. This production would not be possible without the talent of the artists who have all dedicated their time  and energy toward the production at the Cambridge Multicultural Center next January. Your support will go directly toward supporting the production team who is working hard to bring together an immersive performance experience!

Your Contributions Will Go Toward

  • Paying the artists for their time in rehearsals 
  • Paying for rehearsal space this fall and next January
  • Performance fees for the artists
  • Lighting and production design costs

Spread the word!

I understand that it is not always possible to provide a donation but you can still help support us by spreading the word about the campaign and upcoming performances to friends and family! 

Campaign and Overview Photo by Nicole Tomaselli

Perks photos by David Wong, Marc Bartissol, and Nicole Tomaselli

story:
What is Vertigo?

Vertigo gives undergraduate playwrights the opportunity to have their original scripts realized into full-fledged productions. By producing student-written theatre, Vertigo hopes to be a creative and dynamic presence on campus, encouraging students to take artistic risk. Vertigo is the only student theatre organization on campus that produces entirely student-written work.

Tell me about This Is Not A True Story!

This Is Not a True Story takes the heroines from “Madame Butterfly”, “Miss Saigon”, and the Case of Takako Konishi out of their Orientalist, romanticized origins, and gives them their own lives and, for some, their own last names. We follow the lives of these three young Asian women as they contend with the white men so keen on wooing them: a geisha in late 1800s Japan, a bar girl in mid 1970s Vietnam, and a treasure hunter in 21st century Japan. As times collide, fates change and tragic fiction is re-written. For some, though, the hard facts of their realities remain.

Why should I support This Is Not A True Story?

This Is Not A True Story is about the myths and unvarnished realities in the lives of East Asian women. A cast entirely made up of Asian-American women pursues love, friendship, family, career goals and their own places in the world at a breakneck pace. Shows that talk so honestly about fetishization, anti-Asian racism, sexual assault, motherhood and agency are rare in the theatre world. Preston’s script dares to be honest and clear. We couldn’t be more excited to premier his newest play!

Where does the money go?

All donations go to major design elements that, put together, will bring the world of the show to life. Each piece of the puzzle is absolutely vital in making the show what it is.

Set and Space: We’re creating two worlds: the stereotypical “Orient” of shows like Madame Butterflyand Miss Saigon, and the unfamiliar, lonely United States. The space becomes a tea garden, a geisha’s home, a war-torn Vietnam, Fargo, ND, and the space for awkward, meaningful phone calls. We’ll be creating a space that invites the audience into these fictional and true worlds and makes them uncomfortable at the same time.

Lights: In each act, we’re using light to create mood – it’s just as responsible for bringing the space to life as the set. With a largely white-based set, lights will really set the tone.

Sound: With so many settings and so many in-person and face-to-face interactions, our sound team is critical, creating impactful, bold moments.

Props: We couldn’t show a character’s discovery of War and Peace, predicting new love on flower petals, or an apartment marked by depression without our amazing props team.

Costumes: In order to recreate styles from late 19th-century Japan, 1970s Vietnam and early 2000s Japan, our costume designer is buying, renting and creating pieces. Our actresses double roles, and realistic, detailed costumes help distinguish new worlds and eras from each other.

Hair and Makeup: From geishas and bar girls to office ladies and worried mothers, our hair and makeup team will help display and break down stereotypes of East Asian women.

The Cast

Mari Uchida – Takako Konishi (The Myth) and Takako Konishi (The Reality)

Sharon Wei – CioCio Tanaka and Others

Shea Lee  – Kim Nguyen and Others

Production and Team

Preston Choi – Playwright

Rachel Holtzman – Producer

Marley Smith – Space and Set Designer

Janet Lee – Lighting Designer

Camille Michelotti – Sound Designer

Hannah Rosenstein – Costume Designer

Katie Chang – Dramaturg

Jason Yuan - Graphic Designer

Emma Brick – Business Co-Director

Allyson Snyder – Business Co-Director

Rehearsal Team

Jess Levin – Director

Faye Oyang – Stage Manager

Showtimes:

Thursday, April 13th – 8 p.m.

Friday, April 14th – 7 p.m. | 10 p.m.

Saturday, April 15th – 2 p.m. | 8 p.m.

Location:

This Is Not A True Story will be performed in Shanley Pavilion located at 2031 Sheridan Road, Evanston, IL.

Tickets:

Tickets are available at the door: $5 for Northwestern Students and $10 for the General Public.

I want to support this, but I’m having trouble donating through Indiegogo?!

Send cash and checks made out to Northwestern University!

You can send checks to:

Rachel Holtzman

1870 Orrington Ave

Evanston, IL 60201

If you are unable to contribute monetarily, you can also help us out by sharing the link to this page! We appreciate your support!

story:
Dear all,

We are Sally and Tuva, the brains and bodies behind this project!

That Disgusting Thing Called Intimacy is an evening length multidisciplinary performance dealing with power-structures, desire and intimacy. 

That Disgusting Thing Called Intimacy is a choreography of desire and rejection, expectations and failures. An evening-length performance questioning the constitution of gender, power structures, sexuality and success embedded within popular culture, arts and politics. A space where you are allowed to see and be seen.

Through humor, provocation, improvisation, choreography and spoken word, our duet strives to break down expectations on gender and performance steered by neo-liberal capitalist structures. We put ourselves through task-based improvisation and choreography in extreme physical states, performing and decomposing the identity of a woman and femininity. By pushing boundaries and creating an anti-spectacle we allow what is underneath the performance to unfold itself and blur the line between fiction and reality. That Disgusting Thing Called Intimacy complicates and redefines the expectations on women as well as the performer and power-structures within the institutionalized space of the theater.

 

 “ … Their work uniquely addresses the complex issue of feminism and the role of women in contemporary society. Sally O'Neill and Tuva Hildebrand have developed an innovative exploration of co-existence within relationships, and how intimacy erases the identity one has constituted for oneself in order to earn an institutional validation.  [...] this duo breaks down our cultural expectations on gender. “ -Olga Levina (Artistic Director at Jersey City Theater Center) 

Your help could make this project reach a wider audience and diverse community!

On March 26th and April 2nd 2016 we performed at Jersey City Theater Center, during their Identity Series and Women's Issues month and it was an amazing opportunity to spread this thought-provoking piece of work to a local audience, a wider audience and contribute to social change. The theater invited us and provided us with production and space, but they did not cover travel costs, salary and other expenses to make the project possible.

As Sally O'Neill is currently based in Lund, Sweden, she had to travel all the way to US in order for this duo's collaboration to grow and this performance to happen. This involved costs for flight, accommodation, local travel and food. We also had to pay for documentation of the show in form of video and photography, so that we can continue with this work.

 

The future plans for this show is to reach out to smaller under exposed communities that often does not have the means to see performance or the opportunity to speak about gender, sexuality and women's issues, as well as larger art communities in US and Europe. Our wish is to develop a workshop that we offer in relation to the show, which focus on generating a conversation about power-structures, equality, intimacy and sexuality through exercises in movement and somatic improvisation. In order to do all of the above we need to make sure that the production is feasible and that we have the financial and practical ability to continue to work on this project.

“Loved your performance last night! I went with my friend Irene Siegel who has worked with physical theatre and movement based performance. We were talking for awhile afterwards about the brilliance of your show and our sincere wish that you can do it again. The delicate balance of innocence, exploitation, authenticity and gender constructs among SO many other thought provoking concepts you wrote into the story in such an accessible and often humorous way was so inspiring. Your work stimulated really fabulous conversations and I hope you can keep them going! Thank you for your insight, brains and talent! Brava!” – Mary Catherine Donnelly (Teaching artist, Organizer of New York Fringe Festival and Theater Director at United Solo Festival)

  

We are very passionate about this project because it is equally activism as performance. Our past shows has touched women, men and trans of different ages and background, and generated a conversation about their relationship to their body, inequality, sex and so much more. In a society which focus on result, we as a performance duo find it important to embrace, share and create process. We would like to develop work which redefines how we identify the world and makes us see the things we take for granted. We are interested in how to create work that is not just an outlet in order for people to happily return to their daily life, but to create a space that allows change to happen, that resonates and steers up action.

 

 

“Wow wow wow. That was.Bold. Brave. Authentic. Cohesive. Entertaining. Upsetting to some. Two people walked out of the theater. Beautiful. Successful. Watchable. Daring. Aggghhhh, Real. Connected. To the audience and the space.”– Tracy Einstein (Teaching artist, Actor, Director)

That Disgusting Thing Called Intimacy has been presented at Jersey City Theater Center, NJ (US), Theater aan de Rijn (Arnhem, NE), Center for Performance Research (Brooklyn, NY) and Dixon Place Theater (Manhattan, NY). It was developed with support by Generale Oost Production House (NE) and Jersey City Theater Center (NJ).

Information about the artists...

Sally and Tuva's collaboration started unknowingly on a commuting train in 2004,  as they both attended the Swedish Ballet School in Malmö, only to reconvene ten years later after numerous of skype conversations. Sally is based in Lund, Sweden and Tuva is based in New York and Sweden. Sitting on each side of the Atlantic ocean, this project commenced with a simple discussion about performance anxiety, which spiraled into topics such as capitalism, success, end-gaining, patriarchy, presence, authenticity, reality, intimacy, sex, violence and much more. In February 2015 they had their first full-time Artist-In-Residence for 5 weeks at Theater aan the Rijn, Generale Oost, in the Netherlands. There they made the first iteration of this piece, which premiered at Teater aan de Rijn, Arnhem (NE) and it is still emerging. Sally and Tuva's major questions today are: What is authenticity and is it possible not to perform in life, art and work? How can we use performance as activism? What is it to practice feminism and co-existence today in life, in collaborations and on stage?

Our individual bios can be found in our websites.

Further information about the artists involved in the project:

http://tuvahildebrand.com
http://milan-markovic.com/
http://sallymoneill.weebly.com
http://jespernielsen.weebly.com/

 

Transparency...

Minimal budget for the show at Jersey City Theater Center March 19-April 3

Sally's costs:
Travel - $950
Accommodation - $400
Food - $150
Local transport - $120 (Metro in NY + Path train card)

Tuva's costs:
- Path-train card - $60

Production costs:
Set design - $300
Videographer - $200
Photographer - $100
Transportation (gas) - $20

Additional unforeseen costs - $200

Total sum: $2500

 

Impact

The sexual abuse and intimate partner violence rate in US is incredibly high and in the rest of the world it is not better.  In Sweden girls are burnt out from high performance in school before they have even finished high school. People are taught today to value individual performance more than collective actions and community. It is a fact that advertising is successful because it feeds on giving women (and men) low-self esteem. The way women of all ethnicities are portrayed in advertising and music videos specifically affects women of all backgrounds; when the body is compared to an object everyday it leads to lack of empathy for the body and person and it contributes to violation of the body. We are fed from a young age with the information that a woman is lacking something (negative space) and that the man has something (positive space). When we did a survey with our friends as research, asking about their relationship to their vagina, four out of five women responded that they had experienced sexual abuse and therefore had a complex relationship with their pelvis and vagina. 

These are just a few of the facts that encourages us to do this project and that we want to change by spreading this show to a wider audience.


Risks & Challenges

We didn't have much time, but it was enough to pull this show together once again. Sally bought a flight ticket with money that she realistically didn't have, arrived to New York on March 19th, rehearsed the show and then had to go back to Sweden two weeks later to work. It is a wonderful, vulnerable, giving and playful experience to rehearse this show. Our major challenges are the practical aspects that a high budget theater usually can take care of, but that we also have to focus on at this stage of our career. A major obstacle is also the distance between us and that it is so expensive to travel between New York and Europe. The largest obstacle is the stress that can occur if we will anticipate to go minus and the consequences that will lead to. One consequence is that it could be very hard to continue with this project. A challenge is to get all the practical aspects, such as marketing, grants writing, videography, set design  together for each time we are invited to perform the piece. However, with your potential support, our hard work, tight schedule, will-power and enthusiasm, we will make it happen.

 

Thank you

 

March was Women's Issues month and April is Sexual Violence Awareness month - which of course every month should be! So please consider contributing to make this project possible. If you don't have the funds, please share with friends, activists and art lovers!

A challenge is to get all the practical aspects, such as marketing, grants writing, videography, set design  together for each time we are invited to perform the piece. However, with your potential support, our hard work, tight schedule, will-power and enthusiasm, we will make it happen.


 

Thank you
 March was Women's Issues month and April is Sexual Violence Awareness month - which of course every month should be! So please consider contributing to make this project possible. If you don't have the funds, please share with friends, activists and art lovers!

story:
I’m bringing a rare and urgent piece of theater history to life this summer, and I hope you can help me make it happen.

Two years ago, while living at the American Academy in Rome, I unearthed four plays written in 1917 by Fortunato Depero, an Italian Futurist. The plays were never published during Depero's lifetime. They also had never been translated into English, so I spent the bulk of my time in Rome doing just that.

To my knowledge, these short plays, written specifically for the puppet stage, have never been performed. That is, until my new piece, Demolishing Everything with Amazing Speed, premieres at Bard SummerScape from July 7-17 this year!

Unencumbered by dialogue, the work is hallucinatory, violent, and surprisingly playful. The menacing tone captures the mood of the era: civil unrest and a changing world order after years of brutal warfare. The parallel to life today, almost 100 years later, is striking. If we consider that World War I left in its wake a world ripe for Fascism, we see those same forces at work in today’s political climate.

An extraordinary team of collaborators is helping me tease out these connections: Tom Lee (projection design) Dan Moses Schreier (original music) and Tyler Micoleau (lighting), to say nothing of the amazing puppeteers who are animating this historic and almost forgotten work.

Our challenge is financial: we need to raise an additional $20K to finish creating this piece!

Please consider making a tax-deductible donation to Demolishing Everything with Amazing Speed.

With your timely support, this prescient and uncanny piece of theater will come fully alive – a century after it was written. Given current events, the time for this work is now.

Thank you greatly for your consideration and support.

Dan Hurlin

Created by The Ensemble: CB Goodman, Josh Rice, Eric Avery, Lake Simons, Takemi Kitamura, Rowan Magee, Chris Carcione, and Catherine Gowl

Produced by MAPP International Productions

World Premiere at Bard College SummerScape

The Fisher Center at Bard College; July 7-17, 2016

story:
Overview

Poisoned is a Rock Musical about the classic Snow White story. It features strong ideals about Love, Anxiety, and Acceptance with a new contemporary rock twist on the classic Grimm's Fairy Tale. We have loved putting this project together and know with your support, it will be able to be seen on a stage near you!

Short Summary

As we are in full swing to put this amazing production on , we are still in need of some help. POISONED Is a dark retelling that touches on many topics like how fame and power can become an addiction, how to overcome abuse, and believing in hope in the darkest of times.  

With your support this round of campaigning will help contribute to production expenses (set, costumes,props lights and sound),

The Impact

We’ve always been told, “Be the change you want to see in world.” That’s what this musical is: our vision of that change. It features strong female characters, LGBT representation, and diversity, as well surviving abuse, holding on to hope in darkest of times, and standing up for what’s right.

Risks & Challenges

In producing theatre there are always some risks. We are planning for a successful run. In putting all the puzzle pieces in place, we need your support. Live theater is a collaboration of many talents on and off the stage.  Your financial support is needed and ask that you contribute to this project and join us on this journey.  We are committed to bringing this amazing production to the public. Our ultimate goal is a long, beneficial run of Poisoned!

Meet the Team!

T. James Callahan is the Creator, Writer and Director.  Ever since Tyler was a young child, music has always been apart of his life! Throughout his childhood Tyler was involved with his church choir and then was taught to dance at Bataille Dance Academy! It wasn’t till later in his youth that he discovered the world of musical theater and ever since Tyler has been apart of many shows and many productions throughout the Chicago Land area. Later, he studied music and jazz vocals technique at the Bloom School of Jazz with David Bloom himself and Spider Saloff. Tyler is currently studying vocals with the fabulous Christine Shelton and now Tyler’s true love and passion is writing and being involved with music! No matter where he goes Tyler wants to give all his love and thanks to his friends and family for their inspiration and support. Tyler always look forward to dedicate his life to music and most of all to the theater.

Michael Galloway is the Producer. When Michael was in the 3rd grade he played the guard at Emerald City in the Wizard of Oz.  That little Theater Bug germ blossomed into a full blown addiction to being on stage.  After acting in numerous school and community theater shows through his school and college years (proud to be an alum of AMDA and including dancing in a grass skirt and coconut bra), he turned his attention to the dark side..well, working off the stage.  He is able to boast many accomplishments in acting, directing, stage management, and lighting design,  but his passion lies in producing live theater. Now, in his early 50's and having successfully produced over 50 shows in his career (including American Idiot, Nunsense, Billy Elliot the Musical, Legally Blonde, Bleacher Bums, Waiting for Godot just to name a few). He now turns his talents to Poisoned: A Snow White Rock Musical! He would like to thank his family and loved ones for always supporting him and believing in the productions he loves.

Aaron Kaplan is the Musical Director.   Aaron enjoys a multifaceted musical career as a conductor, musical director, cellist, music educator, and arranger. Aaron has been the music director/conductor for over 65 musicals (with complete orchestration) including West Side Story, On the Town, Les Misérables, Sweeney Todd, Of Thee I Sing, RENT, Chess, Guys & Dolls, Fiddler on the Roof, and The Producers.  He is the assistant orchestra director at Glenbrook North and Glenbrook South High Schools in Northbrook and Glenview, IL, is on the faculty at the Music Institute of Chicago and is the assistant director of the Chicago Suzuki Institute.  As a cellist, he is currently a member of Sinfonia da Camera and the Heartland Festival Orchestra. Aaron earned a master’s degree in orchestral conducting from the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign under the tutelage of Donald Schleicher, in addition to a bachelor’s degree in cello performance and bachelor’s degree in music education. 

Annie Snow is the Choreographer.  Annie is a Chicago based teaching artist, choreographer, and performer. Recent choreography credits include: Elf Jr. (Big Deal Productions),  Xanadu  (Big Noise Theatre-Lou Recommended-BWWW Nominee for Best Choreography Non-Equity), Sister Act (Mundelein High School Theatre), Oklahoma! (Glenview Theatre Guild), Elephant and Piggie We're In a Play! (Northbrook Theatre for Young Audiences) and Big Fish (Big Noise Theatre-BWW Nominee for Best Choreography-Non Equity). Annie is the Program Manager for Chicago Lights Dance Academy which services under privileged youth in Chicago. She also enjoys teaching dance at Studio 83 Dance Academy, where her choreography for the Studio 83 Dance Company has received many regional and national accolades. She is excited to be on board for Poisoned. Annie is so thankful to her family and friends for their unwavering support of her work over the years. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t donate right now, we’d still love your help! You can:

Like us on Facebook!  Follow us on Instagram  and @poisonedarockm1 on Twitter

Buy TICKETS TO THE SHOW- www.poisonedarockmusical.com or www.stage773.com 

Share this page with people you know who would be interested in Poisoned! and encourage them to donate.

Reach out! We could always use a hand to help build set pieces, props, and more.

We are also looking for investors for the production. If you would like to be involved in that capacity, please contact our Producer, Michael Galloway at pansfluteproductions@gmail.com

Please show your support and spread the word!

story:
Hi!  I am Glorianne Morrow and I want to tell you about my passion for ballet.  

When I was 3, I had my first ballet class and I have been in love with ballet ever since!  I am now almost 16 so I have been dancing almost all my life. I am currently receiving instruction in a performing classical studio and have performed in major productions such as The Nutcracker, The Sleeping Beauty, Cinderella, Peter and the Wolf, Coppelia, Hansel and Gretel and La Boutique Fantasque.

Most recently I was featured as Rose Queen and Sugar Plum in The Nutcracker and I will be featured as Cinderella in our spring performance in a few weeks.

I have attended several summer intensives at Nashville Ballet and ABT and have been accepted again this year into The American Ballet Theatre's summer intensive program which is June 30th through July 20th.  I consider this an honor and being able to attend will give me a level of continuing experience and training that will greatly help me attain my professional goals of helping underprivileged and "at risk" young  people through dance instruction.

My Mom and Dad adopted me when I was just a few hours old and have loved, supported and encouraged me all along the way. They have believed in me and given me every opportunity to become the best I can be.

That is why I want to help other people.  Being adopted I have a better understanding of what children sometimes deal with in how they feel about themselves and how they look at life. 

As a well trained ballerina, I want to help other kids through dance instruction to have a better self image, to begin to develop a sense of purpose and accomplishment, to see life through different lenses. Through dance they can develop a healthy expression of inner thoughts, conflicts and difficult issues they may be dealing with.

I currently have an invitation to come to Honduras to work with Street Reach as they help in the education of youth.  They have asked me to give dance instruction to the kids they work with.  I am also a student teacher for the younger dancers in my home studio as well as give private lessons to very young dancers before they join our studio.

Your support for me in this campaign will allow me to benefit from the premier ballet instruction I will receive at ABT this summer.  I will be taking classes for 8 hours a day, 6 days a week for 3 weeks.  That's why its called an intensive!

 

What We Need & What You Get

The tuition to ABT for the intensive is $1250 and the room and board at the University of Alabama in Tuscaloosa is $1550.  I will also need specific dance wear and travel expenses.  So, the total I need is $4000.

I have a regular job babysitting a family of 3 children, so I am putting all I make towards what I need for the intensive.  And my parents are helping any way they can, but we all felt that it is time for me to rise to the next level in taking more responsibility for my ballet pursuits.

I would like to give each person who supports me through this campaign an autographed photo taken by professional photographer Keith Glines of Fairhope, AL.

Whatever funds I receive during this campaign will go exclusively towards my continuing ballet instruction.

 

The Impact of Your Support

I know how good I feel when I am able to be part of something bigger than myself and when I can have a direct impact towards helping someone else.  I hope you can grasp my heart's desire to make a difference for other people.  The gift I have been given is Ballet.  (My instructor says I speak the language of ballet everytime I am on stage.)

Your support in this campaign doesn't just get me to a ballet intensive.  Together we will be able to touch other lives with the beauty of dance.  I "come alive" when I am dancing and together we can give that to others.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help.  I would greatly appreciate your asking your friends, family and associates to view this campaign.  

 

And I want to thank you from the bottom of my heart for taking time to view my campaign and whatever level of support you feel to participate in.

story:
CAMPAIGN UPDATE

**This music and dance troupe of young children struggle all year long with broken instruments and not enough costumes. Even though we've reached our goal, your additional contributions will go towards sustaining St. Joseph Magogo's music program throughout the coming year AND the purchase of new instruments and costumes for these superstar students!**

We are overwhelmed by the outpouring of support for these vivacious young musicians! Because of your contributions they are currently competing in the capital city of Kampala for the National Dance and Drama Competition. And guess what, they're blowing the competition out of the water! Just yesterday, we heard from our Program Coordinator on the ground in Uganda, Grace Najjuma, and here's what she had to say: 

"I am happy to JLMC for sending me to watch this National Competition. Honestly, it is fun and I am glad to inform you that Magogo is doing so well in its competition compared to the first class schools it's battling against like Namugongo, Kabojja, Ndejje - for no one believes it is their first time in the Nationals! There are 42 schools in the competition from all parts of the country and it is amazing. The children are so happy and grateful to JLMC for the support and here Magogo is rejoicing!" 

Who We Are

Just Like My Child Foundation™ is a San Diego-based 501(c)3 organization working with impoverished communities in rural Uganda and Senegal. 

Our goal is to transform humanity by empowering women and children to reach their full potential through a holistic system of health care, education, micro-enterprise, girls' empowerment and social justice.

Meet St. Joseph Magogo's Dance Troupe

  • We've worked with St. Joseph Magogo Primary School in the Luwero district of Uganda since 2010 through our Project Universal Education™ and Girl Power Project™.
  • In 2012, after witnessing firsthand the school's incredible culture of music and dance, we funded the purchase of musical instruments for the students.
  • At the beginning of August, they won the opportunity to compete in the Luwero District Music and Dance Competition, and won 9 out of 10 rounds.
  • From there, they went on to Regionals (which included 7 districts), where they won first place!

St. Joseph Magogo has earned the opportunity to compete at Nationals at the end of August, where it will be held in Kampala at the National Theater. This motivated school is drawing on the school development training they've received from us to hold a fundraising event where they will charge a small fee for a dress rehearsal performance. They are confident that the community will turn out to support this incredible opportunity. 

What They Need

This is a rural and impoverished community, and despite overwhelming support from the community members, it's unlikely the school will raise the amount of funds they need to go to Nationals:

  • $2000 will get the school of 250 children to Kampala and back for Nationals, including transporation, hotel, meals and other incidentals.
  • All funds raised will go directly to our on-the-ground Country Director, who will distribute the funds to the school Headmaster and report on each expenditure.

The Impact

St. Joseph Magogo's participation in the National Dance and Drama Competition will be a life-changing experience for the students and their families:

  • Students will get to see the capitol city of Kampala for the first time in their lives.
  • They will get to spend time with peers from an urban environment and practice many of the social skills they've learned through the Girl Power Project™.
  • It will increase their self-confidence tenfold – they put their whole heart and soul into dancing, and this will bring them incredible joy.
  • It will bring national recognition to their school, resulting in more opportunities for St. Joseph Magogo's teachers and students.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't make a monetary contribution, please share this campaign with your friends, family and coworkers. You never know who will be inspired to change a person's life forever! Also...

  • Like us on Facebook
  • Check out our blog
  • Sign up for our e-newsletters

We hope you can help send the students at St. Joseph Magogo to Nationals TODAY!

story:
Para-Dice is a performance project that aims to make audiences laugh, cry and think in a critical way.  It is directed and choreographed by Patricia Hoffbauer, written by George E. Sanchez and Patricia Hoffbauer, projections and video designed by Peter Richards, choreography assistance by Peggy Gould, performed by Alyssa Alpine, Laura Gilbert, Peggy Gould, Patricia Hoffbauer, Elisa Osborne, Tom Rawe, Peter Richards, and George E. Sanchez.

The Para-Dice project began in 2009 with Patricia Hoffbauer and Peggy Gould in a rehearsal space with no prospective performance dates in sight.  The piece has since expanded to include a total of the above mentioned performers in an all-out parade of inter-disciplinary, multi-lingual, performance extravaganza.  The support Para-Dice receives will make the November 21, 22 and 23 dates at Danspace Project at St. Mark’s Church possible.  Para-Dice stands out for its intellectual bravado and performance juices that meld contradictory narratives and controversial issues in a piece that explodes assumptions and definitions that ignite our current social/political matrix.  We need all the help we can get.  As important as the NYC mayoral election is, as challenging as the national and international economic picture appears, we still need contemporary art-making and performances to not only get us through the night, but hopefully to fuel our sense of rage and civic engagement in the early 21st century.

Why support this campaign over others?  Good question!  Because you need to do this for yourself.  You owe it to your highest aspirations for how we survive all the overwhelming obstacles we face daily.  You owe it to your family who you know need this more than you do.  You owe this to your community who is facing similar challenges in a "non-performance" venue.

Please share this information with friends, family and enemies to help us meet our goal and realize the culmination of a 4-year project!

https://www.facebook.com/paradiceproject

http://danspaceproject.org/calendarandtickets/?day=1385082000

story:
About the Project

Four great leaders were assassinated in the 1960's — a time of global unrest and revolution. Each of these men was advocating for peace, justice, and equality; and each was killed before his visions were realized. Today, within our country, and in our communities, we struggle with the same issues that these leaders, and others like them, fought and died for. We are compelled to ask ourselves: What would the world look like today if any, or all, of these great leaders had lived? What role might the government have played in each of their deaths? And, finally — and most importantly — why does it matter today?

Using historical documents, transcripts, and a selection of quotes, the Project Unspeakable writing team has crafted a theatrical journey that immerses us in the lives of each of these leaders, in their ideas, and in their brutal public executions — in a way that has never been seen before. The play offers a new understanding of our American history: one that does not seek to smooth over the rough edges of the unknown or cover up painful truths, but rather challenges us to speak, today, the unspeakable.

Join us, and carry on the work of building a future marked not by hatred, fear, and bloodshed — but by peace, justice, and equality.


Project Unspeakable is partnering with Convergences Theatre Collective in NYC.

This fall, under the leadership of Jeremy Williams, Convergences Theatre Collective will produce a theatrical lab with Project Unspeakable playwright Court Dorsey and a team of professional theatre artists. This lab will workshop attributes of the play's main character and develop final elements of the story and script. On February 21, 2015, CTC will produce a staged reading of the production script of Project Unspeakable. This reading will play its part in a larger commemoration of the 50th anniversary of the assassination of Malcolm X, held in the Harlem neighborhood of New York City. The reading and the surrounding event will include political leaders, social activists, celebrity actors, and members and leaders of the local community. Click here to learn more.

What We Need & What You Get

We're looking to raise $35,000 to make each stage of this process come together.

Your donation will help us to:

  • produce the theatrical lab, where CTC and playwright Court Dorsey will collaborate on final character and staging development;
  • finalize the Project Unspeakable script;
  • bring Project Unspeakable to NYC in February 2015, as a part of the events commemorating the 50th anniversary of the assassination of Malcolm X.
Check out the sidebar for info on the rewards available to donors - and help us bring Project Unspeakable to life!
