story:
About Our Journey

Death of the Persian Prince premiered at the NYC Midtown International Theater Festival to sold out audiences in July, 2015. We received phenomenal reviews as well as features in the Advocate Magazine, India.com, and Reviewflix.com. Immediately after the premiere we were invited to participate in the South Asian International Performing Arts Festival, where we were honored with the festival's Best Play Award. Now we have the opportunity to move our show to the Duo Theater in NYC for a 2-week run, which will help us continue to develop the play, reach a wider audience, and introduce ourselves to more industry members as we grow our production. 

READ OUR REVIEWS >>        READ THE SYNOPSIS >>

What We Need

We want to ensure that we continue improving the quality of our production with each developmental phase. We are looking to raise $5,000 which will help cover:

  • Minimal salaries for actors and skeletal staff of stage manager, lighting designer/operator, PR ($3,400)*
  • PR and advertising costs ($1,200)
  • Collateral creation and printing -- postcards, programs, emails/mailings to industry members ($300)
  • Nominal fee for theater breakdown/cleaning ($100)
TOTAL: $5,000
*represents the minimal amount needed to mount the production

The Impact

“Sexual reassignment surgery is legal in Iran; however, homosexuality is forbidden and in most cases for males, punishable by death,” according to a 2014 report by the BBC. “There is no reliable information on the number of gender reassignment operations carried out in Iran. But one doctor from an Iranian hospital told the BBC that he alone carries out more than 200 such operations every year.”

Death of the Persian Prince sheds light on this little-known topic by telling a very human story; this isn't a political issue-oriented play, but rather a powerful and emotional story of the human spirit. Howard Miller of Upstage-Downstage claimed, "There is a tendency for plays with a strong social justice message to become pedantic and sanctimonious, but, truly, we do not come to the theater to be lectured to.  So double kudos to Mr. Moss for presenting this story through a naturalistic recounting of the story."

We feel this is a moving story, and one that needs to be heard.

Other Ways You Can Help

If cannot contribute to our campaign, you can still help!

  • SPREAD THE WORD!  Part of the success of crowd-funding is simply reaching a large amount of people.  You can share this to people you know by using the Indiegogo share tools.
  • Contact us directly if you'd like to contribute outside of the online campaign.
  • Volunteer to usher or help in other ways
  • Come see the show!!

story:
Hello everyone,

Thanks for looking at our page. We desperately need your help. 

It is our fabulous housemate Helena's 21st birthday party in two weeks time and we want to give her a birthday party to remember, in the form of a hunky stripper. 

We're looking to raise about £100 and every little helps. Please dig deep and contribute as little or as much as you feel it deserves.

Thanks so much for all your help,

Love from 7 skint students x x x

story:
Twelfth Night Productions

Twelfth Night Productions means a great deal to so many people. We are more than a theater troupe – we are a supportive, educational, artistic, open, accepting community.

We are currently in our 20th season of producing theater – a truly impressive feat considering that we are largely a volunteer run organization. Our committed and enthusiastic community continues to embrace our mission and produce outstanding theater each year, volunteering countless hours and resources to pull off these incredible productions.

It is our focus on community building that is really at the heart of our mission. Over the past 20 years TNP has partnered with dozens of local non-profits to help share their messages as well as support their mission. As a result, we have donated nearly $25,000 to non-profits across the city and connected countless supporters with those very deserving organizations. 

Our community includes people of all ages, from young students to retired professionals. Those young students have had the opportunity to work with dedicated mentors in lighting design, play direction, music direction, stage management, performing, and arts marketing among others. For the college students in our ranks, we have provided $3,000 in tuition assistance. The working professionals and retirees of our community have had the opportunity to return to their love of the theater and music, picking up new skills and friends along the way. 

More Than a Theater Troupe

Beyond providing artistic and educational support, this community encourages and embraces one another. We have come together to provide a shoulder to cry on, and support for a family who lost loved ones to cancer and a house to fire. We have been there for a cast member with an injury, securing rides to work and bringing dinners while he healed. When a beloved actor was diagnosed with early Alzheimer’s Disease during rehearsals for our summer show, our community wrapped her in love, and didn’t hesitate for a moment to continue to let her perform – even with the challenges of the disease.

The Power of Community

Twelfth Night Productions believes deeply in the power of community and over 20 years, in addition to producing evocative, humorous and compelling theater, we have created a family of individuals who support one another and lift each other up. The power of the arts goes deeper than artistic expression and helps to shape and mold those who become a part of it.

How You Can Help

Twelfth Night Productions will use a portion of the proceeds from this fund drive to purchase much needed sound equipment. No more pops, hums and technical issues that have plagued our current set-up. We have contracted with our close partner, PNTA, for a state-of-the-art package that will include new speakers and wireless microphones. In addition to support from our fabulous community, we have reached out to 4Culture for additional support for this equipment purchase.
 Please help us to continue building this strong, vibrant and vital community. We can’t do this without your help and we are so grateful for your amazing support.

story:
Short Summary...

Spookfish is a new play by Philadelphia playwright Haygen Brice Walker directed by Jessica Schwartz premiering in the 2015 Neighborhood Fringe Festival.

Kori, Tyger, BethAnne, Gemma, and Dan are losers.  Not your typical-run-of-the-mill-Urban-Outfitters-shopping-hipster-losers either.  They're not trendy enough for that.  These kids are just real, bonafide losers.  Even Gemma—the 'coolest' of the lot:  would undoubtedly be a loser in any other public school system.

Kori, Tyger, BethAnne, Gemma, and Dan work as ‘actors’ at a shitty haunted house attraction...and you guessed it—nobody shows up.  Ever.  In fact, nothing ever happens...until tonight.   

The play is a mean dissection of B-rate slasher flicks, the American dream, sexuality, and the cruelty of pop culture all set in a dilapidated haunted house attraction in the outskirts of the American South wedged somewhere between a feral cat colony and a Wal-Mart Super Center. 

So really...what I’m saying is: 

It’s Scream

                meets Mean Girls

                                meets Kill Bill

                                        meets Texas Chainsaw Massacre

                                                                                     meets Gossip Girl

                                meets Brecht. 


The Impact...

Spookfish is just the kind of theatre that we not only want to see—but that we want to create. 

It’s bold.  It’s edgy.  It’s scary. 

It’s all the shit that we were told in theatre-school shouldn’t happen on stage—

AND guess what?  We’re making it happen. 

We’re young theatre artists working in an established theatre town.  We are trying to break in.  Make a splash.  Make a scene.  Make a statement. 

SAY SOMETHING.  (And say it just a little bit louder than everybody else.) 

I have spent countless nights trying watching audience members of plays fall asleep.  No matter how engrossing or powerful the words or direction or performances are, there is something that [dwindling] audiences are not buying into at live theatre—which blows my mind.  The medium is fascinating to me, not only because I studied it intensely for four years--but because it literally puts people in a room with other people and confronts them with a story. 

It's art at its most confrontational...and that's why I love it.

If audience members can sit through two and half hours of Furious Seven (which was totally badass--don't get me wrong), without falling asleep--they should be able to sit though a ninety minute play without dozing off.  Even if it is Ibsen. 

I wanted to write a play that not only challenges the form of theatre--but also questions it.  What is this thing?  How can we make it as badass as it should be?

A slasher flick.  A bloody, gory slasher flick on stage.  Literally:  put five of the meanest people you've ever met in the same room for two hours and have them talk to each other.

Surely...something will happen. 

What We Need...

The part we hate:  The part that we have to ask (beg) you for money.  But even a dollar would go a long way.  We need...

Lots and lots of blood. 
And a corpse. 
Oh let's not forget the penis.

Making a live-slasher flick doesn't come cheap...

And that doesn't include the rental fees, lighting equipment, or staff costs. 

Most importantly:  please, please, PLEASE come see the show!  If you are a horror-buff, or wanna laugh, or wanna get the crap scared out of you, or if you wanna be made super uncomfortable...please check us out. 
Side Note: We are giving out some bad ass perks! 

Show Dates at Headlong 
1170 South Broad Street
Philadelphia PA 19146 

OPENING NIGHT! Friday night, September 4th 11:55 PM 
Saturday night, September 5th 11:55 PM 

Sunday night, September 6th 10:30 PM

 Thursday night, September 10th 11:00 PM 

 Friday night, September 11th 11:55 PM 

Saturday night, September 12th 11:55 PM 

 Sunday night, September 13th 10:00 PM

story:
Regina Klenjoski Dance Company has an excellent 14-year track record with its successful dance education program, "Dancing with RKDC," in the city of Torrance, CA. RKDC has reached over 13,000 students since 1999, providing high-quality dance instruction at an affordable price to the South Bay, and is now ready to expand the program to a new community and bring it to the company's home town, Long Beach, CA.

THE NEED

In Long Beach, there is a documented need for dance and arts programs to serve underserved, underrepresented students in the region. RKDC is based in Long Beach and has held a long desire to expand its programs to its hometown. As the fifth largest city in California with 23% of its population at or below poverty level, most public schools and young people in the city are without arts programs.

THE MOMENT 

We believe we are at the right moment at the right time to effectuate the change we have longed to bring to our home community for many years. We have proven that with start up funding we can develop a self sustaining arts education model that will thrive and grow in the community for years to come. As a 14-year veteran of programs in Torrance, Regina Klenjoski is uniquely positioned to be successful in this endeavor - she has the knowledge, maturity and community relationships that ensure success for the residents and children of Long Beach.

THE FUNDS 

Regina Klenjoski Dance Company is a 501(c)(3) not-for-profit company and all funds generated by this project will be used to hire, retain and pay high-caliber teaching artists for classes and in-school workshops and start up marketing costs that include a new "LB Dancing with RKDC" website.

It will cost $5,420 to launch the program (Jan-March), but we've already secured $2,420. We need your help to raise the rest ($3,000) to bring this much needed access to arts education to downtown Long Beach. 

Cost breakdown:

Free outreach programs to local schools: $500

Website, Marketing and technology set up: $920

Direct staffing and administrative costs: $2,100

Studio Cost: $1,600

Total: $5,420 (including $300 in Indiegogo administrative fees)

Amount raised to date: $2,420


Risks and challenges

With 14 years of experience in the South Bay, RKDC is prepared and equipped for launching a self-sustaining education program in Long Beach. To do this, RKDC must continue to bring the community together with the support of local partners and stakeholders to raise awareness of our program offerings.

RKDC has faculty lined up to begin instruction once the program opens, and an inherent challenge launching this program is being able to afford and maintain highly qualified teaching instructors. We believe through growth of the program and student body, maintaining the quality faculty will be supported in the way it has been accomplished in Torrance.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Please partner with us and help spread to the word: share our project with friends and family and help us make some noise.

We have proven that with start up funding we can develop a self sustaining arts education model that will thrive and grow in the community for years to come. As a 14-year veteran of programs in Torrance, Regina Klenjoski is uniquely positioned to be successful in this endeavor - she has the knowledge, maturity and community relationships that ensure success for the residents and children of Long Beach.
THE FUNDS 
Regina Klenjoski Dance Company is a 501(c)(3) not-for-profit company and all funds generated by this project will be used to hire, retain and pay high-caliber teaching artists for classes and in-school workshops and start up marketing costs that include a new "LB Dancing with RKDC" website.

It will cost $5,420 to launch the program (Jan-March), but we've already secured $2,420. We need your help to raise the rest ($3,000) to bring this much needed access to arts education to downtown Long Beach. 
Cost breakdown:
Free outreach programs to local schools: $500
Website, Marketing and technology set up: $920Direct staffing and administrative costs: $2,100Studio Cost: $1,600
Total: $5,420 (including $300 in Indiegogo administrative fees)
Amount raised to date: $2,420

Risks and challenges
With 14 years of experience in the South Bay, RKDC is prepared and equipped for launching a self-sustaining education program in Long Beach. To do this, RKDC must continue to bring the community together with the support of local partners and stakeholders to raise awareness of our program offerings.
RKDC has faculty lined up to begin instruction once the program opens, and an inherent challenge launching this program is being able to afford and maintain highly qualified teaching instructors. We believe through growth of the program and student body, maintaining the quality faculty will be supported in the way it has been accomplished in Torrance.
Other Ways You Can Help
Please partner with us and help spread to the word: share our project with friends and family and help us make some noise.

story:
Who is WISTA?

WISTA, the West Island Student Theatre Association, is a non-profit organization founded in December 2006 as a way to allow post-secondary students to interact and perform in the wonderful world of musical theatre. 

It is a school, a theatre company, a performance venue with dedicated volunteers and members, all with more than a passing interest in musical theatre and youth. WISTA is a member of the Quebec Drama Federation (QDF).

With an average of 700 audience members per show, WISTA is a very community oriented theatre group. We often perform at public events and celebration and in return we love to donate a portion of each show's proceeds to various Montreal charities.  In the past, we've donated to charities such as the West Island Community Shares, the Montreal Children’s Hospital and the Quebec Breast Cancer Foundation.

What makes us different? Musical theatre is what we do. It’s all we do. And we know you’ll love it.

About H2$

How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying will be WISTA's 5th full-length musical production. A satire of big business and all it holds sacred, HOW TO SUCCEED IN BUSINESS WITHOUT REALLY TRYING follows the rise of J. Pierrepont Finch, who uses a little handbook called “How To Succeed In Business Without Really Trying” to climb the corporate ladder from lowly window washer to high-powered executive, tackling such familiar but potent dangers as the aggressively compliant “company man,” the office party, backstabbing co-workers, caffeine addiction and, of course, true love.

Winner of the 1962 Pulitzer Prize for Drama, HOW TO SUCCEED IN BUSINESS WITHOUT REALLY TRYING melds wit, comedy, and romance together to perfection.

Why We Need Your Help

As we are a non-profit organization, WISTA does not receive any outside funding. Musical theatre is extremely expensive to put on, we rely on our cast members and program sponsors to help defray some of the costs. You can alleviate some of this stress by funding our project in exchange for some great perks. As a rapidly growing company, we are looking to grow not only in size but in quality. 

For this production, WISTA needs $1,700 to build awesome sets and $1,500 to get costumes for 26 cast members. The money raised here will not cover all of our costume and sets needs but it will be a huge help and allow us to spend some our budget elsewhere (like our venue, lights and mics). This will also allow us to donate more to charity. Every little bit counts in making this our best production yet!

In return for your generosity, we have a bunch of awesome perks like tickets, pins, original songs, t-shirts and more! You can view the full list of perks on your right! -->

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Share our Indiegogo campaign, images and videos via Facebook & Twitter!
  • Like WISTA's Facebok page, Follow us on Twitter or Instagram (@WISTAMontreal)!
  • Come see the show January 31, February 1, 7 and 8 2014! Check our website www.WISTA.ca, Facebook or Twitter pages for details!

Do not hesitate to contact marketing@wista.ca should you have any inquiries!

story:
WHO WE ARE

We’re the CURRENT SESSIONS, a NYC-based dance organization and presenting series founded in July 2011, now in our 3rd year. We present the works of emerging and mid-career contemporary choreographers on an intimate stage in 8 performances per year, known as SESSIONS; engage the NYC community educationally through workshops and TalkBacks; bring together choreographers, collaborators, dancers, artists of other mediums and dance enthusiasts under one roof; and provide a place for contemporary dance to thrive in our city, invigorating the scene.

The CURRENT SESSIONS Family consists of conservatory-trained artists (many with Bachelor & Master degrees) who have shown work in NYC, elsewhere in the US and even other countries (Italy & Israel). We aim to recognize and celebrate the ever-changing definition of what contemporary dance is.   


WHY FUND US?

By launching our campaign the CURRENT SESSIONS: FUND A YEAR, we’re hoping to fund two SESSIONS (8 performances), 8 LAB // SESSIONS (8 workshop-type classes for dancers and non-dancers), increase our stipends for our Administrative Team, Production Team, Guest Artists, Talkback facilitators and our choreographers who teach at LAB // SESSIONS, and reduce/eliminate the Production Fee for our choreographers who are accepted to present work at the SESSIONS in either March or August 2014   Until this point, we have relied on our percentage of box office sales, choreographer application & production fees, and $2,000 from our Kickstarter in September 2011.

As we continue to expand with new initiatives, so do our expenses; yet, our income remains the same. As a non-profit startup with little seed money and a small part-time staff, there are few public grants available for us. Crowdsource funding and private donations are the most effective ways to raise money for our Organization (a recent article published by the SF Gate revealed that dance projects are fully funded 71% of the time on crowdfunding platforms, making it the most successfully-funded category).

We now look to YOU: our most loyal supporters, longtime friends, family, arts lovers and philanthropists, to help us reach our goal. Your investment in our Mission will ensure that we continue to deliver high-caliber choreography and fulfilling artist & audience experience for which we are known. We thank you in advance for your generous contribution!  




WHAT WE NEED TO FUND

We need $11,000 to FUND A YEAR of programming, which includes:

  • 8 performances in 2 SESSIONS
  • 8 workshop classes
  • stipends for both the Administrative and Production Team
  • stipends for Talkback Facilitators and our Guest Artists
  • stipends for our Curation Team
  • funds for marketing materials
  • and more

We also aim to reduce/eliminate the Production Fee for accepted choreographers into the SESSIONS.

For even as little as $10, your contribution can make a difference:

  • $10 can pay for an hour of rehearsal time for one of our choreographers
  • $25 is half of a stipend for a LAB // SESSION Choreographer
  • $50 can pay for a stipend for a Curation Team Member
  • $125 can pay for one Production Fee that a choreographer pays to present work
  • $200 can pay for our Production Manager for one SESSION
  • $350 can pay for Marketing Materials for the whole year
  • $650 can pay for our Lighting Designer for 4 performances and 2 dress rehearsals

WHAT YOU GET IN RETURN // THE SWAG

As a “thank you” from us, we’re giving you some awesome SWAG, including:

  • a personal thank you email
  • a mention on Facebook + Twitter
  • a CURRENT SESSIONS Tote Bag
  • free entrance to our LAB // SESSIONS
  • tickets to a performance in our March or August 2014 SESSIONS
  • drinks on us at either of the SESSIONS
  • free entrance to HAUS, our social engagement events
  • and more

For our most generous donors, we’re giving you “a night on us,” which includes dinner with drinks on us, plus tickets to a performance of your choice in NYC.

CAN'T MAKE A $$$ CONTRIBUTION? BRING AWARENESS!

If you are unable to fund us with a $$$ contribution, you can still share this video and bring awareness to our project! Use the hashtag #fundayear. Share our story on your Facebook or Twitter. Curious? Come to one of our SESSIONS in March or August and find out what we're all about. Your enthusiasm means everything!

story:
CAST:

Jenna Bates

Alessandra Gianino

Bella Hicks

Myles Nuzzi

Javen Smith


PRODUCTION TEAM:

Director: Victoria Pearlman

Assistant Director: Ryan McRee

Musical Direction: Anthony Lucca and Nathan Heldman

Choreographer: Sarah Fanella

Stage Manager: Lea Branyan 

Assistant Stage Manager: Rebecca Mellinger

Production Designer: Madigan Stehly 

Costume Designer: Meagan smith 

Sound Designer: Stephen Jensen 

Producers: Brandon Baer and Taubert Nadalini


ABOUT OUR SHOW:

With this Independent Student Production of Jason Robert Brown’s Songs For a New World, we intend on exploring as a cast and production team a particularly pertinent theme that we greatly look forward to sharing with USC audiences. 

Presented in a series of vignettes and told solely through song, Songs chronicles the life changing moments in the lives of normal people encountering normal human trials and triumphs.  We witness the stories of a suicidal woman, a pregnant teen, a wrongly imprisoned man, a couple avowing their once-lost love for each other, a woman dealing with her husband’s departure for war, and even the inner mind of Mrs. Claus.  This story travels throughout different time periods—such abandonment of time constraint serving to show the universality of human need and the importance Brown places on the human interactions as opposed to physical setting.  MTR is thrilled to be producing this show because we know how relevant the material is to a college-aged audience.  We all understand the moment before a life changing decision, understanding what it means to grow up, learning how to admit fault and avoid blaming others, recognizing solitude as well as companionship.  It’s these moments that comprise the beauty of life. It’s these moments that are the songs for a new world. 


HOW YOUR DONATIONS WILL HELP:

We are a completely student run production, that means that every single person who works on our show is a USC student. Because of this, we all put in a huge amount of time and effort into make this production as incredible as it can be. That being said, something that we need help with is raising funds in order to pay for materials in order to make the technical aspect of the show as fulfilling as they can be. Funds that we raise will be used for lighting, set, props, and costumes. These things will help us create the most truthful and impactful presentation of this beautiful story as possible.

story:
Can you believe that it's been a year?

The Bechdel Group's inaugural reading took place on June 30th, 2014 at the Back Room at Jimmy's No 43, and we are rounding the corner of our first full year of producing readings that challenge the portrayal of women in film and on stage.

Since we sent our first email and cast our first twelve actors, we've produced ten readings featuring sixteen writers and casting over 140 roles ... many of them strong, interesting, new roles for women!

In June, we will be honoring this milestone by producing our first full staged reading. 

What is The Bechdel Group?

The Bechdel Group is a New York City based group that hosts a series of readings and discussions of new work and works in progress. We look for plays and screenplays that include the feminine experience beyond a woman’s romantic relationships. While we acknowledge that love, sex, and romance are all primal parts of being female, we insist that no real, three-dimensional woman lives in a romantic bubble. We want to read, write, and hear stories about women who are more like us: women who talk about many subjects, including, but not limited to, sex.

Where we began ...

It all started at a play reading, when Alexa Fitzpatrick's friend started hitting on Gina Grandi's friend, leaving the two of them free to talk about playwriting, screenwriting, acting, comedy, and the lack of interesting roles for women.

"We should plan our own reading," said Alexa, never really thinking she'd be expected to follow through.

"Absolutely," said Gina, who, it turns out, is the kind of person who actually makes things happen ... and so began The Bechdel Group.

What happened next...

We drank some coffee, we visited a few venues, and, at the suggestion of Aliza Sarian, our resident dramaturg, met Jimmy and Sheila at Jimmy's No 43. A love affair began over high fives and Sauvignon Blanc and eventually blossomed into a full-fledged sponsorship. (We can't say enough about how much we love Jimmy and Sheila!) This venue enables us to host readings in a comfortable setting conducive to conversation, networking, and festivity.

The First Reading ...

We made some business cards, put up a website, sent out some emails, solicited some scripts, set a date ... and waited, biting our nails. Would anyone come? Was there a place for this kind of theater company in New York City? The Back Room at Jimmy's was packed that first night - and as the scripts and headshots started pouring in, it became clear that we weren't the only ones hungry for this kind of opportunity.

Over the past year ...

We have received writing submissions from all over the country, and have featured new work and work in progress from sixteen phenomenal writers over ten workshops. We pre-cast some roles from our database of interested actors and on-the-spot-cast some roles the evening of from actors in attendance - and are proud to have been able to offer reading opportunities to nearly every actor that has expressed interest. Each of our readings includes an informal discussion, led by our resident dramaturg, so that everyone in attendance has the opportunity to participate.

Tell me about this fundraiser!

Our goal of $1000 will fund our first fully produced staged reading in June and cover printing/production costs for our summer workshops and fall readings.

Raising $2000 will enable us to fund our workshops through June 2016, including a second staged reading.

Our special, secret, double-dog-dare goal of $3000 will fund our journey towards becoming an official non-profit organization. Once that happens you will be able to make tax deductible donations ... how cool is that?!

What's down the road?

We are committed to continue to develop new work from emerging and established writers featuring complex, interesting, and fully developed roles for women. Our long term goals include programs to foster new and emerging playwrights, the expansion of our existing workshop and reading series, and - eventually - full production of work that's come through the Bechdel pipeline. Your donations will help make all this possible!

For more about The Bechdel Group, visit www.TheBechdelGroup.com

story:
Hello, Friend.


Over the past eight seasons, LiveWire Chicago Theatre has been blessed to have provided an artistic outlet for over 500 Chicago artists. We have produced ten Chicago and four World Premieres.  Our Vision Fest has birthed over forty new short plays.  You fell in love alongside us at The 13th of Paris, you said OOHRAH! with us at The Steppenwolf Garage, and you shivered at our Hideous Progeny. 

Our last season saw continued growth for the company:  a successful run of Assistance at the DCASE, a Jeff Recommendation for Partners, expansion of our Unplugged Reading Series, and the addition of several new LiveWire Collective Company Members.  As we begin our ninth season, we are honored when we reflect on everything that our company has created.  Drawing on the strength of the past eight seasons, LiveWire is heading into new artistic terrain.  

We are thrilled to announce that LiveWire will be, for the first time, creating a brand new work generated within The LiveWire Ensemble.  And we cannot wait to share it with you.  But before we can, as always, we still need our community. 

Please consider donating to help LiveWire create and produce our first self generated work.  Any little bit - or lot of bits - helps.  As a 501(c)3 organization in the state of Illinois, your donation to us is fully tax-deductible. 

Your donations will help us to tackle a myriad of challenges:  rental costs, marketing, props, costumes, compensation for our artists and beyond. We have learned over the past eight seasons that our company is at its strongest when you are a part of it. Together we can create something great. 

Humbly and Gratefully Yours,

The LiveWire Chicago Theatre Collective:  Anders, Brian, Caitlin, Christopher, Christina, Eric, Erin, Hilary, Joel, John, Josh, Judy, Krista and Madeline

story:
We're almost there!!

We've set up this page for anyone who wants to help us reach our goal of £12,000, to fund taking two amazing shows to the Edinburgh Fringe Festival 2015!

We are a group of 27 acting students from The Italia Conti Academy of Theatre Arts who are currently creating two fantastic performances to take on tour - Oliver Twist by Neil Bartlett and Piaf by Pam Gems.

Please give what you can to help us conplete our fundraising and make it all happen!

Thank you :)

story:
Greetings!

Hi!  I’m Kate Mitchell, a multimedia artist and choreographer. I’m presenting FASHIONING WOMEN, Saturday, November 16, 2013 (7pm) at SOMArts Cultural Center here in San Francisco.  I’m hoping you’ll help me put on the show!

So, what is FASHIONING WOMEN?

Equal parts glamour and guffaw, this one night only event is a book launch, faux fashion show, gallery show and, dance/theater performance... 

And I need your help to raise $3000 to pay the 25 artists in the show who make it all happen.  

In exchange, I'm offering free tickets, signed copies of the book, even a commissioned collage for your donations.  Thanks for joining this campaign!

The Back Story

It all began with the book, which I started working on about 3 years ago. At first, I set out to make a mock fashion magazine. It ended up becoming a commentary on the cultural imperative for women to achieve the unattainable “feminine” ideal. What a humorous, confusing, and shocking series of revelations!  

Why do clothes define who we are?  And are we supposed to be demure and well behaved, or provocative and sexy? Can we be both? Can we remain eternally young and thin and also know how to bake a great chocolate cake in 20 minutes?

I had to respond to all of these mixed messages in a multidimensional way- with stories,  collage, couture, and movement... because some things just can’t be said with words alone. I realized my best route to conveying and making sense of the conflicting roles of women was to explore them in diverse media, which is why I will present them together in one night.

The Show!

Making the book was the first phase. The second phase is bringing the book to life in a performance.  It’s going to be a gorgeous, funny, and provocative night, featuring 25 performers. Fantastic guest artists from several Bay Area dance companies will be making appearances, along with the fabulous T Sisters, the singing trio out of Oakland.  Rounding out the show, we have mothers, accountants, corporate managers, teachers, designers, an attorney and a pediatrician.

How YOU Can Help

Putting up a show of this size takes time and money- a lot of money! My goal is to raise $3000 to pay the dancers and singers for their inspired performances. These artists are the engine of the show. Please help me fuel them!

Whether you crave a clothing swap or a visit to the Paris runways, you can make a donation to fashioning women. You can also help by spreading the word to your friends and liking us on Facebook!

With your donation you’ll be putting your faith in the value of art-making that searches for ways to make sense of the contradictions within us and in the world around us. Plus, your donation is tax deductible thanks to my fiscal sponsor, Dancers Group.

Thank you so much!

My History

I’ve sought creative expression in a lot of different ways in my adult life. Formerly a dancer in New York, I later moved to San Francisco, formed Kate Mitchell & Dancers, and presented three successive dance projects at ODC Theater.

While choreographing these works, I realized that I also wanted to make work whose highly detailed elements could be seen more closely.  And so I began to create faux couture and collaged work, and presented them through Oakland’s Pro Arts Open Studio tours and in the San Francisco weekly.

Last year, I staged a fake fashion event in Union Square with dancers strutting the runway and shoe-shopping at Macy’s.

story:
Greetings! My name is Cherie Hill and I am an independent choreographer, dancer, teacher, mother and scholar based in Oakland, CA. I have been choreographing for over ten years and on June 5-6 I premiere my first evening work called "Terrestrial Footprints" at the Omni Oakland Commons. "Terrestrial Footprints" is a culmination of my research on dance improvisation and African aesthetics and features a diverse cast of six female dancers. 

I am launching this campaign to help fund the production costs and artist fees for our June premiere, and to celebrate my 35th year of life on earth! I want this piece to be strong, and I want the hard working dancers to be paid. Your help will make all this possible!

As an artist I am interested in ways dance can lead societies to personal/communal/and spiritual transformation and I aim to produce dance that is conscious, analytical, and meditational. I have shown choreography in San Francisco, Oakland, Berkeley, and Riverside, CA, Boulder and Denver, CO, and Holland, MI. My research has been published in Gender Forum, The Sacred Dance Journal, and In Dance, and I am currently on faculty at Luna Dance Institute where I teach dance to children and families who otherwise would not have access to it. 

Please read the information below to find out more about the project.

With gratitude,

Cherie Hill  www.iriedance.com.

About the work:

"Terrestrial Footprints" is inspired by my project to teach African dance elements from a conceptual perspective. The choreography explores concepts such as contracting, expanding, undulations and rhythm, that are generally found in traditional African Diaspora dances, but rarely used for improvisational performance. Driving the piece is reggae dub music, a genre that is underground and eclectic in the U.S., and massively popular in parts of Europe, Africa and the Caribbean. The piece features splendid dancers Emmeline Gonzalez-Beban, Andreina Maldonado, Hope McManus, Linda Phung and Rose Rothfeder with dub music produced by Brizion, rearranged by Peter Lionheart. Composed of long, luscious movement, "Terrestrial Footprints" is the first dance of its kind entirely performed to dub music. 

What we need:

Producing a dance concert requires a lot of time, money, collaboration and passion. Some funds have been raised through guest performances and workshops, but we need your help to fund the production costs and to make sure the artists get paid for their hard and thoughtful work. Your contributions to this project will go towards:
Rehearsal space + venue rental                                                                                       Costumes + lights                                                                                                                       Promo materials + stage crew                                                                                                           Dancer + designer fees                                                                                             
We estimate a revenue of $400 through ticket sales, which will go directly towards paying the artists. I have a huge respect for my collaborators and I want them to be compensated. With your help we can do what we do best to make sure this performance is a success.

Other ways you can help: 

We appreciate all the assistance we can get! Here are a few ways you can support us outside of donating:

Give us a shout out on Facebook, twitter or instagram. Use the indiegogo share tools to pass this fundraiser along to those who may be interested.

Volunteer to help with set-up or breakdown of the show. You'll have the opportunity to see the work for free.

Come to the performance and/or invite a friend! Tickets are $10-35 sliding scale. http://www.brownpapertickets.com/event/1446755

Pass this on. Pass this on. Pass this on.

Thank you dearly for your time. I hope you will claim a prize and to see you at the show!

story:
sis·ter·hood

ˈsistərˌho͝od/
noun
  1. the relationship between sisters.
  2.  an association, society, or community of women linked by a common interest, religion, or trade.
Ideas for Three started brewing in September of 2014 over coffee in Queens.The three of us, Allison, Julia and Maddie, had just finished an epic project with renowned experimental theater director, Richard Schechner, and unsure of what to do next, we set out to devise our own project based on the subject we all knew best: sisterhood. 

The first workshop of Three was at NYU’s Experimental Theater Wing in May of 2015. Shortly after, it was selected to be part of the New Works Summer Reading Series at the Culture Project in downtown Manhattan. The second iteration of the play will be presented at Dixon Place on Monday, November 16, 2015.  Our Dixon Place showing will be geared toward inviting industry and theatre professionals who can help move "Three" to the next level.

We are looking to raise $2,000 to help give "Three" the fully-realized theatrical life it demands.  With your help and contributions, we will be able to make "Three" the best showcase it can be at our upcoming Dixon Place performance, but a substantial portion of the funds will be allocated for launching the project into its next phase.  Here's where your money goes:

-Marketing, publicity and promotional materials:  so that we can spread the word about our work. 
-Set, costumes, props:  so that our play's visual aesthetic matches the uncompromising level of the work.
-Space and theatre rental fees:  nitty gritty stuff so that the play has a home, and homes in between as needed.

Three is truly a labor of sisterly love, and over the past year we have endured a lot as a trio: a cold Chekhovian winter, a sticky Mississippi summer, two Shakespearean tragedies, five seasons of The Brady Bunch, and 145 episodes of Keeping Up With the Kardashians. 

Sound bizarre? We can't wait to show you!
For more details and ticket info: http://dixonplace.org/performances/three/
xoxo,
#1 ,#2  & #3
(Julia, Allison, Maddie)

story:
Short Summary

Who are you?

The Aeneid Theatre Company (ATC) is a new student theatre company devoted to independently producing upstanding, non-musical plays at USC. Our third production of our very first full season is already well underway: We've recently cast actors, established a creative team, and begun rehearsing Mary Zimmerman’s The Secret in the Wings.

What's that? 

The Secret in the Wings is a contemporary play featuring several playful yet frighteningly dark fairy tales interwoven in a unique, rhythmic structure. Set in what is described as a basement with leaking colors of other more fantastical locations, The Secret In the Wings is a chance to re-live childhood fantasy and to regain a childlike sense of wonder that is utterly crucial to our work as theatre artists. In the words of Burt Chaikin, our director, “The play is about what we fear and why. It shows that the things we’re most afraid of, we don’t have to be, and the world can be what we want it to be, rather than what we have accepted it as. Zimmerman shows us that our childlike spirits can often be more courageous than our adult selves."

Rather than trying to replicate some sort of thing that already exists, Zimmerman dares us to create. And the courage to do is an invaluable trait we can impress upon young, learning actors. The rehearsal process will teach actors how to be independent artists and how to take charge of their own ideas and creative ambitions. We believe students will learn a lot from taking on an entirely new style of acting, one not grounded in the Western obsession with realism and authenticity, like they have been doing for most of their acting careers thus far, but one grounded in self-conscious performativity, presentation and archetype.

The Secret In the Wings shows us why we dream, and emphasizes the importance of doing so. Mary Zimmerman teaches us in this play that the world can be a wondrous place if we allow it to be, and includes the following quote at the beginning of her play, which summarizes it all:

“Perhaps all the dragons in our lives are princesses who are only waiting to see us act, just once, with beauty and courage. Perhaps everything that frightens us is, in its deepest essence, something helpless that wants our love.” —Rainer Maria Rilke

So what's the Indiegogo page for?

The next step of this creative process involves a monumentally important person: You. Because this is our very first season, ATC is yet to fully acquire the funding and support that other, long-standing production companies possess. We need a little more assistance to get our company off the ground and onto the stage, and contributors like you can make all the difference in the world.

With your help, ATC can begin making a real impact on the USC theatre community and the students involved.

What We Need & What You Get

Where does the money go?

The production team has set a maximum budget for the production which will not change. The budget is broken down between the costs of scenic design, costuming, venue fees, and other essentials for producing any kind of theatre. Any money raised here will go directly to funding these essential costs of production, even if we do not raise the full $1,500.*

*Indiegogo claims 9% of funds if fundraising does not meet the goal amount.

What do I get out of this?

Firstly, you get the knowledge that you've helped enrich the lives of countless students and theatre-lovers in the USC community by helping produce a compelling work of art. 

But if you're looking for something a little more extrinsic, there are a few unique perks involved in contributing to our cause:

·  Every contribution of $10 gets a personal thank you from a member of the ATC board.

·  Every contribution of $25 gets two (2) guests free admission to one of our six shows.

·  Every contribution of $50 gets two (2) guests free admission tickets and priority seating to one or more of our six shows.

·  Every contribution of $100 gets two (2) guests free admission tickets and priority seating to one or more of our six shows, along with a video shoutout from a cast member.

·  Every contribution of $250 gets the contributor recognition as an executive producer of The Secret In the Wings at USC, along with two (2) free admission tickets and priority seating to one or more of our six shows, and a video shout-out from a cast member.

·  Every contribution of $500 gets the contributor recognition as a founding investor in the Aenied Theatre Company on future ATC publications including the website and Facebook page, along with two (2) free admission tickets, priority seating to one or more of our six shows, and a video shoutout from a cast member.

The Impact

How does this help in the big picture?

While USC has amazing student organizations devoted to producing a wide variety of theatre, including musicals and new works, there is no other student organization dedicated to regularly producing great, non-musical plays. Opening with our first full season this year, ATC has set out to provide students a solid platform to practice their art. As part of each season, we've also committed ourselves to producing a contemporary piece of theatre every semester, and with this show, we hope to enrich our student body with a love and understanding of modern and experimental (but always relevant!) plays. Every dollar raised helps us reach that goal.

Other Ways You Can Help

What if I'm totally, 100% broke? 

If you don't have a couple dollars to spare right now, that's okay! You can still help in other ways. Most importantly, you can share this page on all your social media profiles and help spread the word to as many people as possible. Do you have a rich aunt who loves the theatre? Does your best friend's dad save copies of Brothers Grimm fairytales in glass cases all over his mansion? Did your neighbor recently win the lottery and now wants to contribute to a good cause? Share this page with them, and help us get once step closer to our goal!

WHO IS weAREproductions?

- Since being founded in in 2013, weAREproductions has produced eight plays in Chicago.

- weAREproductions is currently prepping their next and last musical in Chicago, SMOKEY AND THE BANDIT: THE MUSICAL, going up in the Spring of 2017 at MCL THEATRE CHICAGO (http://www.mclchicago.com)

- Three of those eight, had sold out runs (which were all produced at different times of the year: October, February and April). 

- Here are sneak peeks of a couple of our shows, performed live on WGN:

BABYSITTER MASSACRE '78: THE MUSICAL http://wgntv.com/2015/10/22/babysitter-massacre...

FLEETWOOD MACBETH http://wgntv.com/2016/04/06/fleetwood-macbeth-a...

- Our most popular show to date, A NIGHTMARE ON BACKSTREET: A BOY BAND MUSICAL PARODY, was originally produced in Chicago 2014, Collegiate Premier at Millikin University 2015, Chicago Remount in 2016, and a special engagement at the Joe Ford Amphitheater in Somerset, Kentucky in the Fall of 2016.

MEET THE CAST AND CREW

The show has already been cast and we already have a remarkable behind the scene team, including:

- BAND LEADER/ARRANGER: Robert Campbell

- VOCAL DIRECTOR: Dan Riley

- CHOREOGRAPHER: Laura Marsh

The show has also already been cast by some of the best comedic performers in Chicago, including:

- Timmy Hart Barron as THE BANDIT

- Ali Delianides as FROG

- Kyle Encinas as SNOWMAN

- Mark Hespen as SHERIFF BUFFORD T JUSTICE

- Caroline Nash as BIG ENOS

- Ashley Geron as LITTLE ENOS

Here is character art provided by Tim Williams:

Timmy Barron as THE BANDIT

 

"BANDIT JACKET" provided by KAMBOZ (www.kamboz.com)

This is a great quality jacket, and we cannot wait to use it for the show.

To get your own "BANDIT JACKET," just like the one seen in this video, go to http://www.kamboz.com/shop/smokey-and-the-bandit

We’ve put together some demos with the live band and members of the cast, to give you an idea of what the show might sound like. If you love the original film, great country rock from the 70’s and 80’s, then support and help us get SMOKEY AND THE BANDIT: THE MUSICAL, to a stage in Chicago, April 2017.

This show is a labor of love. I cannot tell you how many times I have watched these movies, and sang along to these soundtracks, on road trips.

Help us make this dream a reality. 

Risks and challenges

- A big portion of the money raised, will go towards paying the live band. We will be using some of the best musicians in Chicago.

story:
ABOUT US

Hip hop academy Camps Breakerz is a non-religious, non-political grassroots organisation aimed at providing a better future for the youth of Gaza. For 11 years, founder Moh has been teaching the four arts of hip hop – breakdancing, street art, and writing music and lyrics – to give kids confidence, a sense of pride in themselves and the hip hop community, a creative outlet and a relatively safe and normalised place to meet up. It’s an oasis of calm and fun in a perpetually stressful, war-blighted environment.

WHAT WE NEED

The Camps Breakerz dance studio is currently being used as a shelter for families who have lost everything in the continuing conflict. The centre itself has been damaged in the war, and urgently needs to raise $3,000 for essential repairs and supplies. It desperately needs a new generator, as power to the block has been knocked out by Israeli bombing. As well as money to replace windows, lost speakers, floor mats, dance mirrors and art supplies, the centre also have to address more basic needs – the kids need clothes, including shoes and socks.

This is an opportunity to provide direct assistance to the Palestinian people in the name of peace. Camps Breakerz is not affiliated to any political, religious or any other kind of organisation, receives no support from the Palestinian Authority, and is disliked by Hamas as the crew feature b-girls as well as b-boys. If you have any doubt as to the importance of this project, check out these photos from a recent function at the centre. 

As Camp Breakerz Crew Moh (who is studying to be a nurse in the States before returning to Gaza) says, ‘My crew recently ran a small open day for the children of our centre and they became super happy and fun. They are strong enough to still believe in life and its joy after the war on them in Gaza.’

They are strong enough to still believe in life and its joy after the war on them in Gaza.’

story:
New Perk! Contribute $100 or more and you can sit in on our auditions in late February.  Edward Nattenberg runs the auditions like an acting class to establish excellent rapport.  

Why we want to produce Mad Tom: While some productions leave me patting myself on the back, thinking myself even more insightful than before, I prefer a show that leaves me thinking I've landed on another planet. 

Mad Tom is that kind of play.  It opens on a family scene that rapidly exposes  deep fissures.  

Catchy Name produced this work as a one-act in the 2004 San Francisco Fringe Festival and then as a full-length at the SF Actors Center, directed by Steve Budd and starring Josh-Sternin Moser, Nancy Lawson, Belle Borovik, Rob Witowski and Doug Marshall.  

Edward Nattenberg and Jim Strope have been working the script, making the hard-hitting play even stronger.  

Jim Strope

Founder and resident writer, software engineer, backpacker and man-about-town, Jim will stop at nothing to deliver sensational dramatic art with a dark, comic, and claustrophobic philosophic underlayment.  Life is short.  Death is long.  Be all you can be.  Work for peace.  Prepare for the worst.  And most of all, count yourself lucky to be working with Edward Nattenberg! 

Edward Nattenberg

Our director, Edward Nattenberg, builds his life around stage.  He is  amazingly talented and honest and persistent in his dramaturgy.  The cast members will follow him anywhere.  His education, acting experience, brilliant textual analysis, devotion to action and dynamic personality attract the very best actors in the SF Bay area. They want to work with us.  

We’d like to be in it for the money but …

A production in the San Francisco Bay Area runs about $5,000. 

Most of our funds go to the theatre owners who turn it over to their landlords.  Most theatre owners do not get a nickel for all their work.  It costs them to host stage productions. 

Our actors, directors, stage managers, lighting and sound people get a stipend of about $200 and a share of the gate, which totals to about $500 for 70 hours of rehearsal and 12 performances.  About $5 an hour and the glory of getting on stage. 

The writer-producer works for negative money.  Before we went to IndieGoGo he donated $2,000 to secure the theatre.  

Production History

We've mounted over 70 performances in black box theatres in San Francsico.  

Stills and videos... http://www.catchynametheatre.org/bigthings.htm

Evil Hamlet by Wm Shakespeare: Not your grandmother’s Hamlet.  Two families vie for the throne of Denmark in Jim Strope’s edition of the world’s most famous play. 

Mitch Mikinos Jim Strope's retelling of Agamemnon.  

Corned Beef A woman poses as a prostitute to bring men home for her shy roommate.  Part 1 of a trilogy.  Jim Strope

Something You Might Want A young woman wants two husbands.  Part 2 of the trilogy.  Jim Strope.  

Man Without a Mask Part 3 of the trilogy.  Jim Strope.  

Mad Tom Dark comedy of abandonment set in Pensacola Florida.  Jim Strope.  

Sam Marlowe The young private eye takes on every windmill in town in this noir tragedy by Jim Strope.  

San Francisco Fringe Festival 2002, 2004, 2005, 2009.  

On Deck

Mad Tom: Where you go when the bottom falls out of your nihilism. 

Tender is the Dawn: A Sam Marlowe Mystery. 

In Harm’s Way: Young Sam Marlowe on the eve of WWII. 

Parallel Play: A play within a play within a play that asks: Who's going on? 

Director’s Cut: A suicidal director of funeral scenes decides to give it up after all. 

Pounding: The movie!  Two tough guys have a nasty job to do and one  has cold feet.  The other is not pleased.  We want to film the 1-act in a dive bar and take it to Scary Cow.  If they fund us, we'll add a chase scene.   

Catchy Name Theatre Company

Catchy Name Theatre Company is a 501(c)3 non-profit corporation.

story:
Short Summary

Calling all moms! Or anyone who’s ever had a mom. Urban Momfare is a musical romp through the landmines of motherhood.We follow the friendship of three mothers on Manhattan’s Upper East Side, as they navigate 17 years of parenting, from “Music For Gifted and Talented Babies” to college applications. The absurdities of this rarefied setting reflect the universal truths about the dark and darkly comic sides of motherhood. And we sing about them! Urban Momfare has an all-women cast, band, and creative team. By supporting our show, you support women in theatre, helping to make our voices heard and proving that women can create powerful works of art that resonate with all of us.

What We Need & What You Get:

Exciting news for Urban Momfare: We have been selected to participate in the FringeNYC Festival! Which is where you come in...we need help raising funds to cover operating expenses for the run.
For donations of:
$20-$49: Your name will be included in the program as a "Supporter"
$50+: You will receive an Emerging Artists Theater Tote bag in addition to your name appearing in the program

    Other Ways You Can Help

    If you are in the NYC area, be sure to check us out at the FringeNYC Festival. Performance schedule below:

    SAT 8/9 @7pm 
    THURS 8/14 @2pm 
    SUN 8/17 @7:45pm
    FRI 8/22 @5:15pm
    SUN 8/24 @3:30pm

    Tickets available online:
    http://www.fringenyc.org/basic_page.php?ltr=U

story:
Formed in 2009 by Artistic Director Arica Brown, Consuming Kinetics Dance Company (CKDC) seeks to enrich the St. Louis community with works of art that represent cultural expression and dance progression. CKDC is a Contemporary Dance Company producing relevant works based on forward looking ideals. Currently, the company consists of 15 company members, 9 apprentices and 3 junior company members.  CKDC has recently been working with Guest Choreographers Robert Scoggins and Dr. Alice Bloch.

CKDC focuses part of its mission on educating and empowering young artists. The company hosts summer camps and continuing education classes ranging from the classics; Ballet, Tap and Jazz to innovative styles such as Modern, Contemporary, Hip Hop and Breaking. 

CKDC seeks to assist artists making a living as educators, performers and choreographers. CKDC is also home to a junior company where 11-17 year old young artists are encouraged to perform and contribute independent works to the CKDC repertoire.

As a newly formed, 501c3, Consuming Kinetics Dance Company (CKDC) is looking for funding to assist in covering costs of costumes for performers. Costumes and performance space costs are part of the yearly maintenance that assists small cultural arts organizations in producing compelling works.

Your donations will go to purchase much needed branded company warm-ups and costumes for choreography to be launched in the next season. The warm-up pieces will also serve as marketing collateral for the organization.

Any and all donations collected will go to assist in covering the cost for individual dancers. Individually, the warm-ups and costume rates could cost our artists $100 - $200. We will take all funds raised and evenly disperse them amongst our performers. Any funds we raise over the amount we are asking will be forwarded to future costume purchases.

Don't have the capability to donate? You can still help! Please share our campaign with your friends and loved ones to help us reach our goal.

story:
One hundred and ten years ago in Moscow, Konstantin Stanislavsky directed the premiere of Anton Chekhov's The Cherry Orchard, the pinnacle of his art. We decided to seize the opportunity to stage this immortal masterpiece around the exact dates of of its anniversary. We did a new translation and will stage the play for what it has to say right now. Each character portrayed by the author speaks directly to us in ways that are at the same time mysterious and incredibly strong. We can't wait to show it to you!

One of the main nodes of the play is the relationship between beauty and money:
How can beauty thrive without sensible business practices? Is beauty even possible without exploitation? What price are we ready to pay for a piece of that beauty?

The actors, the director, producer, and translator are practically working for free, just for the privilege of materializing this play's multilayered world, its emotions and themes for the audience.

But, even with a "bare bones," no frills production like this, there are a number of expenses. Here are some examples:

4 hours of ensemble rehearsal at Theaterlab: $140 (x11 = $1540)

1 performance at Theaterlab $400 (x5 = 2000)

Designing and printing the poster and postcards with the beautiful cherry tree: $500

Set and props: $500

Costumes and costume designer: $1000

Light design and light board operator: $500

For now, this show has been entirely self-produced but we could defintely use your help, so that we have more opportunities to offer you quality, relevant, engaging theatre as a sustainable ensemble.

Please help us bring this immortal masterpiece to life!
Buy your plot of the Cherry Orchard - 110th anniversary edition.
You can decide the amount of your donation independently from the perks.

Even $5 count and will be highly appreciated!

If you know one of the actors and you are donating in their name, please tell us so in the comments sections as 40% of the amount earned from your donation will go directly to that particular performer.

Thank you in advance for your support!!!

Theatreplots


Theatreplots is a new theatre ensemble dedicated to the staging and reinterpretation of engaging classic plays that are relevant for contemporary audiences. It fosters new translations of drama and embraces the cultural and ethnic diversity of New York City. We believe in a theatre based on actors who, alone, can make the stage the most powerful experience for the spectator in an intimate setting.

story:
Crowdfunding Or, The Whale:

A Salty Dialogue


To pitch our fundraising campaign, we sat down with Captain Peleg, a retired whaler grown wealthy from his investments in the oil and spermaceti trade. This is what transpired. 


CAPTAIN PELEG:  Ahoy there!

ZACH AND ROSA: Good day to you, Captain! We're Zach and Rosa, the founders of Strange Harbor. 

CP: Avast! What strange harbor might that be? Constantinople? Fiji? Or San Francisco?!

Z&R: Actually, "Strange Harbor" is the name of our theater company. We take classic texts like Herman Melville's novel Moby-Dick and turn them into new plays like Or, The Whale. We want to explore this complex narrative to discover a fresh side of a resonant and captivating story. 

CP: So ye're whalers I see. No petty merchant service service for ye. But flukes! Moby Dick, did ye say? The mightiest whale fish in all great Neptune's ocean! What sort of crew have ye, what strong backs to pull the oars and stout hearts to hurl the spear?

Z&R: Zach's directing and Rosa's dramaturgy would be sunk without the work of Strange Harbor's Associate Artists, and we're proud to have a great cast and creative team behind this project, including all the handsome fellows in our video. 

CP: Sunk ye'd be indeed without such a fine crew, but ye'll never launch upon the vasty deep without a ship! Ye must rig a swift vessel to catch that white demon of a whale.

Z&R: Right you are! We're performing in a majestic, wood-paneled hall in Fort Greene, Brooklyn. The exact location is a secret, but we'll send you the coordinates when you reserve your tickets. 

CP: A secret ship! This is a strange harbor indeed. But why hide ye the name of yer craft? Didst not steal it, did ye? Perdition's flames! Are ye pirates?!

Z&R: Not at all! In fact, that's where you come in. We only expect to make about half of our total budget at the box office, so we need help from people like you to cover our upfront costs like renting space to rehearse, buying props and costume pieces, and marketing our show in print and online. Any contribution you can make toward our project will be a big help and, since we're a fiscally sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization, all or part of your contribution will be tax-deductible!

CP: Tax-deductible, ye say? That's mighty interesting. And I'd help ye chase yer whale, too! That might be worth a cruise about the harbor, however strange it be. 

But I'm a whaling man, and ye need a big fish to tempt the likes o' me to make a three years' voyage 'round the globe! What have ye got to make me wager a purse of spanish doubloons on yer success? What prizes have ye?

Z&R: We've got some great rewards for our donors. We'll send everyone who gives $10 or more a hand-written thank-you postcard with a unique nautical design. If you give $25, we'll send you a discount code for 1/3 off the price of a ticket, and for $50 we'll send you codes for a pair of tickets plus a pack of ten blank nautical postcards to send to your friends. Donors of $100 or more also get a limited edition, professionally printed copy of our original script signed by the cast and crew. For $250 and above we're offering complimentary premium reserved seats and a Producer credit, and $500 also gets you a custom-made stamp kit, complete with blank stationary, an ink pad in the color of your choice, and a personalized stamp hand-crafted here in New York!

Plus, as a fiscally sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization, all donations beyond the value of the reward are tax-deductible!

CP: By Jonah, what a catch! She'll fetch quite a price in our Nantucket market. But the longer the voyage the greater the haul! How far will ye venture before ye return to port?

Z&R: We need at least $3000 to rent rehearsal and performance space, but if we raise more we can add more to the show the fancier refreshments and production values. We’ll also be able to give our donors special secret rewards. That’s why we've got...



Help the Pequod (Ahab's trusty ship) reach her final destination by stretching past our starting goal. $3000 helps us launch out of the harbor, and every additional $500 puts more wind in our sails and charts a new reward for our contributors. 

$3000, THE OPEN SEA: Free grog for all! Every good captain knows that whaling is thirsty work, so we'll serve hearty complimentary refreshments to the audience at every performance if we make our initial goal. 

$3500, THE ATLANTIC OCEAN: Unknown. Who can tell what lies beneath the whale fisheries of yore?

$4000, THE CAPE OF GOOD HOPE: Unknown. Untold riches await those who can brave the storms of old "Tormentoso." 

$4500, THE INDIAN OCEAN: Unknown. Countless merchant ships cross these waters, laden with treasures from the East. But so do pirates. 

$5000, THE SEA OF JAPAN: Unkown. Here be dragons, they say. 


CP: But what reward will ye give yer supporters if ye pass the open sea? A pot of Nantucket chowder? A weekend of shore leave? An ounce of Quito gold? Tell me quick!

Z&R: Not so fast, Captain! You'll have to help us make our goal before you find out what stretch rewards we're offering. But we can tell you we're very excited about them and what they'll add to our show!

CP: Blast! More secrets! Then tell me, where can I turn for more about ye and yer crew? What maps and charts, what almanacs? 

Z&R: We'd love for you to check out our website, StrangeHarbor.org! It's got more about Or, The Whale and our upcoming projects as well as bios for all our Associate Artists. 

CP: I see ye've charted an ambitious course. But what shall I do if my ships are sunk and my cargo lost? How can a penniless sailor fly his colors for ye?

Z&R: Spread the word! Tell your friends and shipmates about our show, and be sure to come check it out. We'll have eight performances from June 13th to the 22nd. If you want to be in the know about all our goings-on, you can join our community as an Explorer! That's the best way to learn some of our secrets...

CP: Well, weigh anchor and heave to! It's time to cast off. Luck to ye, Captain Zach. Luck to ye, Captain Rosa. 

Z&R: Thanks, Captain Peleg! Happy sailing!
story_txt:
Crowdfunding Or, The Whale:A Salty DialogueTo pitch our fundraising campaign, we sat down with Captain Peleg, a retired whaler grown wealthy from his investments in the oil and spermaceti trade. This is what transpired. CAPTAIN PELEG:  Ahoy there!ZACH AND ROSA: Good day to you, Captain! We're Zach and Rosa, the founders of Strange Harbor. CP: Avast! What strange harbor might that be? Constantinople? Fiji? Or San Francisco?!Z&R: Actually, "Strange Harbor" is the name of our theater company. We take classic texts like Herman Melville's novel Moby-Dick and turn them into new plays like Or, The Whale. We want to explore this complex narrative to discover a fresh side of a resonant and captivating story. CP: So ye're whalers I see. No petty merchant service service for ye. But flukes! Moby Dick, did ye say? The mightiest whale fish in all great Neptune's ocean! What sort of crew have ye, what strong backs to pull the oars and stout hearts to hurl the spear?Z&R: Zach's directing and Rosa's dramaturgy would be sunk without the work of Strange Harbor's Associate Artists, and we're proud to have a great cast and creative team behind this project, including all the handsome fellows in our video. CP: Sunk ye'd be indeed without such a fine crew, but ye'll never launch upon the vasty deep without a ship! Ye must rig a swift vessel to catch that white demon of a whale.Z&R: Right you are! We're performing in a majestic, wood-paneled hall in Fort Greene, Brooklyn. The exact location is a secret, but we'll send you the coordinates when you reserve your tickets. CP: A secret ship! This is a strange harbor indeed. But why hide ye the name of yer craft? Didst not steal it, did ye? Perdition's flames! Are ye pirates?!Z&R: Not at all! In fact, that's where you come in. We only expect to make about half of our total budget at the box office, so we need help from people like you to cover our upfront costs like renting space to rehearse, buying props and costume pieces, and marketing our show in print and online. Any contribution you can make toward our project will be a big help and, since we're a fiscally sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization, all or part of your contribution will be tax-deductible!CP: Tax-deductible, ye say? That's mighty interesting. And I'd help ye chase yer whale, too! That might be worth a cruise about the harbor, however strange it be. But I'm a whaling man, and ye need a big fish to tempt the likes o' me to make a three years' voyage 'round the globe! What have ye got to make me wager a purse of spanish doubloons on yer success? What prizes have ye?Z&R: We've got some great rewards for our donors. We'll send everyone who gives $10 or more a hand-written thank-you postcard with a unique nautical design. If you give $25, we'll send you a discount code for 1/3 off the price of a ticket, and for $50 we'll send you codes for a pair of tickets plus a pack of ten blank nautical postcards to send to your friends. Donors of $100 or more also get a limited edition, professionally printed copy of our original script signed by the cast and crew. For $250 and above we're offering complimentary premium reserved seats and a Producer credit, and $500 also gets you a custom-made stamp kit, complete with blank stationary, an ink pad in the color of your choice, and a personalized stamp hand-crafted here in New York!

Plus, as a fiscally sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization, all donations beyond the value of the reward are tax-deductible!

$4500, THE INDIAN OCEAN: Unknown. Countless merchant ships cross these waters, laden with treasures from the East. But so do pirates.

story:
The dancers of NDT are excited to share this campaign with all of our friends and supporters worldwide! Please help us produce this special event by making a contribution below.

All revenue from Switch '14 will benefit the new, joint research initiative of Medical Action Myanmar (MAM) and the Amsterdam Institute for Global Health and Development (AIGHD), with support from ArtAids.

 

WHAT IS SWITCH?

Switch is an annual dance performance organized, created and performed by the dancers of the internationally renowned Nederlands Dans Theater. Switch 2014 (March 22nd at Lucent Dans Theater in The Hague) is the 26th anniversary of this special event. All revenue from the evening goes to charity whist showcasing emerging choreographers from NDT. By taking the helm and organizing this benefit dance performance, NDT dancers are presented with opportunities to participate in artistic, social and administrative responsibilities such as design, photography, budgeting, advertising, etc. These opportunities provide an outlet for the dancers to explore and develop valuable new skills while volunteering their time for service work.

The dancers organize everything, including fundraising (this is our first year ever fundraising online!). Dancers from NDT create new works (11 this year) to be performed. Each year, the dancers choose an organization to partner with, and all proceeds from Switch go directly to the partner organization. Additionally, a selection of dancers will be sent to work directly with the organization to volunteer their time and energy to the cause.

All revenue from Switch '14 will benefit the new, joint research initiative of Medical Action Myanmar (MAM) and the Amsterdam Institute for Global Health and Development (AIGHD), with support from ArtAids. MAM focuses on setting up a network of clinics in Myanmar that help with diagnosis, treatment and prevention of HIV/AIDS, Malaria, Tuberculosis, and childhood diseases and malnutrition. We are thrilled to be committing our energies towards such an important cause.

FUNDRAISING GOALS

We need your help. We have to raise another $5,000 to make this event happen. These funds will go towards covering theater rental, technical costs, music rights, costumes, catering, etc. We've had some incredible support thus far and with this online campaign we hope to complete our total fundraising  goal of €20,000. Please consider making a donation for Switch 2014, supporting the creation of 11 new works by NDT dancers while raising money for a great cause. Check out our super fun perks and please help us spread the word by sharing this campaign with friends and family!

Thank you for your time.

Sincerely,

the dancers of Nederlands Dans Theater

story:
Our mission: Puppets Off-Broad Street presents live performances, workshops, and educational programming that showcase the full potential and wonder of puppetry for audiences of all ages.

Puppetry is full of possibilities. Puppet artists present works with unique viewpoints that differentiate themselves from mass media. Working with children, teens, and adults allows for many opportunities to find one's unique voice -- sometimes without even uttering a single word! So many styles of puppetry -- rod, shadow, hand, marionette, and object puppets -- to explore! And there are many entry ways into puppetry: building puppets, performing with puppets, playwriting for puppetry. So many opportunities for young people to shine on stage -- even if they don't want to act or memorize lines.

We are easing into this in a responsible way -- in the same way, for example, that TheatreLAB and Richmond Comedy Coalition grew organically, performing in venues throughout Richmond for several years before opening up their own spaces. This seems smart. We are starting with our Winter Puppetfest for Families from December 26th-Jan 3rd. (There will be FIFTEEN shows!) Then we will be having a regular series of shows INCLUDING a Puppet Slam for adult audiences and other unique theatrical offerings from puppet artists.

To do this right (and legally...), we need to have some "basic" infrastructure. Things like a website (it's almost done!), phone number, ticketing system, facility rental, posters, promotional/marketing, insurance, and other "stuff" necessary to be a legal entity in the state of Virginia. Oh, there is also the need for a mud wrestling ring and wrestlers outside the dressing room and other requests that might be made by touring artists. (OK, that bit was just to see if you are paying attention!) But this is why we are raising funds. It's a lot to do, but it IS worth it!

We have a long list of aspirations and goals that includes regular family programming, performances for adults that range from the silly (like Puppet Slams) to the sublime, workshops, classes, a special film series (wouldn't that be fun when the Byrd gets those new seats?), and even a puppet camp! We have big plans for RVA that are born of what we have learned from visiting and experiencing rich puppetry scenes in other cities. We have seen how puppetry and theatre have transformed neighborhoods, lives, and communities. We hope to give the same to Richmond.

Question: But what are you doing with this money, anyway?

We want to keep ticket prices to $10 each and your donation helps make this possible.  Performance costs include the venue, sound, lighting, tickets, Richmond City admissions tax, paying performers, travel for performers, and all the other legal hoopla! Typically, when you buy a ticket in any theatre, a good bit of the cost is underwritten by fundraising. In addition, if we meet our goals we will be able to give tickets to children and families who would not otherwise be able to see live theatre.

Question: Why did you pick Richmond Triangle Players as your venue? Is this where you will always be performing?

Puppetry is best seen in somewhat intimate spaces where the audience size is under 150 persons. The space inside Richmond Triangle Players (RTP) is beautiful and perfectly laid out for puppetry. Also, Phil Crosby, the managing director, is just fabulous and incredibly supportive of the theatre community in RVA (THANK YOU!) During winter break, RTP is "dark" -- there is nothing scheduled. But this is not usually the case! RTP has a busy, busy schedule. There are some possible dates, but we are currently exploring other spaces in Richmond, too. Our fundraising will dictate much of our planning. If we hit our goal, then we will have a much easier time securing spaces for the rest of the 2015 season.

Question: So...these are kids shows right? Like for two-year-olds?

Well, not really "just" kids. We envision a full series of shows that will provide variety: different styles of puppetry and different target audiences. Yes -- even adult! Believe it or not, in most of the world, puppetry is a form of theatre aimed at adult audiences. Throughout Japan, China, Europe, Canada, Australia, and the Americas! We want to bring shows that introduce Richmond audiences to the fullness of this medium that is both ancient and fully modern.

But, yes, there will be family shows! This is our kick-off: RVA Winter Puppetfest! Most of the time, shows for families are best suited for ages 4 and up. Toddlers are mostly meant to, well, toddle and move about! But this is a wonderful way to introduce younger children to theatre. Some shows may be appropriate for 2-3 year olds, but the greater number of family shows are targeted at ages 4-10 and their parents, grandparents, and caregivers. Having said that, we don't check your child's ID at the door, and we trust that parents will use their best judgment! Puppet playwrights who write for family audiences work hard to create "layers" within a show so that all of the audience members (not just the children) can enjoy the show. This is a wonderful way for families to enjoy time together. A fabulous way to create community!

Please join "the village" that helps makes this happen.
