story:
B is a first generation Brazilian girl living in London at home with her Mum and her two sisters. She’s got the worst hangover of her life, she’s been out all night, and she doesn’t want to go home and face the consequences last night: when over the loud music of a night club, her sisters find out that she’s working at a stripclub… or do they?

Fuck You Pay Me is coming to Platform Southwark in November 2017 and this is why you gotta know about it:

Real reactions from audience who saw us at Brainchild Festival this year:

“A gripping insight into the world of stripping. Authentic, high energy and hilarious, beautifully performed. There's no show like it.”

"Joana's performance at Brainchild blew my mind and deepened my understanding of the paradoxes, ambiguities, and tragedies of life while making me laugh so much at them with her. Magnetic, genuine and funny as fuck."

This project started out as a gut response to a city that only seemed to think about strippers in one of … what, four? ways? “Strippers got a tonne of money. Strippers got absolutely no money. Strippers got trafficked. Strippers run on coke, pink champagne and £50 notes alone. Strippers got daddy issues.”

For a little while I was wired on thinking, exploring and divining, and over the last year, I tested it as a play, as a stand up set, as poetry, as dance, as music, as visual art. Now I’ve got something good going, it’s called Fuck You Pay Me: 60 minutes of joy, mess, laughter and good vibes for and about our dear n darling stripper sisters. Fuck You Pay Me transcends the happy-hooker tragedy porn narrative in the media we are bored to tears with and now we’re ready to share it with you ... if you’d just throw a tiny bit of cash at us ;)

What we need

We need 8K. That sounds like a shittonne, but we don’t agree with the idea of artists working for free (do you?). We want to pay our collaborators industry minimum, so for your money and their time, we’re going to make something bangin’ that'll prick some bigwig ears, not just a jolly for my Mum to pat me on the back for then take me for a Pad Thai after, you feel me?

If you're curious, this is the breakdown:

Equipment hire (lights, sound and music, including rehearsal): £4850

Production design and lighting design consultant: £610

Production (set, props, costume): £550

Marketing and publicity (photography, graphic design, production budgets for online collateral): £1270

Technical staff: £170

Music licensing: £110

Insurance, venue running and contingency: £390

Our rehearsal space and venue has been provided by our mates at Platform Southwark. We like Platform Southwark. Shit like that would usually cost around £3500, so they’ve saved a bit for you.

Becoming a patron for Fuck You Pay Me would mean our artists (all 12 of us) get paid. (Mmm, money.) It means we’ll bring the dopest minds together to make properly good theatre about outness and sex and work. If we exceed our target, we’ll programme some sick acts to accompany our show on 14-15 November and the night will that bit more memorable for your midweek. Your cash will be the difference between stop and go with this project. So, let’s do it. Go, go.

Other ways to help

Do you know other people and communities who might spend a dime on us? Share this page with them and get them to contribute. Cash money is the priority. But further down the line if you want to see the show or do some retweets or something, follow us on Twitter for more of that: @JoanaNastari #FYPMshow #FYPM.

Who are we?

Joana Nastari (writer/performer) is a Brazilian British actress, playwright and theatremaker based in London. Recently, her work's been performed across the UK including The Pleasance, Platform Southwark, Brainchild Festival and The Lyric Hammersmith. Joana has gone on to work with makers such as Simon Stephens, Sean Holmes, Steph O’Driscoll, Steve Marmion, Glenn Waldron, Roy Alexander Weise, Simon Russell-Beale and Joe Murphy, and was most recently nominated for a Broadway World award for Best Actress for The Awakening, Brockley Jack (2016).

She is a founding member of feminist arts collective ‘Sexy Lamp Society’ and hosts sex worker community events at local strip joints including ‘Sleazy Virtue’, encouraging women to share experiences, skills and secrets.

Bethany Pitts (director) is Artistic Director of the MolinoGroup, Associate Director of Poleroid Theatre and a freelance director specialising in new work, both scripted and devised. She is passionate about creating exhilarating live theatre that wears its politics on its sleeve. Recent credits include Brutal Cessation by Milly Thomas (Assembly Edinburgh / Theatre 503) Spine by Clara Brennan (Soho Theatre & UK Tour – Fringe First & Herald Angel award 2014), Tether by Isley Lynn (Underbelly Edinburgh) and Free Fall by Vinay Patel (Pleasance Theatre – Nominated for Off West End Award for Best Director). She was previously Assistant Director at Theatre Royal Plymouth and Resident Assistant Director at Theatre503.

Kitt Proudfoot (live sound artist) is a headlining DJ who regularly features up and down the country in the UK House scene, principally at London’s Dover Street Arts Club. Since his first season in 2009, Kitt has held Balearic summer residencies including sets at SPACE, Blue Marlin, Atzaro, Nassau & Zoo. After a residency at Shoreditch House, London, he’s now based at Berlin's Soho House, all while flying around the globe fuelling dance floors with his eclectic, intuitive and artful sets. Kitt’s also an actor, producer, presenter and creative consultant.

Cathy Keen (executive producer) is a founding sister of The Sisterhood, a non-profit online community and magazine for femme identifying sex workers. Cathy is an ex-stripper and events manager within the dating app industry. She has been the driving force behind many sex and sex worker positive events in London and a champion of female sexual freedom. Fuck You Pay Me is proudly supported by The Sisterhood.

Jules Orcullo (producer) is a Filipina Australian theatre maker and producer across theatre, film and music. Works for theatre include: May Utang (Theatre Absolute, 2017), phroot sahlad (Lyric Hammersmith, The North Wall Arts Centre, Camden People’s Theatre, 2017), Look, See (Theatre Royal Stratford East, 2017) and Arc (Theatre Absolute, 2016). She is an alumna of programmes at The Royal Court, The Lyric Hammersmith, Soho Theatre, Belgrade Theatre, The North Wall Arts Centre, Yellow Earth Theatre, Playwriting Australia and the Australian Theatre for Young People. Jules is currently producing the upcoming earth. ocean. ancestors. programmes for makers from Australia, New Zealand and the Pacific Islands. Fuck You Pay Me is the first collaboration between Joana Nastari and The Joy Offensive, Jules’ new performance production banner.
story_txt:
B is a first generation Brazilian girl living in London at home with her Mum and her two sisters. She’s got the worst hangover of her life, she’s been out all night, and she doesn’t want to go home and face the consequences last night: when over the loud music of a night club, her sisters find out that she’s working at a stripclub… or do they?
Fuck You Pay Me is coming to Platform Southwark in November 2017 and this is why you gotta know about it:
Real reactions from audience who saw us at Brainchild Festival this year:
“A gripping insight into the world of stripping. Authentic, high energy and hilarious, beautifully performed. There's no show like it.”
"Joana's performance at Brainchild blew my mind and deepened my understanding of the paradoxes, ambiguities, and tragedies of life while making me laugh so much at them with her. Magnetic, genuine and funny as fuck."
This project started out as a gut response to a city that only seemed to think about strippers in one of … what, four? ways? “Strippers got a tonne of money. Strippers got absolutely no money. Strippers got trafficked. Strippers run on coke, pink champagne and £50 notes alone. Strippers got daddy issues.”
For a little while I was wired on thinking, exploring and divining, and over the last year, I tested it as a play, as a stand up set, as poetry, as dance, as music, as visual art. Now I’ve got something good going, it’s called Fuck You Pay Me: 60 minutes of joy, mess, laughter and good vibes for and about our dear n darling stripper sisters. Fuck You Pay Me transcends the happy-hooker tragedy porn narrative in the media we are bored to tears with and now we’re ready to share it with you ... if you’d just throw a tiny bit of cash at us ;)
What we need
We need 8K. That sounds like a shittonne, but we don’t agree with the idea of artists working for free (do you?). We want to pay our collaborators industry minimum, so for your money and their time, we’re going to make something bangin’ that'll prick some bigwig ears, not just a jolly for my Mum to pat me on the back for then take me for a Pad Thai after, you feel me?
If you're curious, this is the breakdown:
Equipment hire (lights, sound and music, including rehearsal): £4850
Production design and lighting design consultant: £610
Production (set, props, costume): £550
Marketing and publicity (photography, graphic design, production budgets for online collateral): £1270
Technical staff: £170
Music licensing: £110
Insurance, venue running and contingency: £390
Our rehearsal space and venue has been provided by our mates at Platform Southwark. We like Platform Southwark. Shit like that would usually cost around £3500, so they’ve saved a bit for you.
Becoming a patron for Fuck You Pay Me would mean our artists (all 12 of us) get paid. (Mmm, money.) It means we’ll bring the dopest minds together to make properly good theatre about outness and sex and work. If we exceed our target, we’ll programme some sick acts to accompany our show on 14-15 November and the night will that bit more memorable for your midweek. Your cash will be the difference between stop and go with this project. So, let’s do it. Go, go.
Other ways to help
Do you know other people and communities who might spend a dime on us? Share this page with them and get them to contribute. Cash money is the priority. But further down the line if you want to see the show or do some retweets or something, follow us on Twitter for more of that: @JoanaNastari #FYPMshow #FYPM.
Who are we?
Joana Nastari (writer/performer) is a Brazilian British actress, playwright and theatremaker based in London. Recently, her work's been performed across the UK including The Pleasance, Platform Southwark, Brainchild Festival and The Lyric Hammersmith. Joana has gone on to work with makers such as Simon Stephens, Sean Holmes, Steph O’Driscoll, Steve Marmion, Glenn Waldron, Roy Alexander Weise, Simon Russell-Beale and Joe Murphy, and was most recently nominated for a Broadway World award for Best Actress for The Awakening, Brockley Jack (2016).
She is a founding member of feminist arts collective ‘Sexy Lamp Society’ and hosts sex worker community events at local strip joints including ‘Sleazy Virtue’, encouraging women to share experiences, skills and secrets.
Bethany Pitts (director) is Artistic Director of the MolinoGroup, Associate Director of Poleroid Theatre and a freelance director specialising in new work, both scripted and devised. She is passionate about creating exhilarating live theatre that wears its politics on its sleeve. Recent credits include Brutal Cessation by Milly Thomas (Assembly Edinburgh / Theatre 503) Spine by Clara Brennan (Soho Theatre & UK Tour – Fringe First & Herald Angel award 2014), Tether by Isley Lynn (Underbelly Edinburgh) and Free Fall by Vinay Patel (Pleasance Theatre – Nominated for Off West End Award for Best Director). She was previously Assistant Director at Theatre Royal Plymouth and Resident Assistant Director at Theatre503.
Kitt Proudfoot (live sound artist) is a headlining DJ who regularly features up and down the country in the UK House scene, principally at London’s Dover Street Arts Club. Since his first season in 2009, Kitt has held Balearic summer residencies including sets at SPACE, Blue Marlin, Atzaro, Nassau & Zoo. After a residency at Shoreditch House, London, he’s now based at Berlin's Soho House, all while flying around the globe fuelling dance floors with his eclectic, intuitive and artful sets. Kitt’s also an actor, producer, presenter and creative consultant.
Cathy Keen (executive producer) is a founding sister of The Sisterhood, a non-profit online community and magazine for femme identifying sex workers. Cathy is an ex-stripper and events manager within the dating app industry. She has been the driving force behind many sex and sex worker positive events in London and a champion of female sexual freedom. Fuck You Pay Me is proudly supported by The Sisterhood.
Jules Orcullo (producer) is a Filipina Australian theatre maker and producer across theatre, film and music. Works for theatre include: May Utang (Theatre Absolute, 2017), phroot sahlad (Lyric Hammersmith, The North Wall Arts Centre, Camden People’s Theatre, 2017), Look, See (Theatre Royal Stratford East, 2017) and Arc (Theatre Absolute, 2016). She is an alumna of programmes at The Royal Court, The Lyric Hammersmith, Soho Theatre, Belgrade Theatre, The North Wall Arts Centre, Yellow Earth Theatre, Playwriting Australia and the Australian Theatre for Young People. Jules is currently producing the upcoming earth. ocean. ancestors. programmes for makers from Australia, New Zealand and the Pacific Islands. Fuck You Pay Me is the first collaboration between Joana Nastari and The Joy Offensive, Jules’ new performance production banner.

story:
What is this? 

  • A production & performance team of people of color, womxn, non-binary, and queer folks. 
  • “So Lucky” is a play about Penelope Huang, an Asian American woman attempting to plan her city’s first Lunar New Year Festival. As she plans the festival and grapples with a difficult autobiographical writing assignment, she begins to reflect on her relationships with her friends, her community, and her estranged mother.
  • Our founders hope to make art with the intention of fostering a culture of empathy, inclusivity, and creating space for those who come after us. 

 

Why is this important? 

So often in the arts, we see Asian/Asian American characters written and directed by people who aren't us. Representation isn't empowering when it's not actually your voice doing the speaking. Our show gives local Asian/Asian Americans the agency to be our own voice in talking about the issues within our community.

The show explores contemporary Asian American issues including mental health, intergenerational differences, cultural identity and pride, community organizing, and growing up. We are proud and excited to have a cast of primarily Asian/Asian American performers with many different backgrounds.

 

What do we need money for?

There aren't enough performance spaces in Austin, and the few that are available have costs that are prohibitive to us. As a baby duckling of a theatre organization, we could use all the help we can get to pay for a space.

Also! We would like to pay our cast and crew! Everyone is working extremely hard on this project and artists should always be paid for their work.

From building sets to costuming, make-up, lighting and sound, feeding people, etc., we've got a lot of people we don't want doing unpaid labor. There are many more costs and fees along the way, but we'll spare you the details about how we need to get empty boba cups or a bed on stage.

The Team

Other Ways You Can Help

We totally understand that not everyone can donate to our production at the moment. Luckily, there are lots of other ways you can help us bring local, original theatre to life:

  • Link/share/talk about us to people who you think might be interested in supporting us. It may not seem like a lot, but every single mention of us breaks us out of our own social circles and lets more people know we & the show exist! 
  • Contact us to donate props or set pieces, tell us about low-cost rehearsal spaces in Austin, or lend us your expertise in tech, lighting, or sound. From moral support to a helping hand, we'd love to hear from you regardless.
  • If you know us personally, please feed us- we are hungry in addition to sad
  • Like and keep up with us on Facebook: facebook.com/SadGirlsProductions/
  • Help us beat the algorithm by liking our instagram posts: @sadgirlsproductions
  • See what our production team is tweeting: @sadgirlspro

Thank you so much!

If you have any questions, want to work with us, or would like to get involved in a way not listed above, we can be reached at: sadgirlsproductions@gmail.com.

story:
Short Summary

After a car accident, world-famous reality star Simone Sultana ends up with a disfigured face. Her momager, Sandra, decides to put a golden mask over her daughter’s injuries to save Simone’s beauty and, more importantly, the family’s brand. The mask becomes an overnight phenomenon. The Sultanas are celebrated as cultural icons! But trouble comes when the mask causes a deadly infection. Sandra now must find a way to make sure the family’s fame lasts forever.

Filled with absurd characters whose only desire is popularity, this darkly comedic satire explores our 21st-century obsession with reality TV and instant fame.

The show has 5 performances at the Stephanie Feury Studio Theatre in Los Angeles. Performance dates and times are:

  • 6/3 @ 9pm
  • 6/8 @ 7:30pm
  • 6/13 @ 3:00pm
  • 6/16 @ 4:30pm
  • 6/23 @ 10pm

What We Need & What You Get

The funds we raise will go to paying for advertisement, props, and set pieces. This is an approximate breakdown of how we will spend the money:

  • $500- social media, internet, and print advertisements
  • $300- set pieces
  • $200- props and costumes

Perks include a special thanks in the program, tickets to see the show, and more! 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please come support us by seeing the show! Tickets can be purchased here: http://www.hollywoodfringe.org/projects/5037

Also, please share our campaign with your friends!

story:
BAKERY HILL – AN AUSTRALIAN REBELLION

 

Who Are We?

 

We are Yellow Line Productions, a not-for-profit association dedicated to telling original Australian stories through musical theatre.

For we believe that the telling of our stories, in a musically creative context, is the ultimate expression of our connection to ourselves and our culture.

 

Founded in 2019, our vision is to create and connect Australians with the captivating and unique stories that shaped us as a people, a culture and a nation and then share those stories with the world.

                                                                                

Through YLP we intend to create a platform that allows and facilitates the telling of all Australian stories from all perspectives, ethnicities and backgrounds.

We believe that only through diversity, can we truly encompass the depth and scope of our Australian stories.

 

 

About Bakery Hill:

Bakery Hill – An Australian Rebellion is a new and original musical and is the flagship production for Yellow Line.

The show conveys the dramatic and moving account of the people and events of the Eureka Rebellion in 1854.

It is a story that many Australians are familiar with, some riotous male diggers stand up to an oppressive government and sacrifice their lives for liberty and freedom.

 

A classic and cliché revolutionary story wouldn’t you think?

 

What if I told you that most Australians know less than a quarter of the story and even that quarter doesn’t convey the whole truth.

What if you knew that a number of women fought alongside the men at Eureka?
What if you knew that to this day, their names are not recorded nor remembered?

What if you knew that the diggers were representatives of every continent on earth; every creed, class and colour standing together?

What if you knew that only a single person who died was actually born in Australia?

Would these facts challenge what you think you know about the story?

 

Until we began the research and creation of this story, we were all where you are now.

 

We have a story to tell; brimming with depth and detail, challenging and retelling the narrative, remembering and exhuming the lost and forgotten.

Does it still feel like a cliché revolutionary story? Do you feel like it is still a story you know?

Let us take you to Bakery Hill and under the light of the Southern Cross we will tell you what really happened.

 

Why We Need You?

 

We genuinely believe that Bakery Hill is a story that needs to be told, but like those at Eureka, we cannot do it alone.

 

The effects of Covid-19 have impacted our ability to fundraise, cut our potential ticket sales by 50% and increased our costs due to the requirement for PPE and various precautionary measures to rehearse and perform safely.

 

Despite the challenges presented by Covid-19, we believe that live theatre connects us all in a time when many have felt disconnected, brings us together in a time when many feel isolated and gives purpose to the thousands of artists and creatives who have felt lost and adrift due to the wide ranging effects of Covid-19.

We feel like there has never been a more crucial time to reconnect, rebuild and share our stories with each other.

 

With your help and support we will can:

 

  • Provide crucial work and opportunities for many creatives.
  • Provide Bakery Hill - An Australian Rebellion as an educational resource for students & schools across NSW and Australia to assist educators & students in connecting with content surrounding the Eureka Rebellion.
  • Support venues to provide financial assistance through bookings and ticket sales.
  • Provide meaningful, quality connection, cultural experience and entertainment for the general public.
  • Share this important story from our past, a story that bears great relevance to our modern society, politics and culture.
  • Through collaboration and cross promotion, encourage and foster the recovery of the arts and many affiliated industries.

 

 

How We Plan To Use Your Donation:

 

We are looking to raise a total of $7,000 AUD.

These funds will allow us to expand the quality and duration of our production season resulting in the following:

 

  • A full studio recording of the production with the original cast which can then be made available to you, the public and as a resource for others who wish to produce the production in the future.
  • The funds raised will allow us to produce high quality and historically accurate props and costumes to museum level quality, producing the most truthful and educational rendition of the story to date. 
  • A complete video recording of the final production. The funds raised will go a long way to allowing us to produce a professional video recording of the live performance which we can use as promotion for future Yellow Line projects, as a resource for others wishing to produce the production and as a potential means of sharing the show with audience member who may miss out due to Covid-19 restrictions.
  • Due to restricted funds and the impacts of Covid-19, Bakery Hill is currently set to run for a limited season of 5 shows. With additional funding we have the option of extending the production season or hosting a second season.
  • Your donations will assist us in providing the safest possible environment for our personnel and for our audiences by allowing us to invest in the best quality personal protective equipment (PPE), disinfectant products and safety measures.
  • If we raise over our target amount, we will have the option of hosting a specialised educational season for primary and secondary students. Assisting students in a range of subjects including; History, English and Drama to better understand and connect with the story of Bakery Hill and learn about the full creative process. This will be achieved through curated Q&A sessions after each show with the cast and creatives.

 

Every donation made will help us provide more work for creatives and tell both the story of Bakery Hill and future stories to the quality and standard that they, and you, deserve.

 

The Challenges

 

The primary challenge we need to overcome is the unforeseeable impacts of Covid-19.

No one has to ability to know what the future will hold for April 2021 and although taking every precaution and preparation we cannot predict the unpredictable.

 

So here are some of the things we are doing to help keep all of us and your investment safe:

 

  • Open and regular consultation with our venue – Through a strong venue relationship we are able to continuously assess the situation and risks to preserve the financial interests of all involved.
  • If the production is required to cancel or delay to align with restrictions, we have an extensive system of asset protection and storage. This means that almost all of the material we create for the show (set, props, costumes, promotional materials) can be stored at no cost and reused at a later date to mitigate the financial impact.
  • If you wish to learn all about how we are managing the risks of Covid-19 you can view our Covid-19 Safety Plan on the Yellow Line Theatre website.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

 

Now more than ever before we can understand that people may not have the spare funds to donate to the arts.

Don’t let that get you down because there are so many ways that you can help and support us if you like, and or, believe in our project.

 

  • Sharing this fundraiser and our project with all your family, friends and colleagues. 
  • Following us on all our socials (Facebook, Instagram, Youtube).
  • Coming to see the incredible show that is Bakery Hill – An Australian Rebellion.
  • Supporting all independent arts organisations, it’s not just about us.

 

We cannot thank you enough for all of your interest and support, not just in our project but in the repair and recovery of the whole arts industry.

 

Thank you

story:
TBD's OTHELLO is a psychological thriller that probes our deeply held anxieties about what we call ours: our loved ones, our reputations, and our positions in society.  We're aiming to capture what Shakespeare set out to create: a lean, visceral, gut-punch of a tragedy.


OTHELLO is Shakespeare at the peak of his powers in terms of characters and language, but working in a highly concentrated and potent form.  And the way the play unfurls produces a particular effect on us as audience members: the door closes behind us but we don’t mind.  Then the walls start to close in.  We’re having a perfectly lovely time when we suddenly realize its time to go - but it's too late. We've invested and identified ourselves with these characters, and as the tragic consequences of their actions play out, there is a reckoning: how do we, as humans, account for our very human experience of pride, jealousy, and possessiveness?

The Brewing Dept. found this approach through our long-term commitment to developing the work of our artists.  In August of 2014, director Thomas Kapusta set about editing Shakespeare's text, chronicling his experience and decisions in a series of articles on our website.  In November of that year, TBD held a workshop of the play at the Alchemical Theatre: our production this fall continues that work, fully realizing our artists' vision of this gripping piece of theater,

Please consider making a donation to support this new look at Shakespeare's classic tragedy. Contributions of all sizes are welcome and vital to ensure that our upcoming production of Othello can be seen and experienced by the greater New York audience. 

Thank you so much for your interest and support!

                                               


Featuring: Thomas Brazzle*, Raquel Chavez, Alex Dabertin, Ryan George*, Thomas Kapusta, Brian LaPerche, Matthew McShane, Jefferson Reardon, and Jenny Vallancourt*

Assistant Directed by Tara Pacheco, Original Music by Kathryn Hathaway, Lighting by Luc Michel, Sets and Graphic Design by Stephen Davan, Costumes by Ilana Breitman, Sound by Benjamin Weiner, Press & Marketing by Diana Levy, and General Management by Fortress Productions.

* - Appears courtesy of Actors' Equity Association; Equity Approved Showcase
The Brewing Dept. is a fiscally sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a nonprofit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of The Brewing Dept. must be made payable to Fractured Atlas and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.
story_txt:
TBD's OTHELLO is a psychological thriller that probes our deeply held anxieties about what we call ours: our loved ones, our reputations, and our positions in society.  We're aiming to capture what Shakespeare set out to create: a lean, visceral, gut-punch of a tragedy.

OTHELLO is Shakespeare at the peak of his powers in terms of characters and language, but working in a highly concentrated and potent form.  And the way the play unfurls produces a particular effect on us as audience members: the door closes behind us but we don’t mind.  Then the walls start to close in.  We’re having a perfectly lovely time when we suddenly realize its time to go - but it's too late. We've invested and identified ourselves with these characters, and as the tragic consequences of their actions play out, there is a reckoning: how do we, as humans, account for our very human experience of pride, jealousy, and possessiveness?
The Brewing Dept. found this approach through our long-term commitment to developing the work of our artists.  In August of 2014, director Thomas Kapusta set about editing Shakespeare's text, chronicling his experience and decisions in a series of articles on our website.  In November of that year, TBD held a workshop of the play at the Alchemical Theatre: our production this fall continues that work, fully realizing our artists' vision of this gripping piece of theater,

Please consider making a donation to support this new look at Shakespeare's classic tragedy. Contributions of all sizes are welcome and vital to ensure that our upcoming production of Othello can be seen and experienced by the greater New York audience. 
Thank you so much for your interest and support!
                                               
Featuring: Thomas Brazzle*, Raquel Chavez, Alex Dabertin, Ryan George*, Thomas Kapusta, Brian LaPerche, Matthew McShane, Jefferson Reardon, and Jenny Vallancourt*
Assistant Directed by Tara Pacheco, Original Music by Kathryn Hathaway, Lighting by Luc Michel, Sets and Graphic Design by Stephen Davan, Costumes by Ilana Breitman, Sound by Benjamin Weiner, Press & Marketing by Diana Levy, and General Management by Fortress Productions.* - Appears courtesy of Actors' Equity Association; Equity Approved Showcase
The Brewing Dept. is a fiscally sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a nonprofit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of The Brewing Dept. must be made payable to Fractured Atlas and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

story:
The day of the first preview of RENT Off-Broadway, Jonathan Larson passed away. The young composer never saw his work become the legacy it is today, or even saw it open on Broadway. 

But before RENT, Larson worked on a one-man show about his struggle to balance his dreams of composing with his ties to friends and lovers. After his death, the show was re-written as a three-person musical, produced off-Broadway, and came to be known as tick, tick... BOOM! 

2016 marks the 20th anniversary of Larson's passing and to honor his legacy, After Hours Theatre  is producing his work at The Hudson Theatre in Hollywood. 

Jonathan Larson's rock infused musical style changed the face of Broadway. RENT paved the way for a new kind of diversity on stage, and brought the AIDS epidemic to the forefront of 90's theater. tick, tick...BOOM! chronicles the journey of an aspiring composer struggling to balance the pursuit of a dream with the pressures of everyday life on the eve of his thirtieth birthday. It is a story that resonates not just with artists, but with anyone who has ever fought to achieve a dream.

With your contribution, After Hours Theatre can produce tick tick...BOOM!  to  honor Jonathan Larson's life and legacy, bring awareness to HIV/AIDS, and empower young artists in Los Angeles and beyond.

story:
Wrestleslam II: Wrestlevania

When PWR began, we made an oath. We swore that no matter how insane our events were, every year we had would have a WRESTLESLAM that would top all of them. With your help, we have been able to have some spectacular times. PWR has become, arguably, the largest, regular free event in Austin. Over 900 of us gathered together to shout for wrestling at Winter Wonderslam. How could our second Wrestleslam possibly up the ante? Try this on for size.

Our only corporate sponsor, HELLSPORT INC, has decided to transform our venue into a castle. Not only that, but a haunted castle. Don’t put those Draculas away just yet...Spring time can be just as terrifying as Winter (albeit warmer)! This castle be filled with vanquished souls, skeletons, and ever-flowing green ooze! We can’t think of a better place to showcase a PARTYWEIGHT BELT SHOWDOWN!

That’s right - our first one-on-one title match in NEARLY A YEAR will decide PWR’s greatest champion. If Dan “the Man” Ziggler wins, we can count on him bringing to bear his corporate sponsors onto PWR. He'll definitely sabotage the thing we all love with his corrupt influence!

The cryogenic survivor from colonial times, Theodosia, is our last chance at preserving the spirit of PWR.

Help us keep our community-supported organization alive as we actively eschew nasty corporate sponsors. Er, except for Hellsport Global Inc. Hellsport is a great corporation!

Also, look forward to the conclusions of important battle-stories involving Pasta Man, Luigi Primo, the Dumpster Babes, Dazza Longbarrel, Kippy, Chad Blitz, Chubby Uncle Juan, the Intergalactic Express, Noisebot, Hot Dog and more! ALL UNRESOLVED TITLES WILL BE CHALLENGED! NEW TITLES WILL BE INTRODUCED! PARTY VIOLENCE WILL REIGN!



What We Need and What You Get

$5000 is a lot of money! What’s it going toward?

First, an important declaration: PWR is free and we want to keep it free. PWR is for everyone, even if they can't afford to pay cover at a show. We'd like to keep from having to charge admission for as long as we can.

However, PWR is now a 70-person organization putting on a show for 1000 people. One thundo! Increased expectations beget increased (and wholly worthwhile) costs: we spent just north of $6660 (this number is real) to create WINTER WONDERSLAM.  

New for this campaign is profit sharing. After a show cycle, we'll reconcile our expenses (including investments in our savings accounts) and all revenues. 20% of the delta will be re-invested in PWR. The remaining 80% will be split evenly across all performers. This further horizontalizes our organization and means that your support on our Indiegogo not only keeps our league running, it can go directly to the folks you see in the ring.

Some of the cool things your donations have let us do include:

  • Decorations and props. We have an extremely talented team of designers who transform the venue into an art piece by using garbage. 4th Tap was turned into a GOURD-FILLED WINTERMAS WONDERLAND by their selfless capable hands. Though most of our resources are scavenged from trash bins and thrift stores, filling a venue of our size with cool decorations—and the storage to keep them preserved show after show!—costs money.

  • Safe space/security: PWR is a party for everyone. Our performers have always followed anti-sexist/homophobic/transphobic/racist guidelines, and we wanted to make sure that comfort extends to our audience. We’re proud of our security phone line. Any member of the audience may use this number to report gross behavior at the show, and we resolve the problem, no questions asked. Your support lets us keep reaching toward a goal of ULTIMATE PARTY VIOLENCE for everyone.

  • Ring repairs. Have you seen our ring recently? It’s WILD WITH SPLENDOR! We have new robes, new pads, new turnbuckles, and thirteen extremely heavy steel beams which keep us safe and sound as we fall down and over and over again.

For transparency: this Indiegogo doesn’t cover all of adolescent PWR’s expenses, but it takes care of a majority of them. Below is our complete budget.

Show Expense

WV Budget

Decorations

$650

Props

$350

Video editing

$300

Deco team pay

$300

Promo materials

$200

Security

$125

Misc

$100

Day of Show Food

$50

Subtotal

$2,075


Show Expense

WV Budget

Full-Time Employee Pay

$1,200

Emergency Savings Account

$800

New Projects Capital

$700

Performer Assistance Fund

$420

Discretionary Show Expenses

$400

Event insurance

$370

Ring Maintenance

$300

Ring Payment

$300

Training

200

Subtotal

$4,690

Covering these costs with donations ensures we don't need to have a door charge for the shows and can keep them FREE.


Extremely Hype Swag

Here we'll post photos of some of the stuff you can get by supporting us.

Here's the design for our donor t-shirt by PWR powerman Zeke Guadiana. The only way to lock down on this bad boy is through our Indiegogo—it's an insanely powerful badge of honor for making the WRESTLEVANIA dream real.

The donor hoodie features this design on on the back with the PWR logo on the front.





Stuffed Wrestlfriends

PWR Prayer Candles


Timmy Quivers Bobblehead (Baron Zahkey proof of concept)



Risks & Challenges

Challenges:

PWR has become robust and its universe swole with powerful party drama. As it continues to grow wantonly like an uncontrollable teen (and our expectations for our performance climb) we approach a new realm of costs we could not have imagined before.  We are depending on the support of our Multiverse to keep our show free and open—thank you for your continued support.  Rest assured we are working night and day to make sure this event is the most fun thing you do all quarter.


Risks:

The only risk is the risk of not partying hard enough. We laugh at the concept of "risk." It is as outmoded as "shame," or "weakness." We have sworn to party 'til death, and we will do so.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you don't want to donate money you can help us by getting the word out about this campaign and/or just word out about PWR and WRESTLESLAM II: WRESTLEVANIA.


Here is the Facebook event page: https://www.facebook.com/events/1541837162797155/

story:
Résumé du projet:

QUI SOMMES-NOUS?

CréActifs est une compagnie de théâtre créée par Julien Blais en 2015 pour qui l’envie de fonder cette plateforme artistique a émergé du constat que l’aspect « production » est souvent absent des activités culturelles de loisirs. Notre approche part du principe que c’est à travers le regard d’un public que l’acte créateur prend véritablement son sens et devient ainsi un acquis réel pour le participant. Nous cherchons à mettre l’accent non pas sur une démarche simplement récréative plutôt que créative et proactive. En effet, le mandat de CréActifs est d’être ouvert à tout participant en quête de créativité et de leur donner les outils, la structure et le support nécessaires pour nourrir celle-ci, non seulement à travers l’acquisition de « compétences » artistiques, mais, aussi et surtout, en développant un sentiment d’accomplissement par l’aboutissement d’un projet complet. Cette année, Julien a passé le flambeau de la production à Anne-Marie St-Louis, une jeune metteure en scène émergente dans le domaine du théâtre d’intervention.

Les objectif d’Anne-Marie?

  • De faire de l’art qui déconstruit les notions préconçues de représentation, de culture et d’identité
  • de concevoir la performance comme un acte de revendication et de résistance puissant, provocateur et poétique
  • de s’investir dans les communautés
  • d’utiliser des formes interdisciplinaires, communautaires et non-hierarchiques
  •  d’engager et jouer avec le public, plutôt que simplement pour le divertissement du public. 

QUE FAIT-ON?

En début mai 2017, CréActifs présentera le projet ÉCLOSE: une réécriture iconoclaste et post-moderne de 3 pièces qui traitent toutes de la représentation des femmes et de leur désir de se définir elles-mêmes. Projet intertextuel et interdisciplinaire par dessus tout, la production cherchera à mêler les genres d’expression (cinéma, danse et performance art) et à composer des scènes développées à partir de nos recherches dramaturgiques et improvisations, tout cela afin de raconter trois histoires de cloisonnement et d'éclose dans un labyrinthe des sens tout à fait unique. Nous occuperons le sous-sol de l'église St-Denis et l’idée sera  de se servir pleinement de ces lieux non conventionnels de représentation pour dire de nouvelles choses et développer de nouvelles dynamiques entre spectateurs et comédiens.


Avec :
Robin Abdo, Léa Bégis, Éléonore Brieuc, Maëlle Campagnie, Alexis Curodeau-Codère, Chloé Désiré, Gwenn Duval, Yseult Gibert, Alice Hinchliffe, Samita Mandjee et Clara-Marie Nasser.​

Ce dont nous avons besoin: 

Un tel projet encourt évidemment des dépenses considérables pour des étudiants à revenu modique. Nombreux parmi nous sommes des artistes qui contribuons plus de 10 heures par semaine à ce projet sans rémunération pour notre travail. C’est pour cette raison que nous sollicitons votre aide! Cette contribution de votre part ajouterait de la valeur à notre spectacle, ce qui attirerait un plus grand public et faciliterait la possibilité que le spectacle soit remonté. Votre contribution irait vers l'achat de matériaux pour les décors et costumes qui sont essentiels à la réalisation de notre vision. Enfin, votre contribution nous permettrait également d’acheter nourriture, boissons et décorations afin de créer l’événement communautaire qui précèderait le spectacle et qu'il nous est à cœur d’offrir aux citoyens de Montréal.

Cela dit, si nous ne parvenons pas à notre objectif visé de 1000$, les fonds seront mis vers la location de la salle car notre priorité est d'aboutir notre projet afin qu'artistes et spectateurs puissent se rencontrer, se questionner et formuler ensemble une vision d'un monde meilleur.

Pour vous remercier de votre implication et de votre générosité, nous sommes prêts à vous faire parvenir par courrier ou en personne quelques petites surprises originales! Cliquez dans l’onglet de droite pour en savoir plus.

L'impact de votre contribution :

En contribuant à cette campagne, vous soutenez une troupe d'étudiants montréalais qui cherchent à rêver et créer ensemble, vous soutenez du théâtre qui est non seulement nouveau mais novateur, qui veut promouvoir une égalité sociale diverse, qui veut reconnaître la puissance libératrice des individus qui choisissent de se définir eux-même. Vous soutenez des artistes qui travaillent fort, qui prennent conscience du monde dans lequel ils vivent et veulent éveiller cette conscience chez les autres.

Les risques et défis :

Nous sommes une compagnie qui commençons sur la scène montréalaise mais qui cherche justement à être ouverte et prendre des risques: à essayer de nouvelles choses, à expérimenter de nouvelles formes... Le théâtre nous passionne et si nous n'avons pas les réponses à tout nous nous forçons à poser les bonnes questions. 

Le principal défi de notre travail est de le faire volontairement. Comme nous ne sommes pas soutenus par un théâtre établi, nous devons, en plus de passer du temps dans les répétitions, trouver une salle de représentation adéquate, créer nos propres campagnes de publicité et de sensibilisation et trouver nos propres subventions. Ce n'est pas toujours facile d'équilibrer notre vision idéale avec la réalité concrète de notre situation financière !

Comment nous aider autrement :

Nous apprécions énormément votre intérêt pour notre troupe et notre projet! C'est entièrement grâce a vous, grâce à votre participation, à vos "likes" sur Facebook et à votre encouragement que nous arrivons à progresser et présenter une production finale sur la scène Montréalaise. 

Si vous êtes incapables de faire un don financier mais cherchez d'autres manières de vous impliquer avec CréActifs, soyez rassurés que nous avons quelques options alternatives. 

Vous pouvez par exemple:

  • partager notre lien indiegogo avec d'autres
  • aimer notre page Facebook
  • parler de notre production imminente a vos proches
  • surtout, vous pouvez nous soutenir en vous joignant aux festivités communautaires du 4 au 7 mai 2017!

Pour plus d'information sur la compagnie CreActifs, vous pouvez consultez notre site web a l’adresse suivante : http://creactifs.net/

Comme nous ne sommes pas soutenus par un théâtre établi, nous devons, en plus de passer du temps dans les répétitions, trouver une salle de représentation adéquate, créer nos propres campagnes de publicité et de sensibilisation et trouver nos propres subventions. Ce n'est pas toujours facile d'équilibrer notre vision idéale avec la réalité concrète de notre situation financière !
Comment nous aider autrement :

Nous apprécions énormément votre intérêt pour notre troupe et notre projet! C'est entièrement grâce a vous, grâce à votre participation, à vos "likes" sur Facebook et à votre encouragement que nous arrivons à progresser et présenter une production finale sur la scène Montréalaise. 
Si vous êtes incapables de faire un don financier mais cherchez d'autres manières de vous impliquer avec CréActifs, soyez rassurés que nous avons quelques options alternatives. 
Vous pouvez par exemple:

partager notre lien indiegogo avec d'autres
aimer notre page Facebook
parler de notre production imminente a vos proches
surtout, vous pouvez nous soutenir en vous joignant aux festivités communautaires du 4 au 7 mai 2017!

Pour plus d'information sur la compagnie CreActifs, vous pouvez consultez notre site web a l’adresse suivante : http://creactifs.net/

story:
Short Summary

 

  • We, Kimberly and Michael, are film and stage actors local to Atlanta. We are self producing Nick Payne's "Constellations" at Indigo Yoga Studio in Kirkwood, greater Atlanta area. We would greatly appreciate any contributions to help make this non-linear show a unique theatrical experience for everyone involved. Producing live theatre can be an expensive process and we want to approach this theatre piece in a challenging way that has never been done before by combining the artistic visions of over 12 local Atlanta directors to depict multiple universes.  Any help you can offer would be reciprocated with all the perks listed that we are personally providing as a token of our gratitude. We hope this play will challenge minds, touch hearts, and at the very least get people talking about new ways to perform theatre in Atlanta. 

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • We need a few basic things to make this show happen and then after that everything else will be icing on the cake.
  • 1) we need to pay for the rights in order to actually do the show.
  • 2) We need to pay for lights and pay for a set design that is aligned with each director's vision.
  • 3) We need enough money for posters and programs 
  • 4) We need to pay for comfortable seating and risers
  • Our perks are personal lessons, and services using our unique gifts, and abilities. Kimberly, a certified yoga instructor is offering yoga lessons, guided meditations, energy healing, singing lessons and pottery lessons. Michael, a certified chess instructor, is offering lessons in chess and tennis. All of these perks are intended to empower, teach, heal, and enrich the lives of our donors. We are also offering fun options such scavenger hunts in Kirkwood and healthy kombucha beverages. 
  • Anyone who buys a ticket will also get a discounted $5 yoga class at Indigo Yoga Studio.
  • We are very passionate about this play and committed to making it happen so if we don't reach our entire goal, we will prioritize expenses based on the list above as ordered and put on the best show we can with whatever money have.

The Impact

We hope our show will impact the lives of audience members in a profound way that will stimulate conversations and new ideas. We hope our performance will inspire creative artists in Atlanta to produce more art that touches lives in a unique and positive way.

Risks & Challenges

The non-linear writing is a fabulous challenge. We are taking risks by working with over 12 collaborating directors to create one cohesive theme. Given that the show is a two hander, it is a personal challenge for us as actors to bring so many different perspectives to life within one play. The play delves into sensitive topics like brain cancer, Glioblastoma multiforme, assisted suicide and controversial theories like the "Multiverse" theory.

Other Ways You Can Help

A humble donation of just 1$ would mean a lot to us. Every little bit counts. But if you can't afford to contribute monetarily, please use the Indiegogo share tools and share our campaign on social media

story:
Short Summary

We are unamused theatre, an eclectic group of young theatre makers in Dublin who need a bit of help to make theatre. We are writers, directors, designers actors and producers. We are your friends and neighbours. 

Our play is a response to the ever-growing rental crisis in Dublin, specifically its affect on the ''millennial'' generation. It's a fresh, absurd approach playing on the hilarity of the situation to highlight an often quite sinister reality for young people in Dublin. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise 1000 euro beans to make sure our wonderful production goes off without a hitch.

 

Once raised your money will help our wonderfully talented design team create a beautiful stage to look at, full of pretty lights, costumes, props and set designs to sell your granny for!

Rehearsing is going to be important too. Otherwise you'd just be showing up to a pretty stage full of people who don't speak or move. Boring right? Your funding will help us with much needed rehearsal space and keep our cast up to date with the words they should be speaking.

Great, now you know about our show and its funding and we trust you will tell all of your friends. ''But what about all those people who haven't seen this campaign? How are they going to know about your secret but extremely important play?'' I'm glad you asked! Finally we will use our remaining funding to go towards advertising and making sure that we create a network of wonderful audience members who will surely become your new friends after the show. You might even go for a drink with one of these new friends, get their number perhaps? Imagine we were to help you find your life long partner in crime? Essentially this is an investment in your future wedding. Think about it.  Funding us = finding love. Wow! That is such a bargain.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Keep an eye out on social media for fundraising events you are sure to enjoy also!

story:
21/40 Productions is back and rehearsals have begun for our  first full length production, Dog Sees God: Confessions of a Teenage Blockhead.

Our mission is to tell honest and accessible stories. We strive to give our audiences an intimate and unique experience every time they join us and we believe this script fits perfectly into that vision.

Dog Sees God is an “unauthorized parody” of the Peanuts. The kids are all grown up and hardly recognizable.  And of course, Charlie Brown - now CB - is at the center of it all.

The loss of a childhood friend forces our guy into an identity crisis .... Good Grief! … and nobody seems to care. His sister is too busy with drama club, his ex-girlfriend is in lock up, and his friends are too high to help. With nowhere else to turn, he pours his heart out to a piano player – one of the kids he normally bullies – and their friendship has the entire school on edge

This play has so many wonderful things for us to explore … bullying, loss, friendship, drug uses … and it’s all through the lense of these characters that we all thought we knew.

On top of a stellar story, we’ve assembled an incredible cast and booked a really neat and intimate venue for this show, but of course we still need to raise some funds to make this the best production possible. Anything raised will go towards costumes, props, renting set pieces, marketing and paying our actors for the time and effort they’ve dedicated to telling this story. If enough is raised, we would also use some of the funds raised to sponsor a few free performances, or  pay-what-you-can performances. We want to ensure that all members of our community, no matter their circumstances, have the opportunity to see our show.

 

Dog Sees God opens February 23rd at Pinwheel Arts & Movement Studio. For dates and ticket information, check out our website.  We’d love to see you there

story:
We've hit our target but every penny more we receive will help us to pay for costumes, props and travel!  An extra £250 would cover these vital items for our show.  

Our story

Hi, we’re Nikki and Jean-Daniel, and we an acrobatic duo based in London.  Together, we have worked with some of the most influential contemporary circus companies in the UK.  And we are now seeking to create our first 25-minute show. 

With your support, we can create this:

Like Torvill and Dean, Nikki and JD are a duo who perform as star-crossed lovers.  But JD is gay.  And Nikki is a 30-something woman desperate for a meaningful relationship. 

Told using acrobatics, dance and physical theatre, this is a story of two people on a quest for love:  For JD, it’s the quest to deepen and strengthen his relationship with his real lover.  For Nikki, it’s the search for Mr Right through the tedium of endless Tinder profiles and awkward dates. 

As they attempt together to create the perfect performance, they ask what it really takes to make their relationship(s) last. 

We have already secured the generous support of London’s circus sector, including Jacksons Lane and Cirquit Productions, but their contributions will not cover all of the costs - which is why we need you!

We need £1,200 to help pay for an expert director in physical theatre, to help bring our story to life.  With these funds, we can stage our first-ever showing of the piece in February.  To date, we’ve booked the venue, we’ve got in-kind marketing support and rehearsal space, and we’ve received positive feedback to our duets at the UK’s 2015 Canvas Showcase for programmers and producers.   

From two very grateful acrobats, thank you very very much!!  Your support will launch us to new heights!

story:
Who are you people?

West Edge Opera is located in the San Francisco Bay Area. We produce operas for a new audience. We don't do stuffy opera. We re-imagine classics and create new works in order to appeal to non opera fans and expose them to this art form, making them life long opera lovers.

So what's the project?

So glad you asked. Benjamin Britten is turning 100 this year and we wanted to do something special to celebrate. His amazing, haunting opera - The Turn of the Screw is based on the Henry James short story. It’s a psycological thriller that puts the destruction of innocence front and center.

What's the story?

The production will focus on the world of a young governess who slowly goes mad as she tries to protect the children in her charge from evil ghosts. We will live project the images of two opera singers as they perform the music from off stage.

Who's in the show?

Top quality opera singers have been engaged for the production. The Governess is played by Laura Bohn who was first seen as Ariel in our premiere opera: Caliban Dreams. We next presented Laura in our ground breaking production of The Mahagonny Songspiel. You remember her - she was the clown with the tassels on her boobs!  Also in the production are Buffy Baggott, Jillian Khuner and Daniel Curran as the ghostly Peter Quint. 

Aren't there some kids?

OMG! We almost forgot the kids! We have four amazing kids taking on two roles: Miles and Flora. Milo Boland and Emilia Meachum (The blonde cast) and Arman Marchiel and Larkin Barnard Bahn (The brunette cast)  Why have two casts? Well - you never know with kids... Colds happen and we want to be able to be flexible with them.

Why Indiegogo?

Ah, gee! I knew you would ask that. Many of you have been to our theater and have luxuriated in the comfortable seats, air conditioning and easy parking. You have been amazed that such a theater exists at a high school. What you probably haven’t realized is that up until our last production, the theater has been managed at a very low rate by the district headquarters in Richmond, but no longer - our rental fees have more than doubled mid-season. Surprise costs from our last production sprained our budget and we are still feeling the hurt. Your donation will get us in the door once again. We are having to make tough choices because of this and we don’t want to have to make the choice to leave our beautiful theater. Please help.

Please share our campaign with other arts lovers!  See you at the opera!

story:
Re-Build It, And You Will Come

Malibu Playhouse is a 501(c)3 not for profit corporation and was founded in 1991 by theater icon Charles Marowitz and Jackie Bridgeman.  Over the years, the theater has produced many acclaimed productions as well as served as home for two children's theater groups.  Although the initial funding for the theater -- then called Malibu Stage Company -- helped convert a church into a beautiful functioning theater, the difficult economy has seriously impacted donations, and the theater has fallen into disrepair.

We're reaching out to friends, family and past patrons to help this local gem be repaired and restored so we can continue to entertain audiences, educate children and teens in theater arts and engage the Los Angeles community by providing a center for all performing arts.

Why We Need Your Help

When the theater was constructed, a half-moon-shaped stage was built.  This stage offers unique unimpeded sight lines for the audience, but it was constructed with a sloping rake, which means it's 7 inches high at the front of the stage and 13 inches at the back wall.  (If you place a ball at the back wall, it will roll on its own to the audience's feet!)

The raked stage is impractical -- building sets to fit the weird angle is expensive and time-consuming -- and it's also very dangerous.  Several actors and dancers have sustained injuries during performances.

Also, when the theater was built, the lighting grid was installed too high, which means that the tops of actors' heads are lit but everything else remains in shadow.

Years ago, a large dressing room was added on, but without much-needed donations, it is in a sad state: moldy and frayed carpet, limited electricity, crumbling shelves, insufficient storage and no secure lock-up.

How Your Donation Will Be Spent

  • Rebuild and level the stage
  • Lower the lighting grid by 6 feet
  • Build an enclosed lighting/sound booth
  • Repair and restore the dressing room
  • Replace the severely weathered signage
  • Repair and refresh the front lobby

What Impact Your Donation Will Have

We want to create theater that gets you thinking and discussing, and maybe changes your perspective on the world. Theater has always been about community and sharing stories, ideas and feelings.

Your support will also help us continue to work with children's and teen programs that encourage, teach and promote creative expression.

In return, we'll give you a place where you can enjoy all the arts -- music, dance, vocal performances, stand-up -- and where you can bring friends and family with pride.

The Goodies

  • Private lunch with Castle star Seamus Dever and drop-in guest star!
  • A week's stay in a beautiful ocean-side home in Thailand!
  • Full season subscription, drinks and snacks included!
  • VIP access to meet Katharine Ross and Sam Elliott at a special benefit performance!
  • VIP tickets to all Opening Night Red Carpet galas!
  • Acting classes, vocal instruction, voice-over coaching!
  • Your telephone's message recorded by the signature voice of AMC (Mad Men, Breaking Bad, The Walking Dead!
  • And lots more swag and stuff!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate right now, please share our campaign on Facebook, Twitter, email and good old-fashioned word-of-mouth.

story:
In May of last year, while visiting Buenos Aires, I stumbled upon this show. I thought I had seen everything the stage had to offer on Judy Garland. I remember it was late, I didn't want to go. I even was afraid that I would fall asleep. Still, I went to see it - perhaps expecting something cliché - but Instead I enjoyed an original, sexy, and unexpectedly emotional theatrical experience. It was like hearing the songs for the first time. I realized how little I knew of Garland's songbook, aside from what we are mostly accustomed to hear. The show's uniqueness was puzzling. I was amazed by how sexy and lusty her songs were. Here is a 20 something years old guy singing "The man that got away," pouring his own emotions into the notes. The contrast is difficult to explain. Imagine the 60's Rat Pack, or today's Warblers performing these songs and you're half way there.


I met with the writer and director, Alejandro Ullua - one of the greatest contemporary directors in Argentina. We talked about how much Judy had meant for his father who had recently passed away. This tribute was a way to celebrate his father's memory. And that aspect, although not expressed literally in the piece - came through in its uniqueness. It was more than a concept. It was a love letter. I told Alejandro that I'd love to someday bring the piece to the US. We sucesfully finished a workshop presentation last week in New York City and we premiered the show Off-Broadway to venue owners, some press and friends.


Now... we got invited to the prestigious Dublin Gay Theatre Festival! This is an honor that would give our show good international exposure, as well as it will help us keep and build momentum for our return to the Big Apple in June.
 

We need to fly and accomodate a cast of 6, plus a stage manager and the director for 10 days!


From now until about May 9th, we'll be rehearsing and professionally taping the show and this is where it gets interesting for you. We've crafted some interesting perks ranking from attending rehearsals to participating as audience member on a taped performance or even getting executive producer credit on the Ireland tour.

Check out our perks!

I was amazed by how sexy and lusty her songs were. Here is a 20 something years old guy singing "The man that got away," pouring his own emotions into the notes. The contrast is difficult to explain. Imagine the 60's Rat Pack, or today's Warblers performing these songs and you're half way there.
I met with the writer and director, Alejandro Ullua - one of the greatest contemporary directors in Argentina. We talked about how much Judy had meant for his father who had recently passed away. This tribute was a way to celebrate his father's memory. And that aspect, although not expressed literally in the piece - came through in its uniqueness. It was more than a concept. It was a love letter. I told Alejandro that I'd love to someday bring the piece to the US. We sucesfully finished a workshop presentation last week in New York City and we premiered the show Off-Broadway to venue owners, some press and friends.
Now... we got invited to the prestigious Dublin Gay Theatre Festival! This is an honor that would give our show good international exposure, as well as it will help us keep and build momentum for our return to the Big Apple in June. 
We need to fly and accomodate a cast of 6, plus a stage manager and the director for 10 days! 
From now until about May 9th, we'll be rehearsing and professionally taping the show and this is where it gets interesting for you. We've crafted some interesting perks ranking from attending rehearsals to participating as audience member on a taped performance or even getting executive producer credit on the Ireland tour.
Check out our perks!

story:
OUR STORY:

I recently wrote AZALEA PATH, an inspiring new play that commemorates the 50th anniversary of the death of celebrated American poet Sylvia Plath. The play has been chosen as a selection of the Midtown International Theatre Festival, where it will premiere this Summer. 

For me, this is a personal work in which I explore the challenges of being an artist in American society while balancing family obligations. By contrasting the story of a successful writer with that of my mother, a classically trained singer who chose family life over her singing career, this engrossing play explores the challenges facing the woman and the artist in today's society, promotes education and strives to examine and challenge the misunderstandings still associated with women's rights, the role of the artist in society and the nature of the life of a troubled but gifted artist. www.facebook.com/events/659065070787043/

Remarkably, AZALEA PATH was recently invited to participate in the prestigious Midtown International Theatre Festival (www.midtownfestival.org/) in July 2013, as one of 65 productions chosen from several hundred for this privilege. This is a thrilling opportunity to showcase a new play at an internationally regarded festival in the United States.

New York is an important step both for me as an artist and for this production! I am asking for your assistance to help me fund my production team in New York in order to achieve the greater purpose that has motivated us through the process of mounting a professional production.

We need to generate a minimum of $5,000 (in funds or in-kind support) to make this dream a reality! We are seeking support from corporations, arts council grants, foundations, fund raising events and private donors.

Sylvia Plath returns to her father’s grave on the 50th anniversary of her death, where she encounters ghosts from the past, and a pair of radical feminists determined to rewrite herstory. A drama that explores the fears, struggles and realities of trying to be a successful artist, mother and wife while also battling depression, a chronic condition that affects every day, every relationship, every life decision, Azalea Path is sometimes humorous, sometimes heart-rending, but always inspirational, potent and strikingly honest.

Now in its 14th year, The Midtown International Theatre Festival (MITF) exists to celebrate the diversity of New York theatre culture by discovering and promoting new theatre artists, producers and projects; nurturing a vibrant and innovative artistic community; and connecting one of America's great art forms with a diverse, contemporary audience.


OUR COMPANY:

JACK WERNICK - Writer/Director

MARCINA ZACCARIA - Stage Manager/Dramaturg

CHARLES MOSER - Scenic & Lighting Designer

IRINA GETS - Costume Designer

SEAN VAN DOORNUM - Composer

BETSY HEFFRON - Scenic Designer & Painter

HAL JANNEN - Graphic Design

JOHNNY QUINONES - Videographer

 

HANNAH DAISY BRANDT - Sylvia

EMILY CIOTTI - Anne

MATTI LEINIKKA - Henry

ODELIA AVADI - Pat

ABBY JUDD - Sadie

story:
WHO WE ARE:

Third Eye Theatre Ensemble was launched in September of 2013. Since then we have been working hard to bring The Medium, our first production, to Chicago audiences in October and November of this year. We want to get people talking about the issues we face in today's world and hope the power of music and theater can inspire those conversations at a community level. We also want to provide a professional and well-organized environment for emerging artists to work. There are only a handful of small opera companies in the Chicago area and sadly, some of them have recently shut down. We want to show the Chicago community that opera is relevant in today's world and we also want to showcase the amazing talent we have here!

WHY WE NEED YOUR HELP:

Many people don't realize that arts organizations make very little money on ticket sales. Most of the funding for arts organizations comes from a combination of individual giving, corporate giving, foundations, endowments, and government funded grants. As a brand new company, we certainly don't have any endowments at this point and it is very difficult to get grant money from foundations and government organizations. This is because, understandably, we do not have a body of work to make our case. Therefore, we have to rely on corporate and individual giving for a large part of our funding until we have a few productions under our belt. We hope you will believe in what we want to achieve and will contribute as generously as you can.

WHAT YOU WILL GET:

Our perks are listed on the right hand side of the page. We think they are pretty cool! Everyone who donates to our campaign will be listed in our program and on our website as a supporter of Third Eye Theatre Ensemble. You'll also get our undying gratitude, which we hope counts for a lot, and a feeling that you are making a difference. Your contribution, however big or small, helps us tremendously! You're also helping to keep the performing arts alive. Who wouldn't feel good about that?

WHERE THE MONEY GOES:

  • Artist Salaries (Singers, Actors, Directors, Designers)
  • Sets, Lighting, Props
  • Rehearsal Space Rental
  • Performance Space Rental
  • Keyboard Rental
  • Truck Rental (for transporting set pieces and lighting equipment)
  • The Rights to Perform The Medium
  • Insurance
  • Marketing
  • Unforeseen Expenses (we all know these happen!)
HOW DOES MY CONTRIBUTION HELP:
Here are some examples of what your specific contribution can do for us:
  • $10 buys 1 hour of rehearsal space rental
  • $25 buys 1 hour of truck rental
  • $50 buys 1 hour of performance space rental
  • $100 buys all of the props for our show!
  • $250 buys all of the costumes for our show!
  • $500 buys all of our set pieces and lighting equipment!
  • $1000 buys the rights to perform The Medium
OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP:
  • Come and see the show, October 24 through November 2 (Fridays, Saturdays, Sundays)
  • Share this link with others 
  • Like us on Facebook - https://www.facebook.com/thirdeyete
  • Follow us on Twitter - https://twitter.com/ThirdEyeTE
  • Visit our website at www.thirdeyete.com and sign up for our emails
  • Sign up at iGive.com and shop online at over 1400 retailers who will donate a percentage of your purchase to us! http://www.igive.com/396NT6J
  • Help us spread the word!

story:
Chilliwack School of Performing Arts - Growing

The Chilliwack School Of Performing Arts (CSOPA) is the only non profit, charity status, youth theatre company in Chilliwack. CSOPA’s provides youth, ages 3-18, with musical theatre training, including voice, dance and acting. Enrolment at CSOPA has consistently grown over the last ten years due to the extremely dedicated work of long time personnel, students, and their families.

The growth in demand of what CSOPA offers our youth means that Chilliwack values and wants the skills, personal development, quality time and fun that CSOPA offers our youth which include:

  • developing creativity and imagination
  • building self-confidence and self-awareness
  • strengthening communication skills
  • encouraging a healthy release of emotion


CSOPA's goals are to keep the cost of student enrolment as low as possible all while paying rent for classroom space, stage rehearsal space, wages for instructors, administrative staff, set design and props, and more. We are extremely frugal with our funds, and rely 100% on our fundraising efforts for funding.
In short, because of the demand for what CSOPA offers, we are pushing to raise as much as we can before the new year to pay our bills... specifically by December 31st. Why?

IF WE REACH OUR GOAL, OUR MONEY DOUBLES
If we can reach $9,000 in donations by December 31, 2014 we can double our money!

CSOPA was fortunate enough to be approved for a Sponsorship Matching Grant through artsVest BC totalling $9,000.

The stipulations of the grant are that artsVest BC will match 100% of all business sponsorships, if the sponsorships are from a licensed business (has a business number), and are in excess of $250.

Qualifying businesses that have never sponsored CSOPA before must enter a minimum one-year agreement, while businesses that have sponsored CSOPA in the past must enter a minimum three-year agreement.

In a nutshell, if CSOPA can max out the grant amounts, $9,000 turns into an instant $18,000. This is money wecan use for technical upgrades (lights, sound, music & dance equipment purchases), equipment maintenance, additional programming, and operational costs to keep this organization going and student fees low.

As the deadline quickly approaches (31 Dec), we are still well below expectations in qualifying sponsorships.

This Indiegogo campaign is my plea to you, our biggest supporters, to assist CSOPA in making the most of this wonderful opportunity. Please make a few phone calls and/or visit a few businesses in person and make it easy for people to sponsor us by emailing them a link to our Indiegogo campaign... right here!

We have promotional materials available for download or pick-up in person at the office (season brochures, corporate sponsorship brochures & Addams Family postcards). You are welcome to take as much as you need.

Your assistance in this endeavour will ensure CSOPA can continue offering students the affordable top-notch quality programming and performance opportunities all of us have been accustomed to over the past few years.


Sincerely,


Andrew Smith, BHK
Artistic Director
Chilliwack School of Performing Arts

story:
4/19/14  We did it!

Wow!! Just moments ago, an awesome anonymous donor gave an extremely generous donation of $454 to help us reach our goal of $5,000! Thank you, Anonymous Donor! 

Anika is dancing for joy! And we are excited to achieve our goal (with 20 days remaining!), and be able to assure Anika that she WILL be going to Alvin Ailey this summer. And we are so very grateful for the amazing community of support that has helped us to make this happen!

Any additional donations given before the campaign closes on May 9 will be donated to Living Arts, a wonderful non-profit community arts organization in Southwest Detroit. Anika got her start dancing at Living Arts' Southwest Dance program, and we are happy to be able to give back to Living Arts in this way, and support their efforts to provide high quality arts programming to families in Southwest Detroit, regardless of family income. So, you can still give generously and support this great cause. Thank you, thank you!

Video Update from Anika - 4/18/14

Anika’s talent, hard work and perseverance helped her earn this once-in-a-lifetime opportunity. With your support, she can fulfill her dreams of dancing at The Ailey School for 6 weeks this summer, and take a big step towards her goal of becoming a professional dancer!

Anika’s Story

 “The first time I saw Alvin Ailey Dance Theatre perform, I remember being completely mesmerized by the dancers! I was so impressed by their technical ability, but also the passion and strength they performed with.”  -- Anika

Anika started dancing just before she turned 6. It was fun for her! She had a natural grace and ability, and she quickly developed a passion for dance that has continued to grow over the years. 

Along the way, she began to dream that one day she would be a professional dancer. When she was 13, Anika asked me (her mother), if she could go to New York City and study dance at the Alvin Ailey summer dance intensive in New York. 

(For the non-dancers: each summer, many professional dance companies offer summer dance intensives, usually 2-6 week programs that offer the chance to improve skills and train with new teachers. Participation in these highly competitive, demanding summer intensives is essential if one hopes to join a professional company one day.)

I took Anika to the Detroit Opera House, a stop on Alvin Ailey's national audition tour so she could audition. And, well, let’s just say that she was not quite ready for the big leagues!  She returned the following year, and again was not accepted.

Anika was not discouraged! She continued to work hard, grow as a dancer and pursue her dreams. She attended summer intensives at Blue Lake Fine Arts Camp, and Interlochen. In 2012, Anika joined the Eisenhower Dance Center, and with the opportunity to learn from, and even perform in programs with professional dancers, her skills have improved dramatically in the past two years. 

Last year, Anika auditioned a third time for the Ailey Summer Intensive, this time for the Professional Division. Again, she was not accepted. But she was able to attend the Complexions Contemporary Ballet Intensive in Detroit, which was a wonderful experience for her.

A couple of weeks ago, Anika auditioned with Ailey for a fourth time. This time, she was accepted! She is elated by this opportunity to train at one of the most outstanding dance schools in the country.  Attending the Alvin Ailey Professional Division Summer Intensive would be an important step towards Anika's dream of becoming a professional dancer. But the full cost of this 6 week program in New York City is more than our family can afford.

Anika has worked so hard to earn this, and we don’t want her to miss this opportunity. They say it takes a village, and we are reaching out to our village to ask for your support. We hope that you -- our family and friends, supporters of the arts, supporters of young people's dreams – will help a young dancer from Detroit fulfill her dream! 

The Goal = $5,000

The tuition for the 6-week Alvin Ailey program is $2675, and the Ailey School estimates additional costs of $ 4916 for housing, meals and other living expenses, for a total of $7366. With transportation to New York, required dance clothes and related costs, we expect the total cost to be $8,000. We are able to pay a portion of these costs, and Anika is contributing money from her summer job last year, but we still need to raise $4800. Our goal is $5000 ($5000 - 4% fee to Indiegogo = $4800)

We are doing all we can, including approaching local businesses for donations and holding a yard sale.

Each donation, regardless of the amount,  gets us closer to our goal!   So, please give according to your ability. We appreciate each and every gift. And, don't forget to check out the perks Anika is offering!

If we do not reach our goal, the money will still be used to advance Anika’s dance education, paying for dance classes and a summer intensive closer to home.

If we exceed our goal, we will donate any funds over the goal to Living Arts, a non-profit arts organization where Anika got her start and danced for 10 years. Living Arts offers high quality arts programming for children in Detroit, and ensures that no child is turned away due to financial constraints. So, please give generously!

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that everyone is not able to donate. But everyone can help Anika by making some noise about our campaign. Use the Indiegogo “share” tools. Spread the word to friends and family -- anyone who may want help a talented, young hardworking dancer achieve her dream!  Thank you!
