story:
The Skinny

My name is Colby Nielsen.  Better known by some as Mummbles.  I am an aspiring professional dancer with an affinity for tap.  I have recently been training to break some tap speed world records.  The first one being "Most Taps in a Minute" set at 1,163 by Anthony Morigerato.  I have the speed and am very close to the conditioning to do it but I still can't break it alone.  

Guiness Book of World Records will send out adjudicators and equipment in order to prove I can do it but this is done at my expense.  Being based out of London and the fact that they do this for a living, means that breaking a record is unfortunately not cheap.  So this has switched from a solo effort to a team effort. Want to be a part of it?  Here is how it works: On the top right is my current verses my goal.  Contribute any amount you want.  Below that you will see perks I will give for different amounts.  Once this is closed and I have the amount I need, I set up the record attempt with Guiness and away we go!  

In the gallery tab I have some videos of my training and I will be adding more as I keep training.  Feel free to take a look and see the progress I am making towards beating the record.  This video is where I stand at the start of this project.  It is about 1,144 taps per minute.


Can't contribute?  That isn't a problem. You can still play a part by sharing on social media. Please use the sharing tools just below the pitch video at the top of this page.  If you have contributed or plan on contributing still use the social media sharing tools. The more people that see it the better chance we have of breaking a record!  So please Share, Share, Share.

The Game 

You may have noticed that there were some changes between scenes in the video.  The name of the game is to name all of those changes. Watch the video and see what has changed in it.  Then be sure your have contributed $50 because that perk is what allows you to guess and get the extra reward.  Then send me your guess in a message, not in the comments.  When the project's funding phase has come to an end I will show everyone the list of things that changed and put a list of who was correct up.  Those that guessed correctly get a special reward.

For those able to, they will get to take part in the upcoming video that I will make as a thank you to all my backers.  This either means working with me in person if you can or getting a video of you dancing to me and I will add it to the video.

On top of that I will also give out another special surprise gift to all that got it right.  The special gift will be announced along with those that got it correct at the project's end!

The Details

Below is the break down of where the $9,500 I raise will go.  This site is obviously not just about asking for handouts.  So If you look to the right side or a little further below on here, you will see what I will give you in exchange for becoming a part of this with me.  Aside from the listed "perks", I am also going to be asking opinions and votes on things related to our record.  Because let's be honest it doesn't happen without your help so you get to be as much a part of this as I do!

Without further ado, the funding break down:


Ultimately I aim to reach my goal through this crowd funding campaign alone but if I fall short then the money gained will still be put towards everything outlined above.  In conjunction with this crowd funding campaign, I am also setting up a workshop in December.  If this campaign falls a little short this will be an avenue to make up the difference. Plus it will also be first opportunity to use your perk of free admittance into a class or entire workshop. 

Speaking of Perks, here is the guide to the "Let's Break A Record" Perks:



On the flip side, if I happen to surpass my goal then I still have uses for the extra funds.  A few things on the list if you are all generous enough to contribute and share this project on social media with your friends enough to surpass the goal are:
  • New taps to replace my engraved and mounted taps
  • A fund created to give the studio new floors for so graciously letting me tap all over them.  The floors have several dents and divets from my shoes.  I am appreciative of my studio allowing me to abuse them so much haha.  The least I can do is help put in new, better floors ;)
  • I will also throw some into a better success party for all of those that made it happen :)

    The Send Off

    Remember anything you can do to help makes you are part of this record too.  This isn't my record any more it is ours!  So contribute and get some cool gifts, share on social media, and talk to people about it.

    Please like my Facebook, follow my Twitter, and subscribe to my YouTube.  The links are just below.

    If you have any questions for me then feel free to message me on here or on my social media spaces or email me at dancer.mummbles@gmail.com
story_txt:
The Skinny My name is Colby Nielsen.  Better known by some as Mummbles.  I am an aspiring professional dancer with an affinity for tap.  I have recently been training to break some tap speed world records.  The first one being "Most Taps in a Minute" set at 1,163 by Anthony Morigerato.  I have the speed and am very close to the conditioning to do it but I still can't break it alone.  
Guiness Book of World Records will send out adjudicators and equipment in order to prove I can do it but this is done at my expense.  Being based out of London and the fact that they do this for a living, means that breaking a record is unfortunately not cheap.  So this has switched from a solo effort to a team effort. Want to be a part of it?  Here is how it works: On the top right is my current verses my goal.  Contribute any amount you want.  Below that you will see perks I will give for different amounts.  Once this is closed and I have the amount I need, I set up the record attempt with Guiness and away we go!  
In the gallery tab I have some videos of my training and I will be adding more as I keep training.  Feel free to take a look and see the progress I am making towards beating the record.  This video is where I stand at the start of this project.  It is about 1,144 taps per minute.

Can't contribute?  That isn't a problem. You can still play a part by sharing on social media. Please use the sharing tools just below the pitch video at the top of this page.  If you have contributed or plan on contributing still use the social media sharing tools. The more people that see it the better chance we have of breaking a record!  So please Share, Share, Share.   The Game

story:
Vestments of the Gods sounds exciting! What's it all about?

So glad you asked! Vestments of the Gods is a musical play by Owen Panettieri with music by David Carl. Presented by 5000 Broadway Productions Inc., Vestments of the Gods will be making its world premiere at Theater 80, 80 St Marks Place New York, NY 10003 during the The New York International Fringe Festival - FringeNYC - running August 8th - 24th 2014. 

Vestments of the Gods is a fresh take on Sophocles’ Antigone that takes place in a modern day suburban elementary school.When Annie and Hayden wear costumes in violation of school rules to the Thebes Street Elementary Halloween Celebration, a small power struggle between students and faculty erupts into a full-out battle for control… with tragic consequences. And songs. Vestments of the Gods is suitable for audiences age 10+ but deals with serious issues such as bullying, peer pressure and discrimination by both children and adults.

I'm sold! What do you need to achieve success?

It takes a village to fund a Fringe show! Your contributions will go toward financing costs related to:

  • Rehearsal space! Sets! Costumes! Lights! Scripts & Scores! Paying the wonderful actors you'll see on stage! Paying the lovely designers and technicians working tirelessly off stage! 
  • All funds collected will go completely toward costs related to the show. The more we raise, the more we have to work with to complete our artistic vision of the show. 
  • For each donation level we have set up some fun perks to thank you for your support. And we will send you special updates on the progress of the show leading up to Opening Night! 

Alright! But why Vestments of the Gods? Why now?

Vestments of the Gods takes a classic story and applies it to issues of equality, authority and morality that we are currently facing. It is a story with characters whose voices need to be heard right now. 

I believe in you guys! Are there other ways I can help?

Whether or not you can contribute financially, you can definitely help our efforts to fund the show:

  • Spread the word and let friends and relatives know about the show and our campaign!
  • Check out our website www.vestmentsofthegods.com 
  •  for more info about the show! Like us on Facebook and follow us on Twitter
  • Tickets go on sale July 18th at www.fringenyc.org! Come see the show!

story:
Hello,

We are Éclat Dance, a youth dance company focused in Ballet, neoclassical and contemporary.

The company welcomes dance students from several different dance schools and studios across Vancouver Island to provide extra training and performance opportunities.

Éclat Dance was established by two successful ballet dancers who wanted to give the chance to other young dancers to develop their careers and reach their true potential. Jessa Pereira, Artistic Director of the Youth Company, is from Vancouver Island herself and after completing her dance studies at the prestigious Goh Ballet, in Vancouver, BC, she is back to Vancouver Island to initiate this project which is a dream of hers. 

We are raising money to take our wonderful and super talented young dancers to perform in the big city of London, where they will also have the opportunity to take various classes, workshops, visit the backstage of the Royal Opera House and other historic theatres, visit museums, and have the most incredible experience of their lives on an unforgettable dance tour.


Your contribution is a vote of support that we need to move to bigger venues, woo larger audiences, and create the groundswell of support required to help our dancers to thrive. 


"MOTUS" 

A work of Art Showcasing the Beauty and Complexity of Movement. 

With Original Choreography by Davi Rodrigues and Monica Proenca and Classical pieces staged by Directors Vlad & Jessa Pereira, "MOTUS" brings to stage an innovative way to  explore and expresse the diversity of movement through a variety of styles...

MOTUS is the first creative work of Éclat Dance Youth Company, an enssemble of young dancers of the Comox Valley, Vancouver Island.

The Premiere of “MOTUS” is planned to happen in April of 2015 in Courtenay, BC and the Youth Company plans to tour their production across Vancouver Island, to communities such as Nanaimo, Victoria, Campbell River, Parksville, Port Alberni and Qualicum.



Help Spread the Word

Money isn’t the only thing that makes dance thrive, and there are plenty of ways to help our momentum bound! 

• Help make this campaign viral using the Indiegogo share tools! Our art is by no means limited to our zip code, and Éclat Dance was created with the intent of sharing the beauty of dance with the world.

• If you know someone who would be thrilled to support our vision, please send them this link, put them in touch with us or invite them to a performance.

• Keep sharing the wonder…

story:
Are You Ready to Get Naked?

WWW.NAKEDTHEATRECOMPANY.COM

Naked Theatre Company was founded by Rachael Murray, Jared Murray, and Cory Cunningham last year near Washington, DC. We aim to use the best available technology to bridge the gap between process and performance. We want our audiences to have an immersive experience with our shows from beginning to end, allowing you to see the process in a very raw and "naked" way.

Our goal is to capture the process of creating a show on film to share with our audience online and before the show. During rehearsals, meetings, and other events, we'll be taping and editing the footage to share with anyone interested! We even hope to get feedback from viewers as the show is still being built! Art isn't just about the final product - it's also about the journey, and we want to invite you to join us in that journey and find out why it's so special and addicting to those involved!


The Show


"Bitch: A Play About Antigone" by Andy Boyd is our second production and first attempt at a new work! We've already been accepted to D.C.'s Capital Fringe Festival this July, and the only thing left to do is to raise the funds! This play is a reinterpretation of the Antigone story, best known from Sophocles’ play called, you guessed it, Antigone. Julia Sears will be directing the show, and we'll be following the challenges and rewards of working directly with a new playwright to produce a new show!


The Money


Naked Theatre Company was founded by three starving actors, and so we're looking for your support to help us get theatre out to new audiences while enriching the experience for long-time theatre-goers! We've divided our budget out so that you can see exactly where the money is going. 

Budget:

  • Actors (7) $700
  • Director $100
  • Film Person $100
  • Stage Manager $100
  • Lighting Designer $100
  • Sound Designer $100
  • Costume Designer $100
  • Playwright: $100
  • Advertising (postcards/posters) $100
  • Set $100
  • Props $100
  • Costumes $150
  • Lighting/Sound $85
  • Script copies/paper $150
  • Rehearsal Space $800
  • Indiegogo Fees $115
  • GOAL: $3000


If we reach this goal, it allows us to produce our show without going into debt! 

The Dream

Our first show, R.U.R., was called "an impressive debut" by The Washington Paper and we'd like to keep that momentum going for our second show. We hope it will be the beginning of a new way of experiencing and taking part in theatre. We'd like to start having our own season, start building a community of contributors and patrons, and start discussions about the boundaries that currently exist in this art form and how to bend or break them. It's ambitious, yes, but we think it's an important step towards the survival and revitalization of American theatre.

Last year we live-streamed the whole process. This year we're taking a more refined approach. We feel by editing the content, we'll make it more accessible and easier to digest. Ultimately we hope to meet somewhere in the middle, providing a way to have interaction and instant-feedback during the rehearsal process as well as providing edited videos for those who need to play catch up! We hope to showcase how actors and the director interact in a rehearsal. We also hope to show what goes into designing a show. You can see the struggles along the way, the sacrifices that must be made, and the small victories that add up to the final product. Then you can come see the show live and see how it all turns out. You can congratulate your favorite actor on coming so far since the first day. Or you could do it all in reverse - come see the show and then take a look back at the rehearsals and meetings that made the show what it has become.

It's new. It's scary. It's naked.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people can't even afford to donate $10 and, believe us, we understand. If you'd like to help in some way, though, anything is appreciated. Here are ways you could help:

  • We're looking for spaces where we can rehearse in June. Have a space or a lead on a space?
  • Do you have a website or business where we could advertise for free?
  • Check out our website to see the latest videos!
  • Want to host a party for the cast/crew? We haven't budgeted for fun things, but it's just as important!
  • Like us on Facebook
  • Follow us on Twitter

Contact Us

Any questions? You can contact us at nakedtheatrecompany@gmail.com or by calling (202)670-8359. Visit our website atwww.nakedtheatrecompany.com for more information!

story:
What Are We Doing?

An adaptation of "A Midsummer Night's Dream" we've come to call "Midsummer Lovers."

An imaginative outdoor production of a Shakespearean classic that focuses on the tale of the four misguided lovers. It is brought to the campus of Quinnipiac University by theater alumni and students to form a new, exciting partnership. Directed by fearless Adjunct Professor Drew Scott and alum Melissa Mullaney, the cast takes the audience on an unforgettable journey into the woods.

by William Shakespeare 
Directed by Drew Scott 
assisted by Melissa Mullaney

Presented on Quinnipiac University's Pine Grove**
Friday, June 20 at 6:30 P.M.
Saturday, June 21 at 2:00 P.M. and 6:30 P.M.
Sunday, June 22 at 2:00 P.M.
FREE admission!

**Rain location: Quinnipiac's Black Box Theater

Cast:

  • Hermia - Juli McGourty
  • Lysander - Michael Bobenhausen 
  • Helena - Jessica Otterbine  
  • Demetrius - Michael Pray 
  • Puck - Krystle Bernier
  • Oberon - Melissa Mullaney

What Is Tieline Theater?

In the Quinnipiac Theater department, there's a tradition that's been upheld since its inception. After performing in their first mainstage show all newcomers receive a piece of tie line, presented to them by the veterans of the department.  This tie line is a symbol of inviting them wholeheartedly into the theater family called the "D-Lites" or "Drama Lites" (but we'll save the origin of that D-Lite-ful name for another time).

The piece of tie line has come to represent many things since the tradition started, and though its origins are somewhat blurred, the strongest image is one of unity and bonds. Much like how tie line holds together a theater set; students and alumni of the department are all held together and connected by their experience and the powerful work they've done, no matter where they are.

We have incorporated this idea of being connected into the very core of our performace. "It's like you and your scene partner are attached by a million tiny strings, so everything each of you does directly influences the other." (Timothy Cochran: Professor of Communication and Theater, Holyoke Community College) We want to connect with each other, with other student and performers, with the audience and with the community as a whole. 

And so, our goal is to raise awareness of the theater department's potential, not only on the Quinnipiac Campus but in the surrounding community. We aim to build a stronger alumni/undergraduate relationship as well as a continuing relationship with the faculty further reinforcing those bonds and forging new ones. It will give students a chance to put into practice what they have learned in the classroom, as well as letting alumni and students learn from each other in a creative environment.

This project is being used as the cornerstone for future endeavors; including full-length summer shows and workshops. We wish to bring theater to the community and enhance the local arts culture, while at the same time promoting the talents and the assets that Quinnipiac can provide to the surrounding community.

What We Need & What You Get

In order to successfully put on this show, we need money for:

  • Housing and food for tech week and performances
  • Posters, flyers, and other miscellaneous publicity
  • Transportation (gas and train fare)
  • Costumes and props
  • Stipend for cast and crew

As a result, we'll be able to provide:

  • A touching but fun and exciting romp through the woods!
  • FREE Admission!
  • Some very fun and unique rewards including things like a personalized sonnet, a specially filmed version of the show, a workshop with the actors, and even a lovely reception hosted by the whole Tieline crew!
  • The groundwork to make this kind of project a recurring yearly event.

The Impact

The goal of Quinnipiac's theater department has always been "Theater for Community." But that community is both internal and external. By supporting us, you'll not only be strengthening the student/alumni theater community, but also extending the Quinnipiac/Hamden theater community beyond the confines of the school year. We chose to adapt A Midsummer Night's Dream because we feel the conflict and story of the Lovers, as crazy as it can get, is something that will really connect with people on many levels, and connection is the ultimate purpose of our project. We genuinely feel that this project will leave a lasting impression with everyone involved and will not only challenge and bring the cast together, but strengthen the ties between the community and the art that can flourish within it. If theater hadn't been such an important part of our lives, we wouldn't be doing this. If we didn't think that doing great theater that engages the community was important and could enrich people's lives, we wouldn't be doing this. We want to give back to a school and community that's given us so much, but we need your help! And with it, we know we'll give people a unique and very entertaining experience while laying the groundwork for even greater things to come.

Other Ways You Can Help!

If you support our effort and can't contribute monetarily, never fear! Just spreading the word is an INCREDIBLE help. Tell your friends, your family, your co-workers… anyone! Even a little can go a long way, and we deeply appreciate any form of assistance you can provide.

Meet the Cast & Crew!

Drew Scott (Director)

Drew Scott is a member of Actors’ Equity Association and has performed and directed with companies on both the East and West Coast such as Hartford Stage Company, The Odyssey Theatre, Long Wharf Theatre, The McCarter Theatre, and Yale Repertory Theatre. Drew holds an M.F.A. in Directing from The University of California at Irvine where he studied with Jerzy Grotowski, Patrick Stewart, Keith Fowler, and Luis Valdez and served as assistant to Robert Cohen for a Focused Research Project in the staging of Medieval Drama. He was the Founding Director of the Pacific Shakespeare Company and Associate Director at the Millbrook Playhouse for two seasons. Favorite directing credits include The Crucible, Twelfth Night, The Lark, Translations, The Second Shepherds’ Play, Ernest In Love, Krapp’s Last Tape, Man of La Mancha, Love’s Labors Lost, and the American premiere of Edward Bond’s Restoration.

Melissa Mullaney (Assistant Director/Oberon)

Melissa Mullaney is a recent alum from Quinnipiac, having graduated with her Master of Arts in Teaching in secondary education this past May and she received her Bachelor of Arts in History from Quinnipiac in 2013. She is originally from Quincy, Massachusetts. Melissa hopes to use her skills she learned through Quinnipiac in her future endeavors as an educator. As an undergrad, she had the opportunity to direct her own show, Swimming in the Shallows by Adam Bock through the student-run Fourth Wall Theater. Melissa’s favorite productions include assistant directing the following shows with Drew Scott: Ernest in Love, Dead Man’s Cell Phone, and Mauritius.

Jessica Otterbine (Helena)

Jessica Otterbine is an actor, director, educator, and administrator. She works for the New York State Summer School of the Arts, School of Theater as the Assistant Director for Administration. In her artistic life, she has directed two plays, Almost, Maine and The Clean House. Favorite acting roles include Maire (Translations), Margery (Vinegar Tom), and Holofernia (Love’s Labours Lost). She was trained at the National Theater Institute at the Eugene O'Neill Theater Center. There, she studied Viewpoints and Suzuki with Siti Company and Lecoq with London-based company Complicite, among other disciplines such as Droznin movement, classical acting, Balinese mask, and stage combat. She holds a BA in Theater and Sociology from Quinnipiac University, class of 2012. In the fall, she will be attending Villanova University in the Masters in Theatre Studies program.

Julianne McGourty (Hermia)

Julianne McGourty is a Worcester, MA native; she seriously got involved in theater in the Burncoat High Theater Magnet program a decade ago. Since then she has studied a multitude of theater styles, such as Lecoq, Viewpoints, Comedia dell'arte and stage combat, to name a few. She also has experience in Film acting, competitive Ballroom Dancing and is currently training as a voice actor in Albany, NY.
She's a 2012 graduate of Quinnipiac University's Journalism program with a minor (but major passion) in Theater: where some highlighs include The Clean House (Ana), Dead Man's Cell Phone (Hermia) and Almost, Maine (Marci). She was also an active member and officer of the Alpha Psi Omega Theater Honor Society. She has worked at theaters such as Long Wharf Theater (New Haven, CT) and The Abingdon Theater (NYC), and traveled to Nicaragua to teach theater in schools.
Most recently Juli has acted, stage managed and run tech at Stageloft Repertory Theater in Sturbridge, Mass. Some favorite shows include The Grapes of Wrath (Rose of Sharon), Beverly Hillbillies (Elly May), The Mousetrap (Miss Casewell), Othello (Roderigo) and As You Like It (Rosalind). This summer she will be teaching multiple sessions of the "Enter Laughing" youth theater workshops at Stageloft.

Michael Pray (Demetrius)

Michael Pray is resident of Chicopee, MA who first took interest in theater at the tail end of high school. Performing in an abridged version of A Midsummer Night's Dream was enough to inspire him to pursue the art, and he is now an actor, teacher, and former student of Holyoke Community College and Quinnipiac University's theater programs. He is a founding member of Real Live Theatre and Teaching Artist with Serious Play! Theatre Ensemble where he teaches workshops in Suzuki, Anne Bogart's Viewpoints, and stage combat. He has also taught at Pioneer Valley Performing Arts Charter School, Holyoke Community College, and in residence at various schools as well as CT-based Performing Arts Programs and abroad in Nicaragua. Some favorite roles include Cassio (Othello), Fencer (Commedia dell Smartass), and Moritz (Spring Awakening) and most recently appeared in Stageloft Repertory Theater's production of One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest as Billy Bibbit.

Krystle Bernier (Puck)

Krystle Bernier is a resident of Easthampton, MA, and has had the pleasure of working with various arts and theatre groups in the western Massachusetts area. She has served as student producer and actress for community theatre groups, The Granby Arts Project and Black Cat Theatre. She worked for the shows and entertainment department at Six Flags New England where she held the role of Janis Joplin in Dead Legends Live! She also volunteered her summers during high school as an acting coach and mentor with Act Now! Inc., a nonprofit organization based out of Amherst, MA that aims to inspire and empower young women through filmmaking and improvisational acting. Some of her favorite roles include Alice (Alice in Wonderland), Beatrice (Much Ado About Nothing), and Whitney (Lily Hare). Krystle is currently working as a communications associate for a non-profit in Northampton, MA and continues to volunteer her nights and weekends to community theatres in the surrounding area.

Our Stage!

Stay Tuned!

We'll have more exciting updates as we go along! Thanks for your support!
story_txt:
What Are We Doing?An adaptation of "A Midsummer Night's Dream" we've come to call "Midsummer Lovers."An imaginative outdoor production of a Shakespearean classic that focuses on the tale of the four misguided lovers. It is brought to the campus of Quinnipiac University by theater alumni and students to form a new, exciting partnership. Directed by fearless Adjunct Professor Drew Scott and alum Melissa Mullaney, the cast takes the audience on an unforgettable journey into the woods.by William Shakespeare Directed by Drew Scott assisted by Melissa MullaneyPresented on Quinnipiac University's Pine Grove**Friday, June 20 at 6:30 P.M.Saturday, June 21 at 2:00 P.M. and 6:30 P.M.Sunday, June 22 at 2:00 P.M.FREE admission!**Rain location: Quinnipiac's Black Box TheaterCast:
Hermia - Juli McGourty

Lysander - Michael Bobenhausen 

Helena - Jessica Otterbine  

Demetrius - Michael Pray 

Puck - Krystle Bernier

Oberon - Melissa Mullaney
What Is Tieline Theater?In the Quinnipiac Theater department, there's a tradition that's been upheld since its inception. After performing in their first mainstage show all newcomers receive a piece of tie line, presented to them by the veterans of the department.  This tie line is a symbol of inviting them wholeheartedly into the theater family called the "D-Lites" or "Drama Lites" (but we'll save the origin of that D-Lite-ful name for another time).The piece of tie line has come to represent many things since the tradition started, and though its origins are somewhat blurred, the strongest image is one of unity and bonds. Much like how tie line holds together a theater set; students and alumni of the department are all held together and connected by their experience and the powerful work they've done, no matter where they are.We have incorporated this idea of being connected into the very core of our performace. "It's like you and your scene partner are attached by a million tiny strings, so everything each of you does directly influences the other." (Timothy Cochran: Professor of Communication and Theater, Holyoke Community College) We want to connect with each other, with other student and performers, with the audience and with the community as a whole. And so, our goal is to raise awareness of the theater department's potential, not only on the Quinnipiac Campus but in the surrounding community. We aim to build a stronger alumni/undergraduate relationship as well as a continuing relationship with the faculty further reinforcing those bonds and forging new ones. It will give students a chance to put into practice what they have learned in the classroom, as well as letting alumni and students learn from each other in a creative environment.This project is being used as the cornerstone for future endeavors; including full-length summer shows and workshops. We wish to bring theater to the community and enhance the local arts culture, while at the same time promoting the talents and the assets that Quinnipiac can provide to the surrounding community.What We Need & What You GetIn order to successfully put on this show, we need money for:
Housing and food for tech week and performances
Posters, flyers, and other miscellaneous publicity
Transportation (gas and train fare)
Costumes and props
Stipend for cast and crew
As a result, we'll be able to provide:
A touching but fun and exciting romp through the woods!

FREE Admission!
Some very fun and unique rewards including things like a personalized sonnet, a specially filmed version of the show, a workshop with the actors, and even a lovely reception hosted by the whole Tieline crew!
The groundwork to make this kind of project a recurring yearly event.
The ImpactThe goal of Quinnipiac's theater department has always been "Theater for Community." But that community is both internal and external. By supporting us, you'll not only be strengthening the student/alumni theater community, but also extending the Quinnipiac/Hamden theater community beyond the confines of the school year. We chose to adapt A Midsummer Night's Dream because we feel the conflict and story of the Lovers, as crazy as it can get, is something that will really connect with people on many levels, and connection is the ultimate purpose of our project. We genuinely feel that this project will leave a lasting impression with everyone involved and will not only challenge and bring the cast together, but strengthen the ties between the community and the art that can flourish within it. If theater hadn't been such an important part of our lives, we wouldn't be doing this. If we didn't think that doing great theater that engages the community was important and could enrich people's lives, we wouldn't be doing this. We want to give back to a school and community that's given us so much, but we need your help! And with it, we know we'll give people a unique and very entertaining experience while laying the groundwork for even greater things to come.Other Ways You Can Help!If you support our effort and can't contribute monetarily, never fear! Just spreading the word is an INCREDIBLE help. Tell your friends, your family, your co-workers… anyone! Even a little can go a long way, and we deeply appreciate any form of assistance you can provide.Meet the Cast & Crew!Drew Scott (Director)Drew Scott is a member of Actors’ Equity Association and has performed and directed with companies on both the East and West Coast such as Hartford Stage Company, The Odyssey Theatre, Long Wharf Theatre, The McCarter Theatre, and Yale Repertory Theatre. Drew holds an M.F.A. in Directing from The University of California at Irvine where he studied with Jerzy Grotowski, Patrick Stewart, Keith Fowler, and Luis Valdez and served as assistant to Robert Cohen for a Focused Research Project in the staging of Medieval Drama. He was the Founding Director of the Pacific Shakespeare Company and Associate Director at the Millbrook Playhouse for two seasons. Favorite directing credits include The Crucible, Twelfth Night, The Lark, Translations, The Second Shepherds’ Play, Ernest In Love, Krapp’s Last Tape, Man of La Mancha, Love’s Labors Lost, and the American premiere of Edward Bond’s Restoration.Melissa Mullaney (Assistant Director/Oberon)Melissa Mullaney is a recent alum from Quinnipiac, having graduated with her Master of Arts in Teaching in secondary education this past May and she received her Bachelor of Arts in History from Quinnipiac in 2013.
